title: Heritage Plantation Ownersâ€™ Association v. Paone
text:
THIS OPINION HAS NO PRECEDENTIAL VALUE.Â  IT SHOULD NOT BE CITED OR RELIED ON AS 
PRECEDENT IN ANY PROCEEDING EXCEPT AS PROVIDED BY RULE 239(d)(2), SCACR.
THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Court of Appeals

  
    
      
Heritage Plantation Ownersâ€™ Association, Inc., Respondents,
v.
William Paone and Janice Paone, Appellants.
      
    
  


Appeal From Georgetown County
Benjamin H. Culbertson, Master-in-Equity

Â Unpublished Opinion No. 2006-UP-001
Heard October 12, 2005 â€“ Filed January 4, 2006Â Â Â 

AFFIRMED


  
    
      
Mark Andrew Brunty, of Myrtle Beach, for Appellants.
Richard M. Lovelace, Jr of Conway; Robert Norris Hill , of Newberry, for Respondents.
      
    
  

PER CURIAM:Â  In this action to enforce restrictive covenants, William and Janice Paone appeal the master-in-equityâ€™s order requiring them to remove a flagpole and basketball goal from their property and pay Heritage Plantation Ownersâ€™ Association, Inc. $27,575.00 in fines and $15,054.83 in attorneyâ€™s fees and costs.Â  We affirm.Â  
FACTS
The Paones began construction of their house in Heritage Plantation in late 1999 or early 2000.Â  The Heritage Plantation Declaration of Covenants and Conditions and Restrictions requires owners to receive written approval by the Heritage Plantationsâ€™ Architectural Review Board (ARB) for all construction, including landscaping.Â  In addition to their house plans, the Paones submitted their landscaping and drainage plans to the ARB.Â  Throughout the landscaping project, the ARB required numerous changes to the plans.Â  At the Paonesâ€™ direction, the ARB conferred with the Paonesâ€™ general contractor, Bruce Carrell, who had built numerous homes in Heritage Plantation.Â  On July 10, 2000, the ARB held a special meeting to consider the Paonesâ€™ construction.Â  In a letter sent that day, the ARB required several revisions to the landscaping plan.Â  The Paonesâ€™ landscaper claimed that on July 20, 2000, he submitted a revised landscaping plan for the meeting that was to be held that day.Â  Those plans included a flagpole.Â  The agenda and minutes of the ARBâ€™s July 20 meeting do not indicate that the Paonesâ€™ landscaping was discussed at that meeting.Â  
At the August 3, 2000 meeting, the ARB again considered the Paonesâ€™ landscape plan.Â  It approved the plan subject to completion of the installation of landscaping material on the exterior side of the north fence.Â  After this meeting, members of the ARB noticed the flagpole and a portable basketball goal on the Paone property.Â  The ARB sent Carrell a letter on August 24, 2000 advising him that although flagpoles may be approved, the ARB must approve the location prior to installation.Â  It stated the current flagpole location was not acceptable.Â  The ARB also advised Carrell that portable basketball goals are not permitted and basketball goals must be permanently installed.Â  It directed Carrell to re-submit plans showing the permanently installed basketball goal and the new location of the flagpole to the ARB for approval.Â  In a letter dated September 5, 2000, Carrell replied that a revised landscape plan with the location of the flagpole was submitted to the ARB on July 20.Â  It enclosed a copy of the plan.Â  He also explained the Paones had purchased the basketball goal before they understood that only stationary goals were permitted.Â  He asked that the basketball goal be approved since it would be screened by landscaping.Â Â  
The ARB responded that prior to Carrellâ€™s letter of September 5, 2000, it had never received a landscaping plan indicating a flagpole installation and it had not approved such a plan.Â  The ARB informed Carrell that it had eleven copies of plans for landscape, drainage, irrigation and re-submittals, but the only one showing a flagpole was the one Carrell submitted on September 5, 2000.Â  It requested Carrell submit a site plan with an alternate location for the flagpole that is not directly in front of the home and is some distance from the street.Â  In addition, the ARB did not approve the request for the basketball goal unless it received a letter verifying that the goal is permanently installed.Â  The ARB cautioned that Carrell must submit both an alternate flagpole location and the basketball goal verification before the next ARB meeting on September 21, 2000 and that â€œ[f]ailure to do so will cause this property to be in violation of the Covenants and Guidelines and may incur fines.â€Â  
The Paonesâ€™ attorney subsequently wrote to the ARB maintaining that the landscaping plans showing the flagpole location were dropped off on July 20, 2000 and this was the plan that was approved on August 3, 2000.Â  The attorney asserted the Paones had no plans for removal of the flagpole at that time.Â  
The Heritage Plantation Ownersâ€™ Association subsequently brought this action seeking an injunction requiring the removal of the flagpole and portable basketball goal, payment of cumulative fines for violation of the covenants of $25 a day, retroactive to January 1, 2001, and attorneyâ€™s fees and costs.Â  In their answer and counterclaim, the Paones asserted that they submitted landscapes to the ARB containing the flagpole and the ARB approved those plans.Â  They requested a return of their $2,500.00 deposit, damages for their travel costs, lost wages, and emotional distress, and attorneyâ€™s fees and cost.
The trial court ordered the Paones to immediately take down the flagpole and not re-erect it without written approval by the ARB.Â  It also ordered the Paones to remove the portable basketball goal from view of anyone within Heritage Plantation other than themselves.Â  Although the court found the flagpole and basketball goal were separate violations of the covenants, it imposed a single fine of $25.00 a day from August 15, 2000 through the date of the hearing, for a total of $27,575.00.Â  It also awarded the Association $15,054.83 in attorneyâ€™s fees and costs.Â  The Paones filed a motion to alter or amend the judgment, which the trial court denied.Â  This appeal followed.Â Â  
STANDARD OF REVIEW
An action to enforce a restrictive covenant is in equity.Â  South Carolina Depâ€™t of Natural Res. v. Town of McClellanville, 345 S.C. 617, 622, 550 S.E.2d 299, 302 (2001).Â  In an appeal from an equitable action, tried by a special referee alone, the appellate court has jurisdiction to find facts in accordance with our own view of the preponderance of the evidence.Â  Id.Â  The court should not, however, disregard the findings of the special referee, who was in a better position to weigh the credibility of witnesses.Â  Tiger, Inc. v. Fisher Agro, Inc., 301 S.C. 229, 237, 391 S.E.2d 538, 543 (1990). 
LAW/ANALYSIS
I.  Existence of violations
The Paones argue the facts of this case do not support the masterâ€™s ruling because the evidence reveals the Paonesâ€™ plan was submitted and approved.Â  We disagree.Â  
The Paonesâ€™ landscape designer, Brad Ingram testified that after the ARBâ€™s letter of July 12, 2000 he created a revised landscaping plan.Â  This plan included the flagpole.Â  Ingram explained that normally he would deliver plans to the builder who would in turn submit the plans.Â  In this instance, he received a call from the Paonesâ€™ builder, Bruce Carrell on the morning of July 20 wanting to know if there was any way the plans could be submitted that day in order that they be considered at the ARBâ€™s meeting that evening.Â  Ingram copied the plans himself at the sales office at Heritage Plantation and then delivered the plans to the receptionist at the ownerâ€™s clubhouse by 11:30 a.m.Â  The revised plans, however, were not considered at the ARBâ€™s meeting on July 20.Â  
Art Kent, a member of the ARB during the time the Paones were constructing their home, claimed the ARB never saw the revised plans showing the flagpole location until Carrellâ€™s letter dated September 5, 2000.Â  He asserted that the ARB went through all of its files and did not find the plans Ingram claimed to have delivered on the July 20.Â  Kent averred the ARB had never lost any correspondence before when dealing with 350 homes.Â  He explained that when the ARB approved the Paonesâ€™ basic landscaping plan on August 3, 2000, it considered the written plans that had been submitted for the July 12, 2000 meeting and Carrellâ€™s oral agreement to make the changes required by the ARB.Â  
Importantly, on August 8, 2000 Carrell submitted a request to add the basketball goal to the Paonesâ€™ yard.Â  The attached landscaping plan that showed the addition of the basketball goal did not include the flagpole.Â  Soon after the controversy over the flagpole and basketball goal arose, Carrell wrote to the ARB distancing himself from the matter and instructing the ARB to work directly with Mr. Paone on these issues.Â  In the letter, Carrell stated, â€œNeither the flagpole nor the basketball goal were part of our construction agreement, and we did not arrange for either to be installed.â€Â  However, Carrell did note that he believed the ARBâ€™s letter of August 3, 2000 had approved the revised landscape plan Ingram claimed to have submitted on July 20, 2000, which showed the basketball goal.Â Â  
This case revolves on the credibility of the Associationâ€™s witnesses, who claimed the ARB never saw or approved landscaping plans showing the flagpole, and the Paonesâ€™ witness Ingram, who claimed to have submitted the plans.Â  We give deference to the masterâ€™s factual findings because he had a better vantage point from which to judge the witnessesâ€™ credibility. Â See Patterson v. Goldsmith, 292 S.C. 619, 626, 358 S.E.2d 163, 167 (Ct. App. 1987) (â€œ[T]he conclusions of the master who observed the demeanor and appearance of the witnesses have peculiar value on questions of credibility of witnesses.â€).Â  Giving such deference to the master, we find the ARB never considered or approved landscaping plans that showed a flagpole.Â  Thus, the Paones violated the covenants by installing the flagpole without the ARBâ€™s approval.Â  
Furthermore, the Paones acknowledged at oral argument they waived any argument concerning placement of the portable basketball goal on their property, which constituted a violation of the covenants.Â  Accordingly, we find no error in the masterâ€™s conclusion that the Association had established two violations of the covenants beginning at or about August 15, 2000.
II.Â  Fines as a penalty
The Paones argue the amount of the fines awarded by the master was grossly disproportionate to any damage and is an unenforceable penalty.Â  We find this issue is not properly before this court.Â  
In their complaint, the Association asserted it was entitled to a cumulative fine totaling $25.00 a day.Â  Thus, the Paones were aware that the Association was seeking a significant award of damages from the cumulative fines at the time of the hearing; yet the Paones failed to argue such that the fines were an unenforceable penalty until their motion to alter or amend.Â  A party cannot raise an issue for the first time in a Rule 59(e) motion when the issue could have been raised at trial.Â  MailSource, LLC v. M.A. Bailey & Assoc., Inc., 356 S.C. 370, 588 S.E.2d 639 (Ct. App. 2003).Â  Thus, this issue is not preserved for our review.Â  See Dixon v. Dixon, 362 S.C. 388, 608 S.E.2d 849 (2005)(issue raised for first time in Rule 59, SCRCP, motion is not preserved for review).
III.Â  Reasonableness of attorneyâ€™s fees
The Paones argue the master erred by not addressing the Jackson v. Speed[1] factors when determining reasonable attorneyâ€™s fees.Â  They assert that the case must be remanded for a consideration of the attorneyâ€™s fee request.Â  We disagree. 
There are six factors for the trial court to consider when determining an award of attorneyâ€™s fees:Â  (1) the nature, extent, and difficulty of the case; (2) the time necessarily devoted to the case; (3) professional standing of counsel; (4) contingency of compensation; (5) beneficial results obtained; and (6) customary legal fees for similar services.Â  Jackson v. Speed, 326 S.C. at 308, 486 S.E.2d at 760.Â  
In his order the master held that the Associationâ€™s attorneyâ€™s itemized statement of fees and costs and an affidavit from another real estate attorney averring the fees and costs were reasonable and satisfied him â€œthat all of the standards in the cannons of ethics with regard to attorneyâ€™s fees and their reasonableness have been met in the examination and scrutiny of [the Associationâ€™s attorneyâ€™s] bill for services.â€ The master awarded the Association $12,164.50 in attorneyâ€™s fees and $2,890.00 in costs.Â Â  
Although the master did not list the factors he considered, the master did state he considered factors set out in the â€œcannons of ethics.â€

The factors for determining the reasonableness of fees set forth in Rule 1.5 of the Rules of Professional Conduct, Rule 407, SCACR, include the same factors as those set forth in Jackson v. Speed. [2]   

Thus, in considering the factors set forth in the Rule 1.5 of the Rules of Professional Conduct, the master considered the Jackson v. Speed factors as well as other factors.Â  We find no abuse of discretion in the masterâ€™s award of fees.Â  
IV.Â  Remedies
The Paones argue the covenants restrict the remedies to either imposition of fines or injunctive relief.Â  We disagree.Â  
As restrictive covenants are contractual in nature, the paramount rule of construction is to ascertain and give effect to the intent of the parties as determined from the whole document.Â  Taylor v. Lindsey, 332 S.C. 1, 4, 498 S.E.2d 862, 863 (1998).Â  The court in Taylor elucidated:

The court may not limit a restriction in a deed, nor, on the other hand, will a restriction be enlarged or extended by construction or implication beyond the clear meaning of its terms even to accomplish what it may be thought the parties would have desired had a situation which later developed been foreseen by them at the time when the restriction was written.Â  It is still the settled rule in this jurisdiction that restrictions as to the use of real estate should be strictly construed and all doubts resolved in favor of free use of the property, subject, however, to the provision that this rule of strict construction should not be applied so as to defeat the plain and obvious purpose of the instrument.Â  

Id.Â  (internal quotations and citations omitted).
Article 11.04 of the Covenants, titled Enforcement, provides in part:Â  â€œFailure to comply [with the covenants] shall be grounds for imposing fines, for suspending voting rights, or for instituting and action to recover sums due, for damages, and/or for injunctive relief . . . .â€Â  This section further provides:Â  â€œShould Declarant or the Association employ legal counsel to enforce any of the foregoing, all costs incurred in connection with such enforcement, including court costs and reasonable attorneysâ€™ fees, shall be paid by the violating owner. . . .[I]t is hereby declared that any breach [of the covenants, bylaws or rule or regulations of the Association] may not adequately be compensated by recovery of damages, and thatÂ  . . . the Association . . ., in addition to all other remedies, and not by way of limitation, may require and shall be entitled to the equitable remedies of specific performance and of injunction to restrain any such violation or breach or any threatened violation or breach.â€Â  
Sections10.03 and 10.04 also authorize the ARB to enjoin further construction and to require removal or correction of any work already in place that does not comply with approved plans and specifications.Â  
Considering the plain language of the Declaration, we find the Association clearly had the right to impose fines and then to bring an action to recover the sums due from the aggregated fines.Â  In addition, Article 11.04 authorizes the Association to receive attorneyâ€™s fees and costs from its enforcement action.Â  Furthermore, this section provides â€œin addition to all other remediesâ€ the Association is entitled to an injunction to restrain violations of the covenants.Â  Accordingly, we find the master did not err in awarding the Association damages from the fines due and injunctive relief.Â  
CONCLUSION
For the above reasons, the order of the master is 
AFFIRMED.
ANDERSON, HUFF, and WILLIAMS, JJ., concur.

[1] 326 S.C. 289, 486 S.E.2d 750 (1997).Â Â Â  
[2] We note that Rule 1.5 of the Rules of Professional Conduct applies to the reasonableness of fees between an attorney and client and not to the award of fees to an opposing party.Â

title: Johnson v. Smith
text:
THIS OPINION HAS NO PRECEDENTIAL VALUE.Â  IT SHOULD NOT BE CITED OR RELIED ON AS PRECEDENT IN ANY PROCEEDING EXCEPT AS PROVIDED BY RULE 239(d)(2), SCACR.
THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Court of Appeals

  
    
      
John E. Johnson, III, Appellant,
v.
Estate of Ralston E. Smith, Respondent.
      
    
  


Appeal from Clarendon County
Â Clifton Newman, Circuit Court Judge

Unpublished Opinion No. 2006-UP-002
Submitted December 1, 2005 â€“ Filed January 4, 2006Â Â Â 

AFFIRMED


  
    
      
Scott Lamar Robinson, of Manning, for Appellant.
Melody Joy Edelman Breeden, of Myrtle Beach, for Respondent.
      
    
  

PER CURIAM:Â  John E. Johnson, III, submitted a claim against the Estate of Ralston E. Smith for breach of contract, fraudulent misrepresentation, breach of good faith, conversion, quantum meruit, and sought a constructive trust based on the payment to Smith of tobacco settlement proceeds that belonged to Johnson.Â  The trial court granted summary judgment to Smith, finding Johnsonâ€™s claims barred by the doctrine of accord and satisfaction.Â  We affirm.[1]
FACTS
Ralston E. Smith loaned John E. Johnson, III money in 1999, and Smith took title to Johnsonâ€™s farm as security for the loan.Â  According to Johnson, Smith reconveyed title to the farm to him in 2000 after Johnson paid the debt.Â  Nevertheless, Smith received tobacco settlement proceeds in 2001 based on his title to the farm in 1999.Â  On March 11, 2002, Johnson executed a settlement agreement providing:

In consideration for the payment of Ten thousand and No/100 Dollars ($10,000.00), the receipt of which is hereby acknowledged, I John E. Johnson, III, do hereby agree to release and forever discharge Ralston E. Smith from any and all claims, liabilities, demands, or damages arising from all business transactions between the parties.

In addition, Johnson signed a copy of the check he received, which contained a similar release.
On March 7, 2003, Smith died.Â  Smithâ€™s wife, Stacey G. Smith, and brother serve as co-representatives of his estate (the Estate).Â  Johnson filed a claim in probate court against the Estate, alleging breach of contract, fraudulent misrepresentation, breach of good faith, conversion, quantum meruit, and entitlement to a constructive trust resulting from Smithâ€™s actions with respect to the tobacco allotment.Â  The Estate answered and generally denied Johnsonâ€™s claim.Â  In addition, the Estate asserted various affirmative defenses, including the doctrine of accord and satisfaction, and a counterclaim under the Frivolous Proceedings Act.Â  In support of its accord and satisfaction defense, the Estate attached the executed settlement agreement and check to its answer.Â  On February 10, 2004, the special probate judge removed the case to circuit court.Â  Subsequently, Johnson replied to the Estateâ€™s answer, and generally denied its affirmative defenses and its counterclaim.Â  
Pursuant to Rule 12(b)(6) and 12(c), SCRCP, the Estate moved to dismiss Johnsonâ€™s causes of action for failure to state a claim and judgment on the pleadings.Â  On August 26, 2004, the Estate served Johnson with notice of its intent to convert the motion to dismiss into a motion for summary judgment.Â  The Estate also filed Stacey Smithâ€™s affidavit at this time.Â  The trial court held a hearing on September 8, 2004, at which time Johnson objected to the lack of adequate notice to the summary judgment motion.Â  Without specifically addressing the notice issue, the trial court held the hearing would be treated as a hearing for summary judgment, but allowed Johnson and the Estate to file supplemental affidavits and other documents within ten days of the hearing.Â  Additionally, the trial court requested the Estate submit a proposed order within thirty days and gave Johnson ten days to respond after service of this proposed order.Â  Johnson did not object to this procedure.Â  Also at this hearing, Johnson claimed for the first time that the settlement agreement resulted from duress and coercion.
Johnson replied to the summary judgment motion on September 17, 2004, and submitted his affidavit that indicated Smith had coerced the settlement agreement or forced Johnson to sign it under duress.Â  Johnson also submitted the affidavit of his brother, Clarke Johnson, in which Clarke indicated he was present at the signing of the settlement agreement, and Smith forced Johnson to sign under duress.Â  The Estate entered a memorandum in support of its motion, and the trial court entered summary judgment in favor of the Estate based on the doctrine of accord and satisfaction.Â  This appeal followed.
LAW/ANALYSIS
I. Notice of Summary Judgment
Johnson contends the trial court erred in granting summary judgment because he did not have sufficient notice of the summary judgment hearing.Â  We disagree.
â€œObjections not raised in the trial court cannot be relied on in the appellate court.Â  The duty is on the litigant to make a timely objection in order to preserve the right of review.Â  A contemporaneous objection is required to properly preserve an error for appellate review.â€Â  Doe v. S.B.M., 327 S.C. 352, 356, 488 S.E.2d 878, 880 (Ct. App. 1997) (citations omitted).Â  Johnson objected at the hearing to the propriety of the notice he received with respect to the Estateâ€™s motion for summary judgment.Â  The trial court responded to Johnsonâ€™s objection by treating the hearing as one for summary judgment, but allowed Johnson ten days to supplement his opposition to the motion with affidavits and other documents.Â  Johnson did not object to this procedure, did not demand a second hearing, and actively participated by submitting affidavits and a reply to the motion.Â  Only after the trial court granted summary judgment did Johnson object to this procedure.Â  Under these circumstances, Johnson waived his right to assert lack of proper notice on appeal.
II. Genuine Issue of Material Fact
Johnson argues the trial court erred in finding no genuine issue of material fact existed.Â  We disagree.
Johnson specifically argues the trial court erred in finding no genuine issue of material fact exists as to whether the settlement agreement was entered into under duress or coercion.Â  First, Johnson failed to appeal the trial courtâ€™s decision that Rule 8(c), SCRCP, required Johnson to specifically plead duress or coercion as an affirmative defense.Â  Johnsonâ€™s only response to this ruling on appeal was that â€œ[t]his ruling by the trial judge fails to address the possibility that, after discovery on this issue . . . [Johnson] could move to amend his pleadings to set forth the affirmative defense of duress.â€Â  Johnson did not present the issue of the possibility of amending his pleadings to the trial court and did not otherwise appeal the trial courtâ€™s ruling.Â  Therefore, the trial courtâ€™s ruling is the law of the case.Â  See Lindsay v. Lindsay, 328 S.C. 329, 338, 491 S.E.2d 583, 588 (Ct. App. 1997) (â€œIt is a fundamental rule of law that an appellate court will affirm a ruling by a lower court if the offended party does not challenge that ruling. . . . The unchallenged ruling, â€˜right or wrong, is the law of the case.â€™â€ (citations omitted)).
Moreover, even if Johnson properly appealed the trial courtâ€™s ruling, we hold Johnson was required to specifically plead duress in his reply.Â  â€œIn pleading to a preceding pleading, a party shall set forth affirmatively the defenses: . . . duress . . . and any other matter constituting an avoidance or affirmative defense. . . . A party may file a reply to any of the foregoing affirmative defenses.â€Â  Rule 8(c), SCRCP.Â  An affirmative defense must be pled to be preserved.Â  Adams v. B & D, Inc., 297 S.C. 416, 419, 377 S.E.2d 315, 317 (1989). Â â€œAlthough Rule 8(c) requires a party to set forth affirmative defenses to a â€˜preceding pleading,â€™ this requirement applies only if the party actually pleads responsively to the prior pleading.â€Â  Republic Contr. Corp. v. South Carolina Depâ€™t of Highways and Pub. Transp., 332 S.C. 197, 210, 503 S.E.2d 761, 768 (Ct. App. 1998). Â Johnson filed a reply and failed to plead duress as a way of avoidance of the Estateâ€™s affirmative defense of accord and satisfaction.Â  Therefore, Rule 8(c), SCRCP, applies, and Johnson waived his right to assert duress.
III. Opportunity to Conduct Further DiscoveryÂ Â Â Â Â Â Â Â  
Johnson contends the trial court erred by entering summary judgment prematurely.Â  We disagree.
â€œSince it is a drastic remedy, summary judgment â€˜should be cautiously invoked so that no person will be improperly deprived of a trial of the disputed factual issues.â€™â€Â  Baughman v. Am. Tel. & Tel. Co., 306 S.C. 101, 112, 410 S.E.2d 537, 543 (1991) (quoting Watson v. Southern Ry. Co., 420 F.Supp. 483, 486 (D.S.C. 1975)).Â  â€œThis means, among other things, that summary judgment must not be granted until the opposing party has had a full and fair opportunity to complete discovery.â€Â  Baughman, 306 S.C. at 112, 410 S.E.2d at 543.Â  In Baughman, the Supreme Court of South Carolina expressly cited two factors to be considered in determining whether the party opposing summary judgment has had a â€œfull and fair opportunity to complete discovery.â€Â  First, the party must demonstrate â€œa likelihood that further discovery will uncover additional evidence relevant to the issue . . . and that they are not merely engaged in a â€˜fishing expedition.â€™â€Â  Id. at 112, 410 S.E.2d at 544.Â  Second, they must demonstrate they were not dilatory in seeking discovery on the particular issue.Â  Id. at 113, 410 S.E.2d at 544.Â  
Johnson has failed to meet either of these requirements.Â  Johnson broadly avers the grant of summary judgment would be fatal to his case and would deny him the right to conduct further discovery.Â  He does not explain the likelihood of success if further discovery were to be allowed, or the specific types of discovery that would help his case.Â  Johnson asserts the parties are only sixty days into the discovery process, and no discovery requests have been answered.Â  However, Johnson admits â€œneither party had taken any depositions or noticed the other party thereof.â€Â  Johnson does not explain whether he has asked for other types of discovery or why he failed to notice depositions at this point.Â  Under these circumstances, we hold Johnson has not demonstrated summary judgment is premature.
CONCLUSION
We hold Johnson waived his right to argue he had insufficient notice of the Estateâ€™s summary judgment motion.Â  Moreover, Johnson failed to appeal the trial courtâ€™s decision that Rule 8(c), SCRCP, precluded Johnson from arguing duress or coercion.Â  Also, we hold the trial court properly held Rule 8(c), SCRCP, requires duress or coercion to be specifically pled when a party submits a reply.Â  Finally, we conclude the trial court did not prematurely grant summary judgment.Â  For the foregoing reasons, the decision of the trial court is
AFFIRMED.
KITTREDGE, WILLIAMS, JJ., and CURETON, A.J., concur.

[1] We decide this case without oral argument pursuant to Rule 215, SCACR.

v.

Unpublished Opinion No. 2006-UP-003
Submitted January 3, 2006 â€“ Filed January 4, 2006

Attorney General Henry Dargan McMaster, Chief Deputy Attorney General John W. McIntosh, Assistant Deputy Attorney General Salley W. Elliott, all of Columbia; and Solicitor Donald V. Myers, of Lexington, for Respondent.
      
    
  

PER CURIAM:Â  Carl Cook appeals his guilty plea to two counts of criminal sexual conduct.Â  He maintains his guilty plea failed to conform with the mandates set forth in Boykin v. Alabama because the trial judge failed to adequately inform him of the constitutional rights he waived by entering a guilty plea.Â  395 U.S. 238 (1969).Â  After a thorough review of the record and counselâ€™s brief pursuant to Anders v. California, 386 U.S. 738 (1967), and State v. Williams, 305 S.C. 116, 406 S.E.2d 357 (1991), we dismiss Cookâ€™s appeal and grant counselâ€™s motion to be relieved. 
APPEAL DISMISSED.[1]
GOOLSBY, ANDERSON, and SHORT, JJ., concur.

title: Thomas v. Steinbronn
text:
THIS OPINION HAS NO PRECEDENTIAL VALUE


THIS OPINION HAS NO PRECEDENTIAL VALUE.Â  IT SHOULD NOT BE CITED OR RELIED ON AS 
 PRECEDENT IN ANY PROCEEDING EXCEPT AS PROVIDED BY RULE 239(d)(2), SCACR.
THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Court of Appeals


  
    
      
Raymond Thomas, d/b/a All-In-One Construction, Appellant,
v.
Kenneth C. Steinbronn and Shannon F. Steinbronn,
Respondents.
      
    
  


Appeal From Dorchester County
Â PatrickÂ  R. Watts, Master In Equity

Unpublished Opinion No. 2006-UP-007
Submitted December 1, 2005 â€“ Filed January 5, 2006

AFFIRMED


  
    
      
Laura Catherine Tesh, of Columbia, for Appellant
James A. Bell, of St. George, and James B. Richardson, Jr., of Columbia, for Respondent.
      
    
  

PER CURIAM:Â  Raymond Thomas appeals from a judgment granting Kenneth and Shannon Steinbronn damages for breach of contract.[1]Â  Thomas contends the trial court erred in (1) holding the trial in his absence without proper notice while a motion to be relieved as counsel was still pending, (2) awarding damages beyond the prayer sought in the complaint, and (3) in removing a mechanicâ€™s lien.Â  We affirm.[2]Â  
FACTS
On July 28, 2003, Raymond Thomas (d/b/a All-in-One Construction) filed a notice and certificate of mechanicâ€™s lien in the amount of $39,026.39 for property located at 169 Fisk Road in Dorchester County.Â  Thomas, on October 9, 2003, initiated an action to foreclose on this mechanicâ€™s lien and an action for breach of contract.Â  The complaint alleged that Kenneth and Shannon Steinbronn breached their contract with Thomas to build their home.Â  The Steinbronns counterclaimed for breach of contract seeking unspecified damages, alleging that Thomasâ€™s work was neither up to code nor in compliance with contract specifications.Â  
Due to the fact that Thomas failed and refused to bring his account current despite repeated billings, his attorney, W. Scott Palmer, moved to be relieved as counsel on June 9, 2004.Â  On August 26, 2004, the court granted this motion.Â Â Â  
On September 10, 2004, the Steinbronnsâ€™ attorney sent Thomas notice, by regular and certified mail to his home address, that the trial was scheduled for September 27, 2004.Â  Neither the receipt for the certified mail nor the letter sent via regular mail was returned to the Steinbronnsâ€™ attorney.Â  
The case was tried on September 27, 2004, and neither Thomas nor any representative for him attended.Â  Mrs. Steinbronn testified as to the agreement entered into with Thomas to build her home.Â  The total contract cost was $176,800 to be financed by Farmers and Merchants Bank (Bank).Â  The Bank allowed the Steinbronns to make draws under the loan, and then pay Thomas and the sub-contractors directly.Â  Mrs. Steinbronn further testified that payment under the first draw immediately produced a problem when Thomas admitted he erred and overcharged her for building materials.Â  According to Mrs. Steinbronn, there were a myriad of problems with Thomasâ€™s workmanship, including:Â  the staircase had to be rebuilt 3 times, there were no hurricane clips or straps, the roof was not completely braced, the vents on the porch were improper, termite pre-treatment was not completed, there was insufficient block and brick support for the porches, 2 x 8 ceiling boards had more than the maximum one-third of their width cut out, ceiling joists were crooked and not nailed properly, and all the plumbing had to be replaced.Â Â Â  
The Steinbronns fired Thomas and hired a different contractor who they paid to repair and complete the house.Â  Thomasâ€™s mechanicâ€™s lien delayed the Steinbronnsâ€™ ability to attain permanent financing on their home.Â  The Steinbronns paid more than $11,000 in additional interest on the construction loan, as they missed out on lower permanent financing interest rates which had recently increased.Â  The contractor who finished the house and the Steinbronnsâ€™ loan officer supported Mrs. Steinbronnâ€™s testimony.Â  
Mrs. Steinbronn testified that she and her husband paid $85,075.63 above the originally contracted amount to complete their house. The trial court entered judgment for the Steinbronns in this amount and ordered cancellation of Thomasâ€™s mechanicâ€™s lien.Â  Pursuant to Rule 60(b), SCRCP, Thomas filed an unsuccessful motion to alter or amend the trial courtâ€™s decision.Â  This appeal followed.
STANDARD OF REVIEW
A decision to grant or deny a motion under Rule 60(b), SCRCP, is within the sound discretion of the trial court.Â  Bowman v. Bowman, 357 S.C. 146, 151, 591 S.E.2d 654, 656 (Ct. App. 2004) (citing Coleman v. Dunlap, 306 S.C. 491, 413 S.E.2d 15 (1992)).Â  On review, we are limited to determining whether the trial court abused its discretion in granting or denying the motion.Â  Bowman, 357 S.C. at 151, 591 S.E.2d at 656.Â  
LAW/ANALYSIS
I.Â  Notice of Trial
Thomas contends the trial court erred in holding the trial in his absence because he had not received notice.Â  We disagree.
Thomas claims that he did not receive notice of the September 27, 2004 hearing because he was in Florida from August 22, 2004, until October 29, 2004, repairing hurricane damage.Â  Evidently, neither he nor anyone else was monitoring his mail.Â  He also claims that when he returned, he did not find the notice in his accumulated mail.Â  On November 15, 2004, in an order responding to Thomasâ€™s motion to alter or amend, the trial court found:

Plaintiff [Appellant] brought this suit.Â  He has a duty to timely prosecute it.Â  More particularly, he has a duty to tell the Clerk and other parties when he will be unavailable for trial.Â  Nothing in the record indicates he sought protection for the time he was out of state.

We agree.Â  A party has a duty to monitor the progress of his case, and lack of familiarity with legal proceedings is unacceptable, as the court will not hold a layman to any lesser standard than is applied to an attorney.Â  Goodson v. American Bankers Insurance Company of Florida, 295 S.C. 400, 403, 368 S.E.2d 687, 689 (Ct. App. 1988). 
Thomas further argues that he did not receive notice because the Steinbronnsâ€™ attorney errantly sent notice of the trial to him and not to his attorney of record.Â  This argument was not part of Thomasâ€™s Rule 60 motion and is thus not preserved for appeal.Â  See 
First Union Nat. Bank of South Carolina v. Soden, 333 S.C. 554, 568, 511 S.E.2d 372, 379 (Ct. App. 1998) (where an issue has not been ruled upon by the trial judge nor raised in a post-trial motion,
such issue may not be considered on appeal).Â  The argument is, in any event, without merit.Â  Thomas asserts that at the time the trial occurred on September 27, 2004, the motion from his attorney to be relieved as counsel was still pending.Â  This is not the case.Â  The record clearly reflects that the trial court granted Palmerâ€™s motion to be relieved as counsel on August 26, 2004.Â  At the time the notice of trial was sent, Thomas was acting pro se.Â  As the case is presented to us, mailing notice to Thomas at his correct address cannot be considered improper.Â  It is readily apparent that the arguments advanced by Thomas in his final brief are based on the misunderstanding that the motion to relieve his counsel was still pending as of the date of the trial.Â  Thomas, through counsel, acknowledges this error in the reply brief.
II.Â  Damages
Thomas contends that the trial court erred in awarding damages beyond the prayer sought in the complaint.Â  We disagree.[3]Â  The award does not exceed the prayer for damages.Â  The Steinbronns asked for damages in an amount â€œover $58,000â€ and for â€œactual â€¦ damages in an amount to be determined by the court.â€Â  The suggestion that the damage award exceeds the amount prayed for in the complaint is simply not true.
III.Â  Mechanicâ€™s Lien
Thomas contends that the trial court erred in removing the mechanicâ€™s lien when it was not requested in the pleadings and no amendment was requested at trial.Â  We disagree.Â  This issue may not be preserved for appeal, but if preserved, we find no error by the trial court.[4]Â  
Thomas essentially abandoned his complaint (which included a claim to enforce his mechanicâ€™s lien) and failed to appear at the trial.Â  He cannot now be heard to complain that the court ruled against him on his complaint or cry foul because the trial court did not hold his claim in abeyance.Â  We believe that the trial courtâ€™s decision to dissolve the mechanics lien was ministerial and a consequence of resolving all issues before the court.Â  We find no error.Â Â Â  
CONCLUSION
This court finds that the trial court did not abuse its discretion in holding the trial in Thomasâ€™s absence after finding that he had received proper notice, after his former counsel had been relieved pursuant to court order. Â We further find that the trial court did not err in its damages award or in dissolving Thomasâ€™s mechanicâ€™s lien.Â  Based on the foregoing, the trial courtâ€™s order is
 AFFIRMED.
STILWELL, KITTREDGE, and WILLIAMS, JJ., concur.

[1] Thomasâ€™s appellate counsel did not represent Thomas in the trial court.
[2] We decide this case without oral argument pursuant to Rule 215, SCACR.
[3] One feature of Thomasâ€™s argument here is that the judgment rendered in favor of the Steinbronns is in essence a default judgment, and, therefore, damages cannot exceed the prayer for relief.Â  This specific argument was not raised in Thomasâ€™s Rule 60 motion.Â  In fact, the â€œdefault judgmentâ€ argument surfaced for the first time in Thomasâ€™s reply brief.Â  A party may not properly raise an issue for the first time in his reply brief.Â  We are, then, presented with another argument that is not preserved for review.Â  In any event, the Steinbronns never sought to invoke Rule 55, SCRCP, and hold Thomas in default for his failure to file a reply to their counterclaim.Â Â  The Steinbronns never changed the initial posture of the caseâ€”as commenced by Thomasâ€”and they pursued a trial. We adhere to the view that a partyâ€™s failure to appear for trial does not transform the proceeding into a default hearing.Â  Besides, in the context of a default status, Rule 55 requires â€œat least 3 days priorâ€ notice and Rule 55(b)(2) of the SCRCP states, â€œPursuant to Rule 5(a), notice of any trial or hearing on unliquidated damages shall also be given to parties in default by first class mail to the last known address of such party.â€Â  Notice of the hearingâ€”whether treated as a trial or a default hearingâ€”was properly given to Thomas at his correct address approximately two weeks in advance.Â  Thus, this newly asserted ground that Thomas was in default for failure to reply to the counterclaim provides no basis for relief in this court.Â Â Â  
[4] Thomas does not specifically refer to the mechanicâ€™s lien in his post trial motion to alter or amend, but the motion does note that â€œno credit was given for the amount due to the plaintiff.â€Â  This appears to be in reference to the money owed under the mechanicâ€™s lien.Â

text:
THIS OPINION HAS NO PRECEDENTIAL VALUE.Â  IT SHOULD NOT BE CITED OR RELIED ON AS
PRECEDENT IN ANY PROCEEDING EXCEPT AS PROVIDED BY RULE 239(D)(2), SCACR.
THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Court of Appeals

  
    
      
The State, Appellant,
v.
Henry Poplin, Respondent.
      
    
  


Appeal From Richland County
Â G. Thomas Cooper, Jr., Circuit Court Judge

Unpublished Opinion No.Â  2006-UP-013
Heard December 7, 2006 â€“ Filed January 5, 2006
Withdrawn, Substituted and Refiled March 16, 2006

AFFIRMED


  
    
      
Attorney General Henry Dargan McMaster, Chief Deputy Attorney General John W. McIntosh, Assistant Deputy Attorney General Sally W. Elliott, Assistant Attorney General David Spencer, all of Columbia; and Solicitor Warren Blair Giese, of Columbia, for Appellant.
Assistant Appellate Defender Robert M. Dudek, Â of Columbia, for Respondent.
      
    
  

 PER CURIAM: The State appeals the circuit courtâ€™s acceptance of Henry Poplinâ€™s plea of autrefois convict[1] regarding a charge of Assault and Battery With Intent to Kill (ABWIK).Â  Specifically, the State argues that a preceding PCR order vacated all convictions that were part of a prior plea agreement, allowing the state to retry Poplin on all prior charges.Â  We affirm.
FACTS
In December 1999, Poplin and an acquaintance entered â€œRough Draft,â€ a bar in Columbiaâ€™s Five Points area.Â  Poplinâ€™s companion was apparently banned from the establishment, and the pair was asked to vacate the premises.Â  According to Poplin, although escorted out in a rough manner, they left peacefully.Â  Once outside, however, Poplin realized that he left a drink inside and reentered the bar.Â  The establishmentâ€™s manager noticed Poplinâ€™s reentry and an altercation ensued.Â  Poplin, who was allegedly brandishing a small knife, stabbed the manager several times and attempted to flee.Â  He was apprehended by local citizens and held until his arrest by law enforcement.
In March 2000, Poplin was indicted for Assault and Battery With Intent to Kill (ABWIK) and Possession of a Firearm or Knife During Commission of or Attempt to Commit a Violent Crime.Â  Because of a prior ABWIK charge, he faced a mandatory sentence of life without the possibility of parole pursuant to S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 17-25-45 (2003).Â  Poplin communicated to his trial counsel that he desired to enter a plea to the charges if he could avoid a life sentence.Â  Counsel then vigorously pursued a plea agreement with the State that would avoid a conviction for a second â€œmost serious offenseâ€ and a mandatory life sentence.Â  After much negotiation, the State offered a plea agreement.Â  The offer allowed Poplin to avoid a second ABWIK conviction if he agreed to plead guilty to the following charges:

1. One count of Assault and Battery of a High and Aggravated Nature (ABHAN) as a lesser included offense of the ABWIK charge.
2. An additional count of ABHAN.
3. One count of Second Degree Burglary. 
4. One count of Possession of Tools to be Employed in a Crime.
5.Â  One count of Possession of a Firearm or Knife During the Commission of a Violent Crime.

A guilty plea to all the above charges exposed Poplin to a possible 45 years of incarceration.Â  Defense counsel attempted to negotiate a lighter sentence for her client, but was told by the State that â€œthis is a way to get him the amount of time we think he deservesâ€ and â€œ[its] either trial or 45.â€
Poplinâ€™s trial counsel informed him that some of the charges were â€œquestionable,â€ but that his only options were to either take the deal or go to trial and face a possible life sentence.Â  He pled guilty to all the charges and received consecutive sentences totaling 45 years imprisonment.
Poplin did not appeal the guilty plea.Â  Shortly after sentencing, however, he filed an application for PCR, alleging, inter alia, that his plea counsel was ineffective for failing to inform him of his right to appeal and failing to explain the possibility that several of the indictments placed him in double jeopardy for a single criminal act.Â  The PCR application, it is important to note, challenged only four of the five convictions and did not mention the initial indictment for ABWIK, which, as part of the deal, was pled down to a guilty plea for the lesser included offense of ABHAN.Â  In November 2001, Poplin received a hearing before the circuit court on his PCR claims.
At the hearing, the range of possible relief available to Poplin was discussed often and to a substantial degree of detail.Â  Early in the proceedings, the State addressed the issue and the following exchange took place:

The State:Â  I want to just make sure I understand for the record what relief the applicant is seeking today.
The Court:Â  I guess he wants a new trial but specifically . . .
The State:Â  The, your honor, I understand that . . . the appropriate relief would be a new trial on all the charges . . .
PCR Counsel:Â  Your honor, the applicant would like to ask that the court consider vacating one of the assault and battery charges, one of the weapon charges, and the burglary charge for lack of a factual basis, leaving intact what the applicant concedes heâ€™s guilty of, which is one count of [ABHAN] and a single weapons charge.Â  However, I have explained to him on a previous visit to his correctional institution that it may well be the position of the State that the pleas were entered part and parcel of a negotiated plea bargain and that any effort to undermine the integrity of the pleas on these counts would likely result in vacation of all the judgments and sentences, at which point I believe he would face prosecution on the original indictment for [ABWIK] and Iâ€™m prepared to question him concerning that decision on the stand.

Following this exchange, Poplin testified that he was fully aware the circuit could vacate all the sentences involved in the plea bargain and that the â€œprobable resultâ€ of his PCR action would be a new indictment on the original charge of ABWIK, a charge he knew could result in a life sentence.Â  On cross-examination, Poplin conceded that his guilty plea was, in fact, â€œa package deal . . . in lieu of going to trial.â€
Following the presentation of Poplinâ€™s case, the State moved for a directed verdict on the following grounds:

â€œThe basis is that the relief sought today is to throw out some charges and not others.Â  I mean, I think even Mr. Poplinâ€™s own testimony makes clear he understood this was a package deal.Â  The only relief available is a trial on all the charges.â€

In a one-word response, the circuit court denied the Stateâ€™s directed verdict motion.Â  Following this denial, Poplinâ€™s PCR counsel clarified his position:

â€œI would like to make clear that my client has stated that while the first option [vacation of just the four disputed convictions] would be his preference, he is willing to accept the option, the relief, if you will, of a new trial on everything.â€

The circuit court allowed each party to submit their closing arguments in the form of proposed orders.Â  After consideration of the proposed orders, the circuit court found Poplinâ€™s double jeopardy claims persuasive.Â  In its order, the circuit court stated 1) â€œit is clear that the Applicant could not be prosecuted and punished twice for the same assaultâ€ and 2) â€œ[t]his court further finds that punishment for possession of a weapon during a violent crime and for possession of tools to be used in a crime likewise violates the Applicantâ€™s rights against double jeopardy where the â€˜toolâ€™ alleged by the one indictment was the same â€˜weaponâ€™ alleged in the other.â€Â  Because Poplin was not mindful of his double jeopardy claims when he waived the defense, the court found that his plea counsel failed to adequately advise him of the nature and consequences of the pleas.Â  The order concludes with the following rather vague ruling:

â€œFor all the reasons set forth above, this Application for Post-Conviction Relief is hereby granted.Â  The Applicantâ€™s case is to be remanded to the Richland County Court of General Sessions for a new trial.â€

The order does not specifically address whether it vacates the entirety of Poplinâ€™s negotiated plea or just those convictions brought into question by his double jeopardy claims.Â  
The State petitioned the South Carolina Supreme Court for writ of certiorari regarding the PCR ruling on the basis that Defendant was generally aware of the consequences of either accepting the plea agreement or going to trial.Â  The petition was denied.Â  Shortly after the denial of the Stateâ€™s petition, Defendant was recharged on the original indictment for ABWIK and its mandatory life sentence.Â  In January 2004, the case was brought to trial.
Poplinâ€™s new counsel promptly entered a plea of autrefois convict, on the basis that one of Poplinâ€™s prior guilty pleas, the ABHAN charge brought as a lesser included offense of the original ABWIK, was not vacated by the PCR order.Â  The renewed ABWIK charge, therefore, was a clear violation of the double jeopardy clause.Â  According to defense counsel, Poplin was still serving a ten-year sentence for the ABHAN guilty plea; thus, he could not be tried for ABWIK based on the same criminal act.Â  Because Poplin had been in Richland County Detention Center, and not a typical correctional facility, some confusion arose as to whether or not he was, in fact, still serving a prison sentence.Â  The State argued that the PCR order vacated all sentences involved in the prior negotiated plea agreement and Poplin was being held like any other defendant awaiting trial.
The circuit court concluded that the State was prohibited from further proceeding against Poplin on the ABWIK charge because the initial sentence for ABHAN was not vacated by the PCR order.Â  This conclusion was based on the fact that Poplinâ€™s application for PCR did not challenge his conviction for ABHAN as a lesser-included offense of the initial ABWIK charge.Â  This appeal followed.
DISCUSSION
The State argues the PCR order vacated the entirety of Poplinâ€™s negotiated guilty plea, allowing the State to retry Poplin on the originally indicted charge of ABWIK.Â  We disagree.
Quoting 46 Am.Jur.2d Judgments Â§ 73 (1969), the South Carolina Supreme Court outlined the rules for construing judgments in Eddins v. Eddins, 304 S.C. 133, 403 S.E.2d 164 (1991), as follows:

As a general rule, judgments are to be construed like other written instruments.Â  The determinative factor is the intention of the court, as gathered, not from an isolated part thereof, but from all parts of the judgment itself.Â  Hence, in construing a judgment, it should be examined and considered in its entirety.Â  Such construction should be given to a judgment as will give force and effect to every word of it, if possible, and make it as a whole consistent and reasonable.Â  In applying this rule, effect must be given to that which is unavoidably and necessarily implied in a judgment, as well as to that which is expressed in the most appropriate language.

Id. at 135-36, 403 S.E.2d at 166.
In the present case, the PCR courtâ€™s order initially recounts the entirety of Poplinâ€™s package guilty plea, but, whether purposefully or by accidental omission, lists only one of the ABHAN convictions when reviewing the sentences before it.Â  Furthermore, the PCR court stated its granted relief as â€œthis Application for Post-Conviction Relief is hereby granted.â€Â Â  Poplinâ€™s application for PCR raises only four of the five convictions.Â  The application, expressly granted by the circuit court, lacks any mention of the initial ABHAN charge.Â  In fact, in the memorandum in support of his PCR claims, Poplin expressly states that he is not challenging his conviction on the ABHAN charged as a lesser-included offense of
ABWIK. 
A review of the record on appeal, though in no way conclusive, also reveals evidence supporting the circuit courtâ€™s interpretation of the PCR order.Â  The Stateâ€™s motion for a directed verdict on the basis that all the charges must be vacated together was promptly denied.[2]Â  Although the entire negotiated plea was openly discussed at the PCR hearing, as well as the very likely scenario that all the pleas would be vacated, Poplin made clear that the primary relief sought from the circuit court was a new trial on only the four guilty pleas raised in his application.Â  At no point during the hearing did Poplin concede his only possible relief would be a new trial on all charges.
â€œIn criminal cases, the appellate court sits to review errors of law only.â€ Â State v. Wilson, 345 S.C. 1, 5-6, 545 S.E.2d 827, 829 (2001).Â  Thus, we are bound by the circuit courtâ€™s factual findings unless they are clearly erroneous.Â  Id.Â  In the case before us, we find no articulable error of law in the circuit courtâ€™s interpretation of the PCR order.Â  Despite the fact that the issue of proper relief was extensively discussed at the PCR hearing, the circuit court was faced with an enigmatic PCR order which failed to address the issue.Â  While it would certainly not offend reason to reach an opposite conclusion to that of the circuit court, neither the PCR order itself, nor the record on appeal, conclusively reveals the PCR court intended to vacate the entire negotiated plea.Â  Although we may have construed the PCR order differently, the circuit courtâ€™s interpretation is supported by evidence both in the order itself and the record on appeal and, thus, is not a â€œclearly erroneousâ€ construction of the order.Â  
The State contends that this construction of the PCR order renders the judgment meaningless because the order expressly remands Poplinâ€™s case for a new trial.Â  We are not persuaded by this argument.Â  Although the fact that Poplin is presently serving a ten-year sentence for ABHAN certainly prevents the State from pursuing an additional conviction on the initial ABWIK indictment, the PCR order, as construed by the circuit court, vacated both guilty pleas to possession of a weapon during a violent crime and possession of tools to be used in a crime as dual prosecutions for a singular criminal act.Â  There is nothing preventing the State from prosecuting Poplin on the possession of tools to be used in a crime charge; thus, the orderâ€™s remand for a new trial is not rendered meaningless.
For the foregoing reasons, the circuit courtâ€™s order is
 AFFIRMED.  
 STILWELL, KITTREDGE, and WILLIAMS, JJ., concur.

[1] â€œA plea in bar of arraignment that the defendant has been convicted of the offense.â€Â  Blacks Law Dictionary 130 (7th ed. 1999).
[2] We note that the proper motion in this situation, as PCR actions are civil in nature, would be a motion for nonsuit pursuant to Rule 41, SCRCP.

THIS OPINION HAS NO PRECEDENTIAL VALUE.Â  IT SHOULD NOT BE CITED OR RELIED ON AS PRECEDENT IN ANY PROCEEDING EXCEPT AS PROVIDED BY RULE 239(d)(2), SCACR.
THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Court of Appeals

  
    
      
        Isaac Clutch Ware, Respondent,
      
    
  

v.

  
    
      
        Tradesman International Inc., and National Fire Insurance Co., Appellants.
      
    
  


Appeal From Greenville County
Â Larry R. Patterson, Circuit Court Judge

Unpublished Opinion No.Â  2006-UP-014
Submitted December 1, 2005 â€“ Filed January 11, 2006

AFFIRMED


  
    
      
        Stanford E. Lacy and Suzanne C. Boulware, both of Columbia, for Appellants.
        KathrynÂ  Williams, of Greenville, for Respondent.
      
    
  

PER CURIAM:Â  Tradesman International, Inc. and National Fire Insurance Company of Hartford (Appellants) appeal the decision of the circuit court affirming the South Carolina Workersâ€™ Compensation Commissionâ€™s (the Commission) award of workerâ€™s compensation benefits to Isaac Ware.Â  We affirm.[1]
FACTS
Ware was employed by a temporary employment service as a â€œMIGâ€ welder at Tradesman.Â  As part of his employment, he had to move pieces of steel in order to set up jigs for welding.Â  While moving steel to a jig on June 25, 2001, Ware felt a â€œpullâ€ in his lower left groin area.Â  He experienced pain when this occurred, and as a result, he dropped the piece of steel he was carrying.Â  He remained at work for the rest of the day, but had to get a coworker to move the pieces of steel to the jig for him.Â  Ware returned to work the next day and tried to work as usual.Â  He was in more pain than he had been in the day before, and again his coworker had to move the pieces of steel to the jig for him.Â  After a couple of hours of work, Ware decided he could not continue and spoke to his supervisor about the situation. 
Ware told his supervisor that he thought he may have a hernia.Â  His supervisor advised him to call Tradesman International.Â  Ware explained the situation to Tradesman and advised them that he was going to see his family physician, Dr. Kevin Smith.Â  Tradesman requested that he also see a doctor at Doctorâ€™s Care.
Ware went to see Dr. Smith first and then, on the same day, went to Doctorâ€™s Care and saw Dr. Peter Manos.Â  During his visit with Dr. Smith on June 26, 2001, Ware explained the events and pain that lead to him seeking treatment.Â  He also told Dr. Smith that he had noticed a slight swelling in his lower left groin approximately ten days prior to feeling the â€œpullâ€ while moving the steel at work.Â  Based on an examination, Dr. Smith diagnosed Ware as having a left inguinal hernia.Â  Ware was given the same diagnosis by Dr. Manos at Doctorâ€™s Care.Â  On February 08, 2002, Dr. Manos specifically stated that Wareâ€™s hernia was caused by â€œlifting a heavy object at work on June 25, 2001.â€ 
On July 19, 2001, Dr. Benjamin Risinger, a general surgeon, performed surgery on Ware to repair his hernia.Â  Hours after the surgery, Ware started bleeding and experiencing severe pain, and he had to be transported by ambulance to the emergency room.Â  Due to postoperative bleeding and a massive scrotal hematoma with a probable testicular artery injury,Â  Ware underwent a second surgery the following day. Â Ware has experienced pain, depression, severe anger, and loss of sexual function as result of his injuries.Â  Â Â Â Ware has not been able to return to work since June 27, 2001.Â  
On September 6, 2001, Ware filed a Form 50, seeking compensation for his injuries, treatment, and lost wages.Â  On October 22, 2002, the Single Commissioner found that on June 26, 2001, Ware sustained an injury from an accident arising out of and in the course of his employment, resulting in a hernia.Â  The Single Commissioner also found that the hernia did not exist before the accident.Â  He ordered the Appellants to pay Ware for all causally related medical treatment and expenses and to pay Ware $313.26 per week for all periods of total disability from June 25, 2001 until further order or agreement.Â  The Appellants appealed the Single Commissionerâ€™s decision to the Commission.Â Â Â Â Â Â  
On June 17, 2003, the Commission unanimously affirmed the Order of the Single Commissioner.Â  Thereafter, the Appellants appealed the Commissionâ€™s decision to the circuit court.Â  On November 5, 2004, the circuit court affirmed the Commissionâ€™s decision.Â  This appeal followed.Â  Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â  
LAW/ANALYSIS
The Administrative Procedures Act establishes the standard of review for decisions by the Workersâ€™ Compensation Commission. Â S.C.Code Ann.Â Â  Â§1-23-380 (2005); Lark v. Bi-Lo, Inc., 276 S.C. 130, 132, 276 S.E.2d 304, 305 (1981). Â â€œThe appellate courtâ€™s review is limited to deciding whether the commissionâ€™s decision is unsupported by substantial evidence or is controlled by some error of law.â€ Â Hendricks v. Pickens County, 335 S.C. 405, 411, 517 S.E.2d 698, 701 (Ct. App. 1999).Â  Substantial evidence is â€œnot a mere scintilla of evidence nor the evidence viewed blindly from one side of the case, but is evidence which, considering the record as a whole, would allow reasonable minds to reach the conclusion that the administrative agency reached or must have reached in order to justify its action.â€  Miller by Miller v. State Roofing Co., 312 S.C. 452, 454, 441 S.E.2d 323, 324-25 (1994) (quoting Lark v. Bi-Lo, Inc., 276 S.C. 130, 135, 276 S.E.2d 304, 306 (1981)). 
â€œA judgment upon which reasonable men might differ will not be set aside.â€ Â Toddâ€™s Ice Cream, Inc. v. South Carolina Employment Sec. Commâ€™n, 281 S.C. 254, 258, 315 S.E.2d 373, 375 (Ct. App. 1984). Â The final determination of witness credibility and the weight to be accorded evidence is reserved to the Commission. Â Ross v. American Red Cross, 298 S.C. 490, 492, 381 S.E.2d 728, 730 (1989). Â The reviewing court may not â€œsubstitute its judgment for that of the [Commission] as to the weight of the evidence on questions of fact.â€ S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 1-23-380(6) (2005). Â â€œWhere there is a conflict in the evidence, either of different witnesses or of the same witnesses, the findings of fact of the Commission as triers of fact are conclusive.â€Â Â  Hoxit v. Michelin Tire Corp., 304 S.C. 461, 465, 405 S.E.2d 407, 409 (1991).Â  
In order for a hernia to be a compensable injury under workersâ€™ compensation in South Carolina, a claimant must prove: 1) that there was an injury resulting in a hernia or a rupture; 2) that the injury or rupture appeared suddenly; 3) that it was accompanied by pain; 4) that the hernia or rupture immediately followed an accident; and 5) that the hernia or rupture did not exist prior to the accident.Â Â  S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 42-9-40 (1976).Â  We find there was substantial evidence presented to satisfy all five elements of the statute. Â Â Â 
Ware testified that while he was moving steel to a jig on June 25, 2001, he felt a â€œpullâ€ in his lower left groin area.Â  Ware experienced pain when this occurred, and as a result, he dropped the piece of steel he was carrying.Â  Additionally, Ware testified that he initially noticed the injury the day of the accident.Â  Dr. Smith testified that Ware told him on the day of the accident that the swelling in his lower left groin was hurting.Â  Dr. Smith also stated that lifting or straining can cause hernias.Â  Most importantly, the Appellantâ€™s own doctor, Dr. Manos, specifically stated that Wareâ€™s hernia was caused by â€œlifting a heavy object at work on June 25, 2001.â€Â  Tradesmanâ€™s general manager for Greenville testified that prior to June 25, 2001, Ware had not experienced problems performing his work activities.Â  However, Ware testified that as soon as he felt the â€œpull,â€ he experienced pain and had difficultly working.Â  Thus, there is substantial evidence that Ware suffered an injury resulting in a hernia, the hernia appeared suddenly, it was accompanied by pain, and it immediately followed an accident that occurred while Ware was pulling steel at work.Â  See Eaddy v. Smurfit-Stone Container Corp., 355 S.C. 154, 161- 62, 584 S.E.2d 390, 394 (Ct. App. 2003).Â Â  
The Appellants contend that Ware failed to satisfy the final element of S.C. Code Ann. Â§42-9-40 (1976), which requires that the hernia or rupture did not exist prior to the accident.Â  It is undisputed that Ware told Dr. Smith he had noticed swelling in his lower left groin up to 10 days prior to June 25, 2001.Â Â  Based on this, Dr. Smith opined that the hernia was present before the accident on June 25, 2001.Â  However, the Appellantâ€™s own doctor, Dr. Manos, specifically stated that Wareâ€™s hernia was caused by â€œlifting a heavy object at work on June 25, 2001.â€Â  Both doctors saw Ware in the hours following the accident, and both doctors reached different conclusions on when his hernia first occurred.Â  â€œWhere there is a conflict in the evidence, either of different witnesses or of the same witnesses, the findings of fact of the Commission as triers of fact are conclusive.â€Â Â  Hoxit, 304 S.C. at 465, 405 S.E.2d at 409.Â  Therefore, the Commissionâ€™s findings on the timing and the cause of the hernia are conclusive.Â  Accordingly, the order of the circuit court is 
AFFIRMED. 
GOOLSBY, ANDERSON, and SHORT, JJ., concur.

[1] We decide this case without oral argument pursuant to Rule 215, SCACR.

title: Watts Construction Company v. Feltes
text:

THIS OPINION HAS NO PRECEDENTIAL VALUE.Â  IT SHOULD NOT BE CITED OR RELIED ON AS PRECEDENT IN ANY PROCEEDING EXCEPT AS PROVIDED BY RULE 239(d)(2), SCACR.
THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Court of Appeals

  
    
      
        Watts Construction Company, Inc. and Donald Watts, Appellants,
      
    
  

v.

  
    
      
        Gerald H. Feltes and Lupe Feltes, Respondents.
      
    
  


Appeal From Lexington County
Â Clyde N. Davis, Jr., Master-in-Equity

Unpublished Opinion No.Â  2006-UP-015
Heard December 6, 2005 â€“ Filed January 11, 2006

AFFIRMED


  
    
      
        Katherine Carruth Link and S. Jahue Moore, both of West Columbia, for Appellants.
        George A. Kastanes, of Gilbert, for Respondents.
      
    
  

PER CURIAM: Watts Construction Company, Inc., and Donald Watts (Appellants) appeal the Master-In-Equityâ€™s order awarding $80,000 in damages to Gerald and Lupe Feltes for breach of a construction contract and breach of the implied warranty of workmanlike service.Â  We affirm.Â Â Â  
FACTS
The Feltes entered into a contract with Watts Construction Company, Inc. and Donald D. Watts for the construction of a new residence for the purchase price of $175,000 with a $17,500 initial deposit.Â  The contract included allowances for lighting, hardware, flooring (tile, hardwood, and carpet), fixtures, windows, a heat and air system, two garage doors with openers, cabinetry, certain ceiling heights, brick and vinyl exterior, and countertops.Â  The contract also stipulated â€œ[t]here will be no occupancy until all work has been completed and all costs have been paid.â€Â  As to any â€œchanges [desired by the Feltes] during the period in which the home [was] being constructed,â€ the contract provides â€œall extras [are to] be charged and billed to [the Feltes] at the time the changes are complete.â€Â  An employee of Watts Construction composed the agreement on company letterhead.Â  The Feltes and Appellants signed the document.Â  A handwritten amendment to the contract was later added setting the closing date on the construction of the home for December 15, 1997.Â  
Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â  Construction began in the summer of 1997.Â  Throughout the construction process, Appellants made periodic draws against the Feltesâ€™ construction loan.Â  On December 11, 1997, the Feltes contacted their construction loan company and requested that Appellants not be allowed to make further draws on the account without their express approval.Â  At this point, the Feltes had paid Appellants a total of $135,000.Â  On December 16, 1997, the Feltes provided Appellants with a written inspectorâ€™s report and a letter citing the items that needed immediate attention for completion of the home.Â  â€œDue to lack of response and progress on the home,â€ the Feltes terminated the contract with Appellants on January 12, 1998.Â  
Appellants brought a mechanicâ€™s lien foreclosure and breach of contract actions against the Feltes.Â  The Feltes counterclaimed for breach of contract and breach of the implied warranty of workmanlike service.Â  By consent of the parties, the mechanicâ€™s lien cause of action was dismissed.Â  The Master awarded the Feltes $153,505.23 for construction loan interest paid after December 15, 1997, costs incurred to complete the house, and â€œcost of repairs necessary to correct the defective workmanship.â€Â  This amount was to be offset by the $40,000 remaining due under the terms of the contract.Â  
Appellants then filed a motion for new trial or amended judgment.Â  Appellants argued the following issues: (1) Daniel Watts should have been excluded from the award because the Feltes produced no evidence warranting piercing of the corporate veil to reach him as a party; (2) Appellants were prejudiced by the two month delay between the hearing dates; (3) Appellants deserved an award because the overwhelming evidence proves the Feltes breached the contract; and (4) in the alternative, the amount awarded should be reduced, including increasing the amount offset to encompass the overages.Â  
The Master found the first issue was not preserved, but that all evidence indicated â€œthe judgment should be entered against both Plaintiffs.â€Â  Noting his extensive review of his thirteen pages of notes from the first hearing prior to the second part of the trial, the Master found no prejudice to Appellants from the bifurcated trial.Â  Finally, the Master reduced the total judgment of $113,505.23 to $80,000.Â  This appeal followed.Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â  
STANDARD OF REVIEW
An action for breach of contract seeking money damages is an action at law.Â  Sterling Dev. Co. v. Collins, 309 S.C. 237, 240, 421 S.E.2d 402, 404 (1992).Â  In an action at law, tried without a jury, the appellate court standard of review extends only to the correction of errors of law.Â  Okatie River, L.L.C. v. Southeastern Site Prep, L.L.C., 353 S.C. 327, 334, 577 S.E.2d 468, 472 (Ct. App. 2003).Â  The trial judgeâ€™s findings of fact will not be disturbed on appeal unless those findings are â€œwholly unsupported by the evidence or controlled by an erroneous conception or application of the law.â€Â  Maddux Supply Co. v. Safhi, Inc., 316 S.C. 404, 406, 450 S.E.2d 101, 102 (Ct. App. 1994). 
LAW/ANALYSIS
Appellants contend the Master erred in awarding the Feltes $80,000 for breach of contract and breach of the implied warranty of workmanlike service, or, in the alternative, in failing to set-off this award with the amounts attributable to the installation of the septic tank and the construction overages.Â  We disagree.
Â â€œA contract is an obligation which arises from actual agreement of the parties manifested by words, oral or written, or by conduct.â€ Â Roberts v. Gaskins, 327 S.C. 478, 483, 486 S.E.2d 771, 773 (Ct. App. 1997).Â  When a contract is clear and unambiguous, the construction of the contract is a question of law for the court. Â Conner v. Alvarez, 285 S.C. 97, 328 S.E.2d 334 (1985). Â In construing the terms of a contract, the foremost rule is that the court must give effect to the intentions of the parties by looking to the language of the contract. Â Id. at 101, 328 S.E.2d at 336. When the language of a contract is clear, explicit, and unambiguous, the language of the contract alone determines the contractâ€™s force and effect and the court must construe it according to its plain, ordinary, and popular meaning. Â Moser v. Gosnell, 334 S.C. 425, 430, 513 S.E.2d 123, 125 (Ct. App. 1999).
A builder who contracts to construct a dwelling impliedly warrants that the work undertaken will be performed in a careful, diligent, and workmanlike manner.Â  See Hill v. Polar Pantries, 219 S.C. 263, 64 S.E.2d 885 (1951).Â  A builder also has a legal duty to undertake construction commensurate with industry standards.Â  Kennedy v. Columbia Lumber and Mfg. Co., Inc., 299 S.C. 335, 346, 384 S.E.2d 730, 737 (1989) (citing Terlinde v. Neely, 275 S.C. 395, 399, 271 S.E.2d 768, 770 (1980)).
According to the amended contract, Appellants were responsible for completing construction of the home in a condition ready for occupancy by December 15, 1997.Â  Watts admitted that the agreement included an obligation to complete construction, as evidenced by the issuance of a certificate of occupancy.Â  In order to receive the certificate of occupancy, the house had to have electricity, a septic system, and plumbing with connected water.Â  
According to the Feltes, Appellants still had not installed the carpet, completed painting, or repaired defective brick work by the contractâ€™s deadline, December 15.Â  Furthermore, Appellantsâ€™ poor grading of the land caused the Feltesâ€™ septic system permit to be revoked.Â  Appellants contend they did not complete construction because the Feltes would not allow them to take a draw from the construction loan.Â  However, the contract did not require the Feltes to pay draws to Watts during the construction of the house.Â  The contract only required that the Feltes make an initial payment of $17, 500 and pay the balance of the construction price upon completion of the house.Â  Â 
After Appellants breached the contract by not completing it by the December 15 deadline, the Feltes gave Appellants additional time (more than a month) to complete a list of unsatisfactory or incomplete items.Â  However, these specified items were not completed.Â  Furthermore, several experts the in construction of residential houses testified that Appellantsâ€™ construction of the home substantially deviated from the industry standard.Â  Though their inspections cited numerous problems with the interior of the home, the majority of the inspections focused on the deficiency of the brick work.Â  The brick work problems included â€œtoo many problems with the mortar joint width, damaged brick, . . . chipped, broken out areas, mortar not matching, flashing omitted, which is a code violation.â€Â  According to the construction experts, the quality of the brick work was below the standard that would be acceptable in the home construction industry.Â  The construction experts also stated that the tiling, staining of the trim, and installation of the windows and cabinets were substandard.Â  
The Master had the benefit of hearing and observing the witnesses in this case; in addition, he inspected and personally observed the construction project in dispute.Â  Diamond Swimming Pool Co. v. Broome, 252 S.C. 379, 383, 166 S.E.2d 308, 310 (1969).Â  Based on more than sufficient evidence in the record to support the Masterâ€™s finding of a breach of contract and breach of the implied warranty of workmanlike service, we affirm the Masterâ€™s decision as to the $80,000 award to the Feltes.Â Â Â  
Appellants argue damages should be reduced by the amount used to install the septic tank and the amount Watts spent on construction overages.Â  We disagree.
Mark Burgess, an expert in home construction, estimated that to complete construction of the home and repair the substandard work would cost in the proximity of $143,801.79.Â  While this amount includes the cost of the installation of the septic system, which is not covered in the contract, there is no dispute that DHEC revoked the septic tank permit because of Appellantsâ€™ improper grading of the land.Â  Appellants also claim they are entitled to a $6,360.38 offset of the overage charges for extras added by the Feltes after the contract was signed.Â  We find the Master effectively took out the cost of installing the septic tank and offset the overages by lowering the damage award by $33,505.23. 
Appellants claim the Master erred in failing to dismiss Donald Watts as a party in this action.Â  We disagree.Â  
â€œIt is well-settled that an issue cannot be raised for the first time on appeal, but must have been raised to and ruled upon by the trial court to be preserved for appellate review.â€Â  Ellie, Inc. v. Miccichi, 358 S.C. 78, 102, 594 S.E.2d 485, 498 (Ct. App. 2004).Â  â€œA party cannot for the first time raise an issue by way of a Rule 59(e) motion which could have been raised at trial.â€Â  Patterson v. Reid , 318 S.C. 183, 185, 456 S.E.2d 436, 437 (Ct. App. 1995).Â  The first time Appellants raise this issue was in the Rule 59(e) motion for reconsideration.Â  Therefore, as the Master concluded, this issue was not timely raised and is not preserved for our review.Â  
For the reasons stated herein, the Masterâ€™s order is
AFFIRMED. Â Â Â Â 
GOOLSBY, ANDERSON, and SHORT, JJ. concur.
