THIS OPINION HAS NO PRECEDENTIAL VALUE.Â  IT SHOULD NOT BE CITED OR RELIED ON AS PRECEDENT IN ANY PROCEEDING EXCEPT AS PROVIDED BY RULE 239(d)(2), SCACR.
THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Court of Appeals

  
    
      
        Jesse D. Smith, Appellant,
      
    
  

v.

  
    
      
        Young’s Food Store, Inc., Respondent.
      
    
  


Appeal from Sumter County
Â Clifton Newman, Circuit Court Judge

Unpublished Opinion No. 2006-UP-016
Heard December 6, 2005 â€“ Filed January 11, 2006

AFFIRMED


  
    
      
        James K. Holmes, of Charleston, for Appellant.
        F. Barron Grier, III and Lauri S. Darwin, both of Columbia, for Respondent.
      
    
  

PER CURIAM: Jesse D. Smith brought causes of action against Youngâ€™s Food Stores for negligence and gross negligence arising from injuries he sustained while performing work at a Youngâ€™s store.Â  The circuit court held Smith was a statutory employee whose sole remedy was under the Workersâ€™ Compensation Act and dismissed the case.Â  Smith appeals the trial courtâ€™s ruling.Â  We affirm.Â Â Â Â  
FACTS
Between the fall of 1998 and the fall of 2001, Smith, d/b/a J & J Smith Contracting, contracted with Youngâ€™s Food Stores to perform paint and maintenance work at Youngâ€™s stores located in the Midlands and Pee Dee regions of South Carolina.Â  Smith performed work on about thirty-seven Youngâ€™s stores. Â Smithâ€™s work included remodeling, painting, flooring, and roofing. Â During this period, Smith worked â€œmostly . . . all for Youngâ€™sâ€ and considered the Youngâ€™s work â€œpretty full time.â€ Â Full-time employees of Youngâ€™s, including maintenance employee Andy Smith, did some of the same work and often worked alongside Smith.Â  
On August 14, 2001, Smith was working at Youngâ€™s store #6.Â  Smith was attempting to prepare the area he was to paint when he placed his hand on a metal gable and received an electric shock.Â  As a result of the shock, Smith claims he suffered physical injury, pain, lost wages, medical bills, loss of consortium, and loss of enjoyment of life.Â  Smith brought causes of action for negligence and gross negligence against Youngâ€™s.Â  
At trial, Youngâ€™s moved to dismiss the case arguing Smithâ€™s action was barred by the exclusivity provision of the Workersâ€™ Compensation Act because Smith qualified as a statutory employee.Â  Smith argued he was not a statutory employee because the work he performed was not an integral part of Youngâ€™s business.Â  The trial court held Smith was a statutory employee of Youngâ€™s and his exclusive remedy was through the Workersâ€™ Compensation Act.Â  Accordingly, the trial court dismissed the action for lack of jurisdiction. Â This appeal followed.
STANDARD OF REVIEW
â€œCoverage under the Workersâ€™ Compensation Act depends on the existence of an employment relationship.â€Â  Edens v. Bellini, 359 S.C. 433, 439, 597 S.E.2d 863, 866 (Ct. App. 2004).Â  â€œWhether or not an employer-employee relationship exists is a jurisdictional question.â€ Nelson v. Yellow Cab Co., 349 S.C. 589, 594, 564 S.E.2d 110, 112 (2002).Â  â€œThe determination of whether a worker is a statutory employee is jurisdictional and therefore the question on appeal is one of law.â€ Â Harrell v. Pineland Plantation, Ltd., 337 S.C. 313, 320, 523 S.E.2d 766, 769 (1999).Â  But, the exclusivity provision of the Workersâ€™ Compensation Act is procedural in nature and does not involve subject matter jurisdiction.Â  Saab v. South Carolina State University, 350 S.C. 416, 423, 567 S.E.2d 231, 234 (2002). Â Â Â 
LAW/ANALYSIS
Smith argues the trial court erred in dismissing his negligence claim on the basis that the exclusivity provision of the Workersâ€™ Compensation Act barred his negligence claim as he was a statutory employee of Youngâ€™s.Â  Smith asserts that the statutory employee portion of the Act does not apply to him because he was a subcontractor rather than an employee of a subcontractor.Â  This issue is not preserved for our review.Â  
â€œ[A]n issue cannot be raised for the first time on appeal, but must have been raised to and ruled upon by the trial judge to be preserved for appellate review.â€Â  Wilder Corp. v. Wilke, 330 S.C. 71, 76, 497 S.E.2d 731, 733 (1998). Â A party may not argue one ground at trial and another on appeal.Â  State v. McCray, 332 S.C. 536, 542, 506 S.E.2d 301, 303 (1998) (citing State v. Byram, 326 S.C. 107, 485 S.E.2d 360 (1997)).Â  
At trial, Smith contended he was not a statutory employee because he did not meet the criteria for determining whether a worker qualifies as a statutory employee for purposes of the Workersâ€™ Compensation Act.Â  Smith argued the work he performed, painting a sign, was not an integral part of the business of selling â€œsoda pop, cigarettes and things like that,â€ so the exclusively provision of the workersâ€™ compensation act did not bar his negligence action.Â  SeeÂ  Boone v. Huntington and Guerry Elec. Co.  311 S.C. 550, 553, 430 S.E.2d 507, 509 (1993); Carter v. Florentine Corp., Inc.  310 S.C. 228, 231, 423 S.E.2d 112, 113 (1992) (Three tests are applied in determining whether an employee of a subcontractor is a statutory employee of the owner: (1) is the activity an important part of the ownerâ€™s business; (2) is the activity a necessary, essential, integral part of the business; and (3) has the identical activity been performed by employees of the principal employer?).Â  On appeal Smith argues statutory employee section of the Act does not apply to him because he is the subcontractor and not an employee of the subcontractor.Â  Because Smith argues a different ground on appeal than he argued at trial, the issue is not preserved for appellate review.Â  Accordingly, the order of the trial court is 
AFFIRMED.
GOOLSBY, ANDERSON, and SHORT, JJ. concur.

THIS OPINION HAS NO PRECEDENTIAL VALUE.Â  IT SHOULD NOT BE CITED OR RELIED ON AS PRECEDENT IN ANY PROCEEDING EXCEPT AS PROVIDED BY RULE 239(d)(2), SCACR.
THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Court of Appeals

  
    
      
        Wayne Whitlock, Respondent,
      
    
  

v.

  
    
      
        Finley Siding, Inc., and Auto Owners Insurance Company, Appellants.
      
    
  


Appeal From Greenville County
Â Edward W. Miller, Circuit Court Judge

Unpublished Opinion No. 2006-UP-017
Submitted December 1, 2005 â€“ Filed January 11, 2006

AFFIRMED


  
    
      
        C. Roland Jones, Jr., of Spartanburg, for Appellants.
        Alton L. Martin, of Greenville and John P. Griffith, both of Anderson, for Respondent.
      
    
  

PER CURIAM:Â  Finley Siding and Auto Owners Insurance Company (Appellants) appeal the decision of the circuit court affirming the Appellant Panel of the South Carolina Workersâ€™ Compensation Commissionâ€™s (Full Commission) award of benefits to Wayne Whitlock.Â  We affirm.[1]
FACTS
In March 2000, Whitlock suffered an injury to his neck while in the course and scope of his employment at Finley Siding.Â  He reported the accident to his employer, who referred Whitlock to a chiropractor, Dr. Kolarik, and paid for his medical treatment.Â  Whitlock also saw his family doctor, Dr. Landrum McCarrell, who prescribed him pain medication.Â  
On December 17, 2001, Whitlock suffered a second work related injury.Â  Whitlock was carrying a large ladder when he stepped into a hole and jarred his shoulders, neck, and lower back.Â  Whitlock continued to work, but the burning pain worsened as the day progressed, so he reported the accident to Don Finley, the president of Finley Siding, the following day.Â  Finley again referred Whitlock to Dr. Kolarik and paid for the medical treatment.Â  Dr. Kolarik treated Whitlock for neck and shoulder pain, then Whitlock went on vacation and spent his time recuperating.
Whitlock did not seek further medical treatment for the next few months because he did not have health insurance.Â  However, when work began to pick up in the Spring of 2002, the pain in Whitlockâ€™s neck, shoulder, and back increased.Â  Whitlock saw Dr. McCarrell who referred him for an MRI, which showed a bulging disc in his neck.Â  Then, Whitlock was referred to a neurologist, who noted that Whitlockâ€™s job was aggravating his symptoms.Â  Dr. McCarrell proscribed pain medication and recommended physical therapy.Â  
Whitlock then notified his employer that he needed additional medical treatment and was referred to their workersâ€™ compensation insurance carrier, Auto Owners Insurance Company.Â  Auto Ownerâ€™s denied Whitlockâ€™s claim for additional treatment.Â  
On October 10, 2002, Whitlock filed a Form 50, seeking reimbursement for additional medical treatment.Â  Whitlock asserted that he had difficulty doing his job because of problems with his neck, shoulders, and back, and he remained in pain, which he treated with medication.Â  Don Finley conceded that Whitlock had reported the December 17, 2001 accident to him and that he authorized Whitlock to obtain medical treatment.Â  
The Single Commissioner found that Whitlock had a pre-exisiting arthritic condition in his back, and the accident caused a compensable aggravation to his condition.Â  The Single Commissioner ordered that Whitlock was entitled to reimbursement for future medical treatment and for causally-related medical treatment already incurred.Â  
Appellants sought review of the decision by the Full Commission, which unanimously affirmed the Single Commissionerâ€™s decision and adopted his order verbatim.Â  Thereafter, Appellants appealed to the circuit court, arguing the Full Commissionâ€™s order was not supported by substantial evidence.Â  The circuit court affirmed the Full Commissionâ€™s order.Â  This appeal followed.
LAW/ANALYSIS
Appellants argue the Full Commission erred in finding that Whitlock is entitled to future medical treatment for his back and shoulder because his on-going complaints stem from his accident on December 17, 2001. Â Appellants contend that any future treatment Whitlock may require is the result of his pre-existing arthritic condition rather than the accident.Â  We disagree.
The Administrative Procedures Act establishes the standard of review for decisions by the Workersâ€™ Compensation Commission.Â  S.C. Code Ann. Â§Â  1-23-380 (2005); Lark v. Bi-Lo, Inc., 276 S.C. 130, 132, 276 S.E.2d 304, 305 (1981).Â  â€œThe appellate courtâ€™s review is limited to deciding whether the commissionâ€™s decision is unsupported by substantial evidence or is controlled by some error of law.â€Â  Hendricks v. Pickens County, 335 S.C. 405, 411, 517 S.E.2d 698, 701 (Ct. App. 1999).Â  Substantial evidence is â€œnot a mere scintilla of evidence nor the evidence viewed blindly from one side of the case, but is evidence which, considering the record as a whole, would allow reasonable minds to reach the conclusion that the administrative agency reached or must have reached in order to justify its action.â€Â  Miller by Miller v. State Roofing Co., 312 S.C. 452, 454, 441 S.E.2d 323, 324-25 (1994) (quoting Lark v. Bi-Lo, Inc., 276 S.C. 130, 136, 276 S.E.2d 304, 307 (1981)).Â  A court may reverse or modify an agencyâ€™s decision â€œâ€˜if substantial rights of the appellant have been prejudiced because the administrative findings, inferences, conclusions or decisions are . . . affected by other error of law.â€™â€Â  Stephen v. Avins Const. Co., 324 S.C. 334, 337, 478 S.E.2d 74, 76 (Ct. App. 1996) (citations omitted).
Our courts have clearly held that a work-related accident that aggravates or accelerates a pre-existing condition, infirmity, or disease is compensable.Â  Mullinax v. Winn-Dixie Stores, Inc., 318 S.C. 431, 437, 458 S.E.2d 76, 79 (Ct. App. 1995); Brown v. R.L. Jordan Oil Co., 291 S.C. 272, 275, 353 S.E.2d 280, 282 (1987); Sturkie v. Ballenger Corp., 268 S.C. 536, 541, 235 S.E.2d 120, 122 (1977); Glover v. Columbia Hospital of Richland County, 236 S.C. 410, , 114 S.E.2d 565, 569 (1960) (a quiescent weakened, but not disabling condition accidentally aggravated, accelerated, or activated, with resulting disability, is compensable).Â  A condition is compensable unless it is due solely to the natural progression of a pre-existing condition.Â  Mullinax, 318 S.C. at 437, 458 S.E.2d at 80.Â  â€œIt is no defense that the accident, standing alone, would not have caused the claimantâ€™s condition, because the employer takes the employee as it finds him or her.â€Â  Brown, 291 S.C. at 275, 353 S.E.2d at 582.Â  Circumstantial evidence may be used to prove causation.Â  Mullinax, 318 S.C. at 437, 458 S.E.2d at 80.Â  Moreover, â€œâ€˜[t]he causal sequence . . . may be more indirect or complex, but as long as the causal connection is in fact present the compensability of the subsequent condition is beyond question.â€™â€Â  Id. (quoting Arthur Larson, The Law of Workmenâ€™s Compensation Â§ 13.11(b) (1994)).
The Full Commission found that Whitlock had a pre-existing arthritic condition in his back but found Whitlockâ€™s testimony that the pain became unbearable as a result of the accident credible.Â  Whitlock testified that he missed more than ten days of work and was late on several occasions because he â€œhad to get the hurting to stop first.â€Â  Furthermore, the president of Finley Siding admitted that Whitlock reported the accident and sought treatment at the businessesâ€™ expense as a result.Â  
The medical evidence also supports the Full Commissionâ€™s finding that the accident caused a worsening in Whitlockâ€™s condition.Â  In his APA submissions, Whitlock presented a letter in which Dr. McCarrell stated that since the accident, Whitlock â€œhas had worsened pain and has had increasing need for pain medication and really intensification of his symptom complex.â€Â  Dr. McCarrell, who treated Whitlock before and after the accident, also asserted that he believed Whitlockâ€™s increased pain was the result of the December 17, 2001 accident.Â  Dr. McCarrell additionally opined that Whitlock will need continued medical treatment as a result of the accident, including physical therapy and pain medication.Â  
Therefore, the Full Commissionâ€™s finding that Whitlock suffered a compensable aggravation of his injury and had not reached maximum medical improvement is supported by substantial evidence in the record.Â  We find no error in the Full Commissionâ€™s decision to award Whitlock benefits for additional medical treatment for his back and shoulder.Â  Accordingly, the order of the circuit court is 
AFFIRMED.
GOOLSBY, ANDERSON, and SHORT, JJ. concur.Â  


[1] Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â  We decide this case without oral argument pursuant to Rule 215, SCACR.

THIS OPINION HAS NO PRECEDENTIAL VALUE.Â  IT SHOULD NOT BE CITED OR RELIED ON AS PRECEDENT IN ANY PROCEEDINGÂ Â  EXCEPT AS PROVIDED BY RULE 239(d)(2), SCACR.
THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Court of Appeals

  
    
      
        Rhonda Hendrix, Individually and as the duly appointed Guardian Ad Litem of Haley Hendrix, a minor under the age of fourteen years, Appellant,
      
    
  

v.

  
    
      
        Duke Energy Corporation, Mike Burton, Individually and d/b/a Burton Plumbing and Electrical Service, Burton Plumbing and Electrical Service, Inc., Recreational Factory Warehouse of Greenville, Inc., and Tri-State Installations, Inc., Defendants,
        Of whom Duke Energy Corporation is the, Respondent.
      
    
  


Appeal From Oconee County
Â James C. Williams, Jr., Circuit Court Judge

Unpublished Opinion No. 2006-UP-022
Heard December 6, 2005 â€“ Filed January 12, 2006

AFFIRMED


  
    
      
        Eugene Charles Fulton, Jr., of Columbia and J. Edward Bell, III, of Sumter, for Appellant.
        James W. Logan, Jr., of Anderson, for Respondent.
      
    
  

PER CURIAM:Â  Rhonda Hendrix brought this negligence action against Duke Energy Corporation and others after her daughter suffered an electrical shock when she touched a dock Hendrix owned at Lake Keowee.Â  Hendrix alleged Duke was negligent in failing to properly oversee the permitting of the dock.Â  The circuit court granted Dukeâ€™s motion for summary judgment, finding as a matter of law that Duke owed no duty of care in this regard and that, in any event, the claim was barred by the South Carolina Recreational Use Statute.Â  Hendrix appeals.Â  We affirm.
FACTS
Duke owns Lake Keowee in Oconee County and operates it pursuant to a license granted by the Federal Energy Regulation Commission (FERC) covering the â€œKeowee-Toxaway Project.â€Â  In 1996, FERC issued an â€œOrder Amending Licenseâ€ to Duke stating the purpose of the amendment was â€œto reduce some administrative burden on [Duke]â€ by allowing it to authorize certain minor uses of the property without seeking prior approval from FERC.Â  Among other things, Duke was authorized to grant permission for the use of boat docks that were intended to serve single-family dwellings.Â Â Â  
The order â€œcontain[ed] conditions designed to ensure that any authorized use . . . permitted . . . is consistent with the project license and the protection of the projectâ€™s scenic, recreational, and other environmental values.â€Â  Duke was required to â€œensure, to the satisfaction of the Commissionâ€™s [FERCâ€™s] authorized representative, that the uses and occupancies for which it grants permission are maintained in good repair and comply with applicable State and local health and safety requirements.â€Â  The order further provided as follows:Â  

  [Duke] shall . . . have continuing responsibility to supervise and control the use and occupancies for which it grants permission, and to monitor the use of, ensure compliance with the covenants of the instrument of conveyance for, any interests that it has conveyed under this article.Â  If a permitted use and occupancy violates any condition of this article or any other condition imposed by [Duke] for protection and enhancement of the projectâ€™s scenic, recreational, or other environmental values, or, if a covenant of a conveyance made under the authority of this article is violated, [Duke] shall take any lawful action necessary to correct the violation.Â  

Management of Lake Keowee is also controlled by Dukeâ€™s own Shoreline Management Guidelines.Â  The purpose of the Guidelines â€œis to provide detailed procedures and criteria to regulate activities within reservoirs managed by Duke . . . .â€Â  The Guidelines state â€œLake Management is responsible for the continuous monitoring of activities within the boundaries of Duke reservoirs to ensure activities are consistent with established company policies and license requirements.â€Â  
As part of its management of Lake Keowee, Duke conducted inspections of docks built on the lake and issued permits for construction.Â  Dukeâ€™s formal permitting process began in 1987 and applied only to future construction; docks built prior to 1987 were grandfathered in â€œunless the dock was in such bad repair that it was a navigational hazard.â€Â  Duke did not check electrical power to docks and has no guidelines or rules regulating electrical power to docks.Â  Dukeâ€™s inspections were limited to checking â€œto make sure the dock was safe and not a navigational hazardâ€ and making sure the permitee â€œbuilt what they were approved for.â€Â  
In 1999, Rhonda Hendrix was the owner of real property abutting Lake Keowee.Â  Hendrixâ€™s property included a dock that extended into Lake Keowee.Â  A light fixture on the dock connected to electric transmission wires that ran to Hendrixâ€™s house.Â  Sometime prior to 1999, Duke issued a permit for Hendrixâ€™s dock.Â  The trial court noted â€œ[t]he Hendrix dock appears to be one of those docks that was already in existence in 1987 and that was issued a tag or permit without an application or inspection.â€Â  
In 1998, Hendrix purchased a swimming pool from Recreational Factory Warehouse, which subcontracted the installation to Tri-States Installation, Inc.Â  Tri-States, in turn, hired a grading contractor to grade the yard prior to installation.Â  The grading contractor apparently cut some of the electrical wires in the yard.Â  Someone then spliced the wires back together and left them in the yard.Â Â Â Â Â  
In the spring of 1999, Hendrix hired Mike Burton, an electrician, to install an outlet near the pool.Â  Hendrix informed Burton that her daughter Haley had been shocked at the boat dock about two weeks earlier.Â  When Burton installed the outlet, he inspected the dock wiring and determined all of the dock wiring â€œneeded to be redoneâ€ as â€œnone of that stuff was to code.â€Â  Specifically, he noticed â€œthat the wires were just exposed and nothing was in conduit.â€Â  According to Burton, state code requires installing all electric wires on docks in a flex conduit.Â  Burton showed Hendrix the wires and advised her that he did not have time to fix them and that she would need to secure the services of another electrician to correct the problem.Â  
On August 14, 1999, Hendrixâ€™s daughter Haley and some friends left the Hendrix dock for a boat outing.Â  When the boat stalled, Haley jumped out of the boat and swam back to the Hendrix dock.Â  When she touched the dock, she received an electric shock and was rendered unconscious.Â  A neighbor, Alan D. Wheeler, heard screams for help and came over in his boat to help.Â  When he touched the Hendrix dock, Wheeler was electrocuted.Â Â  Haley survived the accident, but suffered severe personal injuries.Â  
Hendrix filed this action against Duke and others to recover for Haleyâ€™s injuries, alleging Haley was injured â€œdue to faulty installation of the pool and electrical wiring.â€Â  As to Duke, Hendrix alleged Duke was negligent and reckless in the management of Lake Keowee and in the inspection and permitting of the Hendrix dock.Â  
Duke moved for summary judgment, arguing it had no duty of care.Â  Hendrix alleged a duty of care arose from Dukeâ€™s status as owner or manager of Lake Keowee, from the FERC license (as amended), or from Dukeâ€™s own Guidelines.Â  The trial court ruled as a matter of law that no duty existed and granted Dukeâ€™s motion for summary judgment.Â  Hendrix appeals.
STANDARD OF REVIEW
In reviewing the grant of a motion for summary judgment, an appellate court applies the same standard that governs the trial court under Rule 56(c), SCRCP.Â  Ferguson v. Charleston Lincoln Mercury, Inc., 349 S.C. 558, 564 S.E.2d 94 (2002).Â  Summary judgment is appropriate when â€œthe pleadings, depositions, answers to interrogatories, and admissions on file, together with the affidavits, if any, show that there is no genuine issue as to any material fact and that the moving party is entitled to a judgment as a matter of law.â€Â  Rule 56(c), SCRCP; see also Standard Fire Ins. Co. v. Marine Contracting & Towing Co., 301 S.C. 418, 421, 392 S.E.2d 460, 462 (1990).Â  In determining whether any triable issues of fact exist, the evidence and all reasonable inferences therefrom must be viewed in the light most favorable to the party opposing summary judgment.Â  Summer v. Carpenter, 328 S.C. 36, 492 S.E.2d 55 (1997).Â  
LAW/ANALYSIS
I.Â  Negligence Liability
On appeal, Hendrix argues Duke owed a duty to exercise reasonable care to inspect the electrical wiring at the Hendrix dock and to discover the allegedly faulty wiring.Â  
â€œTo establish a cause of action in negligence, a plaintiff must prove the following three elements: (1) a duty of care owed by [the] defendant to [the] plaintiff; (2) breach of that duty by a negligent act or omission; and (3) damage proximately resulting from the breach of duty.â€Â  Bloom v. Ravoira, 339 S.C. 417, 422, 529 S.E.2d 710, 712 (2000).Â  â€œThe absence of any one of these elements renders the cause of action insufficient.â€Â  South Carolina State Ports Auth. v. Booz-Allen & Hamilton, Inc., 289 S.C. 373, 376, 346 S.E.2d 324, 325 (1986).
â€œThe court must determine, as a matter of law, whether the law recognizes a particular duty.â€Â  Simmons v. Tuomey Regâ€™l Med. Ctr., 341 S.C. 32, 39, 533 S.E.2d 312, 316 (2000). Â â€œIf there is no duty, then the defendant in a negligence action is entitled to a judgment as a matter of law.â€Â  Id.
a.Â  Duty owed as Owner and Manager
Hendrix asserts Duke owed a duty to exercise reasonable care by virtue of its status as the owner and manager of Lake Keowee.Â Â Â  
â€œAn owner of land possesses a general duty to warn others of latent hazardous conditions on his land.â€Â  Byerly v. Connor, 307 S.C. 441, 443, 415 S.E.2d 796, 798 (1992).Â  â€œThis duty arises from the ownerâ€™s superior knowledge of conditions on the premises within his control.â€Â  Id. 
We hold Duke had no duty to warn of faulty electrical wiring on Hendrixâ€™s dock because Duke did not have control of the dock and did not have superior knowledge of the conditions on the dock.Â  
The facts of this case are similar to those of Byerly.Â  In Byerly, a lake user was electrocuted after diving into Lake Marion from a houseboat that was moored to a dock operated by a lessee (J & J Marina, Inc.) of Santee Cooper.Â  Either a defectively wired outlet on the dock or a defect in the wiring of the houseboat itself caused the shock.Â  Id. at 443, 415 S.E.2d at 798.Â  Our supreme court noted that in typical lease agreements the lessor generally â€œis not responsible for hazardous conditions which thereafter develop or are created by the lessee,â€ in part because â€œthe lessor surrenders possession and control of the land to the lessee.â€Â  Id.Â  The supreme court affirmed the trial judgeâ€™s grant of summary judgment to Santee Cooper, concluding the lake owner had no duty to discover and warn of a latent hazardous condition which it did not create and about which it had no knowledge.Â  Id. at 445-46, 415 S.E.2d at 799.Â  The court stated Santee Cooperâ€™s limited undertaking to inspect docks and piers to ensure that they conformed to the structural requirements of the permits issued by Santee Cooper â€œdid not include a duty to inspect for a latent hazardous electrical condition at J & J Marina.â€Â  Id.Â  at 445, 415 S.E.2d at 799.
While the appeal now before us does not involve a lease, the analysis is the same.Â  The key element imposing a general duty on landowners to warn of latent hazardous defects is the landownerâ€™s presumed superior knowledge based on control and possession of property.Â  A landowner lacking control and possession does not have the same general duty.Â  Duke, like the lake owner in Byerly, did not have control of the dock and therefore possessed no superior knowledge of the property.Â  Accordingly, we hold Duke owed no duty to discover and warn lake users of faulty wiring on Hendrixâ€™s dock.Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â  
Categorizing Haley as an invitee does not change the analysis.Â  Hendrix argues Duke owed Haley a duty to exercise reasonable care because of Haleyâ€™s status as an â€œinvitee.â€Â  A landowner has a duty to warn an invitee of latent or hidden dangers of which the landowner has knowledge or should have knowledge.Â  See, e.g., Callander v. Charleston Doughnut Corp., 305 S.C. 123, 126, 406 S.E.2d 361, 362 (1991).Â  The invitorâ€™s liability rests entirely upon his superior knowledge of the danger that caused the inviteeâ€™s injuries.Â  Larimore v. Carolina Power & Light, 340 S.C. 438, 448, 531 S.E.2d 535, 540 (Ct. App. 2000).Â  The invitor cannot be held liable, however, if the invitor lacks superior knowledge.Â  Id.Â  Thus, even if Haley is determined to be an invitee, Duke owed Haley no duty to warn of the faulty wiring on Hendrixâ€™s dock because Duke lacked superior knowledge of the property.
b.Â  Duty arising from FERC License
Hendrix next contends Duke owed a duty to exercise reasonable care based on the provisions of the FERC license (as amended).Â  
â€œAn affirmative legal duty to act exists only if created by statute, contract, relationship, status, property interest, or some other special circumstance.â€Â  Charleston Dry Cleaners & Laundry, Inc. v. Zurich American Ins. Co., 355 S.C. 614, 618, 586 S.E.2d 586, 588 (2003).Â Â  
We agree with the trial courtâ€™s conclusion that the general requirements imposed by the FERC license cannot be read to create in Duke a duty to discover and warn of a latent hazardous defect which it did not create and about which it had no knowledge.Â  The FERC license requires Duke to â€œensure . . . that the uses and occupancies for which it grants permission are maintained in good repair and comply with applicable State and local health and safety requirements,â€ and imposes on Duke a â€œcontinuing responsibility to supervise and control the use and occupancies for which it grants permission.â€Â  As noted by the trial court, there is no indication the license creates a private right of action, even if Duke failed to meet the licenseâ€™s conditions.Â Â Â  
Reading the licenseâ€™s general requirements to create a special duty to inspect dock wiring would make Duke an absolute insurer of the safety of every person who uses or comes in contact with a dock on Lake Keowee, even though Duke does not own, construct, or control such docks.Â  This was clearly not the intent of the license, and to adopt such a finding would be an unreasonable interpretation of the license.Â  We conclude the FERC license did not create a duty to Hendrix even if it did result in an obligation to FERC.Â  Accordingly, we find Duke does not owe dock users a duty of care by virtue of the general requirements contained in the FERC license.[1]Â Â Â  Â 
c.Â  Duty Arising from Undertaking and by Virtue of Guidelines
Hendrix alleges Dukeâ€™s own Guidelines and its undertaking to inspect docks on Lake Keowee created in Duke a duty to exercise reasonable care to discover the allegedly faulty wiring on her dock. 
â€œAt common law, where there is no duty to act, but an act is voluntarily undertaken, the actor assumes a duty to use due care.â€Â  Byerly, 307 S.C. at 445, 415 S.E.2d at 799.Â  Nonetheless, â€œ[t]he concept of a duty in tort liability will not extend beyond reasonable limits.â€Â  Huggins v. Citibank, 355 S.C. 329, 333, 585 S.E.2d 275, 277 (2003). 
We agree with the trial court that Duke did not undertake to inspect the electrical wiring of the docks on Lake Keowee and, therefore, no act by Duke created any duty to use reasonable care to inspect the docks.Â  Dukeâ€™s permitting process only sought to make sure permitted docks were structurally sound and did not create a navigational hazard.Â  Duke did not check electrical power to docks and had no policies or rules regulating electrical power on private docks.Â  Under similar facts in Byerly, our supreme court found that the lake owner only undertook a â€œlimited duty to use due care to discover structural nonconformity with permits,â€ and that â€œundertaking to inspect for structural conformity did not include a duty to inspect for a latent hazardous electrical condition.â€Â  Id., 307 S.C. at 445, 415 S.E.2d at 799.Â  The evidence shows Duke did not undertake a duty to inspect electrical wiring on the docks, and its permitting process cannot be used to create such a duty.Â  
II.Â  The South Carolina Recreational Use Statute
Hendrix next argues the trial court erred in ruling the South Carolina Recreational Use Statute applied so as to limit Dukeâ€™s liability.Â  The court stated the statute provided an additional ground for summary judgment beyond the fact that there was no common law duty.Â  Hendrix argues Duke was grossly negligent, an exception to the statute. 
â€œThe purpose of [the Recreational Use Statute] is to encourage owners of land to make land and water areas available to the public for recreational purposes by limiting their liability toward persons entering thereon for such purposes.â€Â  S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 27-3-10 (1991).Â  A â€œâ€˜[r]ecreational purposeâ€™ includes, but is not limited to, any of the following, or any combination thereof:Â Â  . . . swimming, boating, . . . [and] summer and winter sports . . . .â€Â  Id. Â§ 27-3-20(c).Â  
The Recreational Use Statute states â€œan owner of land owes no duty of care to keep the premises safe for entry or use by persons who have sought and obtained his permission to use it for recreational purposes or to give any warning of a dangerous condition, use, structure, or activity on such premises to such persons entering for such purposes.â€Â  Id. Â§ 27-3-30.Â  There are, however, two exceptions as the statute does not limit liability which otherwise exists for (1) â€œgrossly negligent, willful or malicious failure to guard or warn against a dangerous condition, use, structure, or activityâ€ orÂ  (2) â€œinjury suffered . . . where the owner of land charges personsâ€ who use the property.Â  Id. Â§ 27-3-60.Â Â Â  
The Recreational Use Statute specifically limits the liability of landowners who make property available to the public for recreational purposes.Â  Duke falls squarely within the parameters of the Recreational Use Statute because Duke allowed members of the public to use Lake Keowee for recreational purposes (e.g., swimming and boating).Â  Duke, therefore,Â  generally owed no duty to lake users â€œto keep the premises safeâ€ or â€œto give any warning of a dangerous condition, use, structure, or activity.â€Â  See S.C. Code Â§ 27-3-30(a) & (b). 
On appeal, Hendrix asserts Duke falls within the grossly negligent exception to the Recreational Use Statute.Â  We find there is no evidence to support an allegation that Duke was grossly negligent.Â  â€œGross negligence is the intentional, conscious failure to do something which it is incumbent upon one to do or the doing of a thing intentionally that one ought not to do.â€Â  Richardson v. Hambright, 296 S.C. 504, 506, 374 S.E.2d 296, 298 (1988).Â  Duke had no duty to inspect dock wiring and committed no intentional act.Â  Thus, as a matter of law, Duke cannot be found grossly negligent and the trial court correctly found the Recreational Use Statute limits Dukeâ€™s liability and provides an additional ground supporting summary judgment.[2]Â Â  
III.Â  Punitive Damages 
Hendrix lastly argues the trial court improperly granted summary judgment on her punitive damages claim because a jury could find a conscious failure to exercise due care by Duke.Â  
â€œIn order for a plaintiff to recover punitive damages, there must be evidence the defendantâ€™s conduct was wilful, wanton, or in reckless disregard of the plaintiffâ€™s rights.â€Â  McCourt v. Abernathy, 318 S.C. 301, 308, 457 S.E.2d 603, 607 (1995).Â  â€œA conscious failure to exercise due care constitutes wilfulness.â€Â  Id.Â  
No evidence in the record indicates Duke acted in a wilful, wanton, or reckless manner.Â  As discussed above, Duke owed no duty of care to discover or warn of faulty wiring on Hendrixâ€™s dock.Â  Accordingly, Duke did not demonstrate â€œa conscious failure to exercise due care,â€ and we find the trial court properly dismissed Hendrixâ€™s claim for punitive damages.Â  
CONCLUSION
Based on the foregoing, we find, as a matter of law, Duke owed no duty of care to lake users to discover or warn of a latent hazardous defect which it did not create and about which it had no knowledge.Â  The decision of the trial court is
AFFIRMED.
GOOLSBY, ANDERSON, and SHORT, JJ., concur.

[1]Â  The trial court also found that Hendrix could not rely on the provisions in the FERC license to create a duty in this state court action because 16 U.S.C.A. Â§ 825p (2005) provides violations come within the jurisdiction of the federal courts.Â  This section provides as follows:

  The District Courts of the United States . . . shall have exclusive jurisdiction of violations of [the Federal Power Act] or the rules, regulations, and orders thereunder, and of all suits in equity and actions at law brought to enforce any liability or duty created by . . . this chapter or rule, regulation, or order thereunder. 

Hendrix disputes the trial courtâ€™s finding.Â  She acknowledges that, where FERC seeks to enforce an obligation against a licensee for violating a provision of its FERC license, it must do so in federal court, but argues this â€œdoes not mean that a plaintiff suing on a state law negligence claim must sue in federal court when he uses the FERC license to establish a duty of care.â€Â  Since we have found the FERC license would not, in any event, create a duty in this regard, we need not decide whether it is applicable in state court.Â  
[2]Â Â  Hendrix does not argue on appeal that the second exception regarding the charge of a fee applies in this case.Â  The trial court ruled that this exception did not apply as Hendrix had made â€œno allegation and no proof that Duke charged a fee for the Plaintiffsâ€™ recreational use of Lake Keowee or for the Hendrix dock.â€Â  Since no challenge is made to this finding, it is the law of the case.Â  Accordingly, we do not address this exception.

THIS OPINION HAS NO PRECEDENTIAL VALUE.Â  IT SHOULD NOT BE CITED OR RELIED ON AS PRECEDENT IN ANY PROCEEDING EXCEPT AS PROVIDED BY RULE 239(d)(2), SCACR.
THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Court of Appeals

  
    
      
        The State, Respondent,
      
    
  

v.

  
    
      
        Ray Lynn Hollifield, Appellant.
      
    
  


Appeal From Spartanburg County
Â Howard P. King, Circuit Court Judge

Unpublished Opinion No.Â  2006-UP-023
Submitted January 1, 2006 â€“ Filed January 12, 2006

AFFIRMED


  
    
      
        Ricky Keith Harris, of Spartanburg, for Appellant.
        Attorney General Henry Dargan McMaster, Chief Deputy Attorney General John W. McIntosh, Assistant Deputy Attorney General Salley W. Elliott, Â Senior Assistant Attorney General Norman Mark Rapoport, all of Columbia; and Solicitor Harold W. Gowdy, III, of Spartanburg, for Respondent.
      
    
  

PER CURIAM:Â  Appellant Ray Lynn Hollifield was indicted by the Spartanburg County Grand Jury on June 5, 2003 for distribution of methamphetamine, trafficking in methamphetamine more than 100 grams, possession of Xanax, and possession of a firearm during the commission of a violent crime.Â  Hollifield moved to quash the indictments of trafficking in methamphetamine more than 100 grams, possession of a firearm during the commission of a violent crime, and possession of Xanax.Â  Hollifield argued that the witness listed on those indictments did not testify before the grand jury.Â  The trial court denied Hollifieldâ€™s motion.Â  Hollifield pled guilty to all of the charges on the second day of the trial and was sentenced to 15 years concurrent on all counts.Â  Hollifield contends the unknown individual who testified provided summary hearsay and was a designated officer of the State.
We affirm pursuant to Rule 220(b)(2), SCACR, and the following authorities: Â Evans v. State, 363 S.C. 495, 611 S.E.2d 510 (2005) (stating a defendantâ€™s challenge to the sufficiency of a grand jury indictment does not implicate the subject matter jurisdiction of the trial court); State v. Gentry, 363 S.C. 93, 102, 610 S.E.2d 494, 499 (2005) (holding the presentment of an indictment is not needed to confer subject matter jurisdiction on the circuit court, but that an indictment is needed to give notice to the defendant of the charges against him); State v. Truesdale, 278 S.C. 368, 296 S.E.2d 528 (1982) (ruling that pleas of guilty are unconditional, and if an accused attempts to attach any condition or qualification thereto, the trial court should direct a plea of not guilty); Rivers v. Strickland, 264 S.C. 121, 213 S.E.2d 97 (1975) (holding a guilty plea, voluntarily and understandingly made, generally constitutes a waiver of nonjurisdictional defects and defenses, including claims of violation of constitutional rights prior to plea).
AFFIRMED.[1]
GOOLSBY, ANDERSON, and SHORT, JJ., concur.


[1] We decide this case without oral argument pursuant to Rule 215, SCACR.

THIS OPINION HAS NO PRECEDENTIAL VALUE.  IT SHOULD NOT BE CITED OR RELIED ON AS PRECEDENT IN ANY PROCEEDING EXCEPT AS PROVIDED BY RULE 239(d)(2), SCACR.
THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Court of Appeals


  
    
      
        Jane Addis Hunnicutt, Respondent,
      
    
  

v.

  
    
      
        Stanley Philips Hunnicutt, Appellant.
      
    
  


Appeal From Horry County
Lisa A. Kinon, Family Court Judge

 Unpublished Opinion No. 2006-UP-024
Submitted December 1, 2005 â€“ Filed January 12, 2006

AFFIRMED IN PART,
REVERSED IN PART, AND
MODIFIED IN PART


  
    
      
        John O. McDougall and Emma I. Bryson, both of Sumter, for Appellant.
        James L. Hills, of Myrtle Beach, for Respondent.
      
    
  

PER CURIAM:Â  Stanley Philips Hunnicutt (Husband) appeals from the family courtâ€™s order granting Jane Addis Hunnicutt (Wife) a divorce and awarding her alimony, an equitable division of the marital property, and attorneyâ€™s fees.Â  He asserts the family court improperly awarded alimony based, in part, on expenses associated with the partiesâ€™ emancipated daughter.Â  Additionally, he contends the family court erred in its valuation of marital property, including Wifeâ€™s retirement account.Â  Finally, he maintains the court erred in awarding Wife attorneyâ€™s fees.Â  We affirm in part, reverse in part, and modify in part.[1]
FACTS
Husband and Wife were married for nearly twenty-six years and lived in Greenville County.Â  The parties had two daughters, both of whom were emancipated.Â  One of the daughters attended college and was aided financially by Wife.Â  Additionally, the parties had historically allocated money received from a partnership towards her tuition.Â  
Shortly before the parties separated, Husband was terminated from his employment with Springs Industries and received a severance package equal to six months salary.Â  Husband became self-employed as a sales representative for ViPac.Â  His salary was approximately $73,000 per year.Â  Wife testified Husband informed her that once he was established he could earn greater income in the range of $90-110,000 per year. 
After the separation, Wife moved to the partiesâ€™ residence in Horry County and took a teaching position.Â  However, in early 2003, Wife returned to Greenville due to emotional problems.Â  She eventually took a position as a guidance counselor earning a gross income of approximately $53,000 per year. 
Wife sought a divorce on the ground of Husbandâ€™s adultery.Â  She further sought permanent periodic or lump sum alimony, an equitable division of the partiesâ€™ assets and debts, and attorneyâ€™s fees.Â  Husband answered and counterclaimed requesting that neither party receive alimony, the marital residence be sold, an equitable division of marital assets, and attorneyâ€™s fees. 
The family court granted the divorce on the ground of Husbandâ€™s adultery, awarded Wife permanent periodic alimony of $750 per month, awarded Wife the marital home, divided the marital assets equally (fifty percent to each party), and awarded Wife $10,000 in attorneyâ€™s fees.Â  After Husband filed a motion for reconsideration, the family court altered the amount of his severance package for the purpose of dividing the marital estate.Â  This appeal followed.
STANDARD OF REVIEW
In appeals from the family court, this court may find facts in accordance with its own view of the preponderance of the evidence. Rutherford v. Rutherford, 307 S.C. 199, 204, 414 S.E.2d 157, 160 (1992); Owens v. Owens, 320 S.C. 543, 546, 466 S.E.2d 373, 375 (Ct. App. 1996).Â  However, this broad scope of review does not require us to disregard the family courtâ€™s findings.Â  Stevenson v. Stevenson, 276 S.C. 475, 477, 279 S.E.2d 616, 617 (1981).Â  Nor must we ignore the fact that the trial judge, who saw and heard the witnesses, was in a better position to evaluate their credibility and assign comparative weight to their testimony.Â  Cherry v. Thomasson, 276 S.C. 524, 525, 280 S.E.2d 541, 541 (1981); Miles v. Miles, 355 S.C. 511, 516, 586 S.E.2d 136, 139 (Ct. App. 2003).
DISCUSSION
Husband contends the family court erred in its determination that Wife was entitled to an award of alimony, the valuation of Wifeâ€™s retirement account, the equitable distribution of marital property, and the award of attorneyâ€™s fees to Wife. 
I.Â Â Alimony
Husband maintains the family court erred in awarding Wife permanent periodic alimony.Â  First, he contends Wifeâ€™s testimony indicated she sought rehabilitative alimony, which was not requested in her complaint.Â  Second, he asserts Wifeâ€™s financial declarations improperly included expenses related to the partiesâ€™ daughter and the need for alimony was not shown.Â  Finally, he argues the family court erred in imputing income to him as a result of his termination from Springs and his self-employment as a sales representative. 
An award of alimony rests within the sound discretion of the family court and will not be disturbed absent an abuse of discretion.Â  Dearybury v. Dearybury, 351 S.C. 278, 282, 569 S.E.2d 367, 369 (2002).Â  â€œAlimony is a substitute for the support which is normally incident to the marital relationship.â€Â  Spence v. Spence, 260 S.C. 526, 529, 197 S.E.2d 683, 684 (1973); Johnson v. Johnson, 296 S.C. 289, 300, 372 S.E.2d 107, 113 (Ct. App. 1988).Â  â€œGenerally, alimony should place the supported spouse, as nearly as is practical, in the same position he or she enjoyed during the marriage.â€Â  Allen v. Allen, 347 S.C. 177, 184, 554 S.E.2d 421, 424 (Ct. App. 2001).Â  â€œIt is the duty of the family court to make an alimony award that is fit, equitable, and just if the claim is well founded.â€Â  Id. at 184, 554 S.E.2d at 424.Â  The family court judge may grant alimony in an amount and for a term as the judge considers appropriate under the circumstances. S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 20-3-130(A) (Supp. 2004).
Factors to be considered in making an alimony award include:Â  (1) duration of the marriage; (2) physical and emotional health of the parties; (3) educational background of the parties; (4) employment history and earning potential of the parties; (5) standard of living established during the marriage; (6) current and reasonably anticipated earnings of the parties; (7) current and reasonably anticipated expenses of the parties; (8) marital and nonmarital properties of the parties; (9) custody of children; (10) marital misconduct or fault; (11) tax consequences; and (12) prior support obligations; as well as (13) other factors the court considers relevant.Â  S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 20-3-130(C) (Supp. 2004).Â  The court is required to consider all relevant factors in determining alimony.Â  Epperly v. Epperly, 312 S.C. 411, 415, 440 S.E.2d 884, 886 (Ct. App. 1994).Â  No one factor is dispositive.Â  Lide v. Lide, 277 S.C. 155, 157, 283 S.E.2d 832, 833 (1981).
A.Â Â Wifeâ€™s Testimony
Husband contends Wifeâ€™s testimony established that she sought rehabilitative alimony of only $750 per month for ten years.Â  He claims because this type of alimony was not requested in her complaint, she should be barred from receiving any alimony.Â  In the alternative, he contends the family court erred in awarding her $750 per month as permanent periodic alimony given her testimony.Â  We disagree.
â€œAlthough rehabilitative alimony may be an appropriate form of spousal support in some cases, permanent periodic alimony is favored in South Carolina.â€Â  Jenkins v. Jenkins, 345 S.C. 88, 95, 545 S.E.2d 531, 535 (Ct. App. 2001).Â  â€œRehabilitative alimony may be awarded only upon a showing of special circumstances justifying a departure from the normal preference for permanent periodic support.Â  The purpose of rehabilitative alimony is to encourage a dependent spouse to become self-supporting after a divorce.â€Â  Id. 
Additionally, â€œ[t]he appellate courts of this state have said many times that ordinarily a party may not receive relief not contemplated in his pleadings.â€Â  Loftis v. Loftis, 286 S.C. 12, 13-14, 331 S.E.2d 372, 373 (Ct. App. 1985) (citing Gainey v. Gainey, 279 S.C. 68, 301 S.E.2d 763 (1983);Â  Ingram v. Ingram, 273 S.C. 113, 254 S.E.2d 680 (1979); Bass v. Bass, 272 S.C. 177, 249 S.E.2d 905 (1978); Bolding v. Bolding, 283 S.C. 501, 323 S.E.2d 535 (Ct. App. 1984); Bryan v. Bryan, 282 S.C. 506, 319 S.E.2d 360 (Ct. App. 1984)).Â  â€œDue process requires that a litigant be placed on notice of the issues which the court is to consider.â€Â  Richardson v. Richardson, 309 S.C. 31, 35, 419 S.E.2d 806, 808 (Ct. App. 1992).
Wifeâ€™s pleadings made a request for the court to â€œrequire the Defendant both pendente lite and permanently, to pay a reasonable amount of permanent periodic support to Plaintiff . . . or, in the alternative, for payment of a lump sum based upon the Defendantâ€™s substantial estate.â€Â  Later in her complaint she again requested either permanent periodic or lump sum alimony, but never did she specifically request rehabilitative alimony.Â  Her complaint also asked the court to grant â€œsuch other and further relief as [the family court] may deem just and appropriate.â€ 
During her trial testimony, Wife was asked:Â  â€œMrs. Hunnicutt, do you think that the Court should award you alimony?â€Â  She replied:Â  â€œYes, sir.â€Â  She was then asked:Â  â€œAnd do you have an amount that you think would be fair and appropriate?â€Â  She responded:Â  â€œ$750 a month for ten years.â€Â  In explaining her answer she stated:Â  â€œLooking at my salary and what I can make and what [Husbandâ€™s] salary is and what he can make, I felt like that would be a fair price.â€ 
Husband made a motion for an involuntary dismissal of Wifeâ€™s cause of action for alimony, arguing her testimony did not support a type of alimony requested in her complaint. Â The court denied the motion, and ultimately awarded Wife $750 a month in permanent periodic alimony.Â  The court noted:Â  â€œThis court found [Wife] to be in the $1000.00 per month category, but awarded $750.00 because that is what [Wife] asked for. . . . Court finds it does not have the authority to cap this amount or to impose a time limit, therefore, this award is a permanent periodic alimony.Â  There were no facts for rehabilitative alimony.â€Â  
While Wifeâ€™s request in her testimony appears to ask for rehabilitative alimony, it was merely a suggestion of an amount she felt was fair.Â  She clearly believed Husband had more income and should have to contribute to her standard of living.Â  Her explanation indicates she felt the alimony should continue as long as there was a difference in the incomes of the parties.Â  Additionally, there was no case presented to support a claim of rehabilitative alimony.Â  Finally, Husband was well aware of Wifeâ€™s request for permanent periodic alimony as it was properly requested in her complaint.
The family court judge may grant alimony in an amount and for a term as the judge considers appropriate under the circumstances. S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 20-3-130(A) (Supp. 2004).Â  Under the circumstances of this case, it was not error for the judge to award permanent periodic alimony when it was requested in Wifeâ€™s complaint, Wifeâ€™s testimony was suggestive of rehabilitative or periodic alimony, and there was clearly no case made for rehabilitative alimony. Â Accordingly, we find the court did not abuse its discretion in awarding permanent periodic alimony to Wife or in denying Husbandâ€™s motion for an involuntary nonsuit on the issue of alimony.
B.Â Â Â Daughterâ€™s Expenses
Husband maintains Wifeâ€™s financial declarations include numerous expenses attributable to the partiesâ€™ daughter who is attending college.Â  He asserts the financial declaration was inherently unreliable and any remaining expenses do not justify an award of alimony.Â  We disagree.
First, most of Husbandâ€™s claims are not preserved for review on appeal.Â  In his motion for reconsideration after the court specifically excluded some items on Wifeâ€™s financial declaration and set the amount of alimony, Husband did not request the court recalculate the amount based on additional items belonging to the daughter and not Wife.Â  He never raised the issue of additional school expenses being included in the calculation of the amount of alimony.Â  Accordingly, the issue is not preserved for review on appeal.Â  See Widman v. Widman, 348 S.C. 97, 119, 557 S.E.2d 693, 704 (Ct. App. 2001) (holding issue cannot be raised for the first time on appeal, but must have been raised to and ruled upon by the trial judge to be preserved for appellate review).Â Â  
Husbandâ€™s claim would also fail on the merits.Â  The family court specifically stated:Â  â€œThis Court is not awarding any college expenses of the daughter to [Wife], to be paid by [Husband]. . . . In [Wifeâ€™s] Financial Declaration, the rent expense of $348.00 per month and the school expense of $950.00 per month are school expenses of Blair, and have not been considered.â€Â  The court went on to examine all of the relevant factors under section 20-3-130(C).
The court properly considered the relevant factors and made very detailed findings of fact regarding the required factors.Â  The court found Wifeâ€™s expenses were about $1000 more than her income and that Husband had the ability to pay in order to maintain Wifeâ€™s standard of living.Â  We find no abuse of discretion in the courtâ€™s determination that Wife was entitled to $750 per month in alimony, even if some of the expenses questioned by Husband are removed.
C.Â Â Imputation of Income
Husband asserts the trial court erred in imputing income in the range of $90-120,000 per year to him when his financial declaration indicated he was earning approximately $73,000 and there was no evidence to show he could have been making additional income.Â  Although we agree with this assertion, we find it would not change the award of alimony.
It is well settled in South Carolina that an award of alimony should be based on the payor spouseâ€™s earning potential rather than merely his current, reported earnings.Â  See S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 20-3-130(C)(4) & -130(C)(6) (Supp. 2004) (requiring the family court to consider â€œthe employment history and earning potential of each spouseâ€ and â€œthe current and reasonably anticipated earnings of both spousesâ€ when awarding alimony).Â  Accordingly, a spouse obligated to pay alimony may not voluntarily or intentionally change his employment or economic circumstances so as to curtail his income and thereby avoid paying alimony or child support.Â  See Camp v. Camp, 269 S.C. 173, 174, 236 S.E.2d 814, 815 (1977) (affirming family courtâ€™s decision ordering Husband/Father to continue paying alimony and child support at the same amount he agreed to pay prior to his voluntary change in employment which resulted in a reduced income).Â  
Given the principle of imputation of income for the purpose of spousal support is analogous to that of child support, we are instructed by case law involving child support.Â  Where a parent voluntarily lessens his or her earning capacity, this court will closely scrutinize the facts to determine the parentâ€™s earning potential, rather than the parentâ€™s actual income.Â  Camp, 269 S.C. at 174, 236 S.E.2d at 815; Robinson v. Tyson, 319 S.C. 360, 363, 461 S.E.2d 397, 399 (Ct. App. 1995); see Chastain v. Chastain, 289 S.C. 281, 283, 346 S.E.2d 33, 35 (Ct. App. 1986) (finding that father with masterâ€™s degree voluntarily removed himself from the job market to attend law school and his earning potential was properly considered in calculating child support).Â  The failure by a parent to reach full earning capacity, by itself, does not automatically equate to voluntary underemployment such that income must be imputed.Â  See Kelley v. Kelley, 324 S.C. 481, 488-89, 477 S.E.2d 727, 731 (Ct. App. 1996) (â€œ[I]ncreased or decreased income, without more, is insufficient to warrant a change in circumstances; the failure to reach earning capacity, by itself, does not automatically equate to voluntary underemployment such that income must be imputed.â€)(citations omitted).Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â  
The family court found Husband was terminated from his employment with Springs where he earned â€œover $9,000.00 per month.â€ Â Additionally, the court found he was self-employed, earning $73,424.90 in his first year in sales.Â  While the amount he was earning as a sales representative for ViPac was less than the amount he earned at Springs, there was no evidence presented indicating he could have found a similar position to the one at Springs or intentionally forfeited income in order to avoid paying alimony.Â  Additionally, the only indication that his earning potential was in the range of $90-120,000 was from Wife, who testified Husband told her he could build up the job to make $90-110,000.Â  This is insufficient evidence to support a finding Husband was underemployed and should have additional income imputed to him in order to calculate alimony.
Notwithstanding our finding that the court improperly imputed additional income, the amount of the alimony awarded is not excessive and need not be altered.Â  As discussed above, the court properly considered all relevant factors including the length of the marriage, Husbandâ€™s fault in the divorce, the income differential, and the partiesâ€™ standard of living.Â  Even considering the new income differential, it clearly does not outweigh the other factors, which suggested the award was proper. Â Accordingly, we reverse the courtâ€™s order so far as it imputed income to Husband, but affirm the award of alimony because the imputation did not result in an excess award.
II.Â Â Wifeâ€™s Retirement Account
Husband contends the family court erred in its valuation of Wifeâ€™s retirement account.Â  He asserts the court improperly valued her State Retirement Plan as a defined contribution plan instead of as a defined benefits plan.Â  However, these arguments were not presented to the family court in Husbandâ€™s motion to reconsider, alter or amend.Â  Accordingly, the issues are not preserved for our review on appeal.Â  Widman v. Widman, 348 S.C. 97, 119, 557 S.E.2d 693, 704 (Ct. App. 2001) (holding issue cannot be raised for the first time on appeal, but must have been raised to and ruled upon by the trial judge to be preserved for appellate review); see also Wilder Corp. v. Wilke, 330 S.C. 71, 76, 497 S.E.2d 731, 733 (1998) (â€œIt is axiomatic that an issue cannot be raised for the first time on appeal, but must have been raised to and ruled upon by the trial judge to be preserved for appellate review.â€). 
III.Â Â Equitable Distribution
Husband contends the family court erred in its equitable distribution by improperly including his severance pay and the down payment on his condominium in the marital estate.Â  He also contends the court erred by not including money used by Wife which was received from a partnership that included Wife and Husband.Â  He maintains the court erred in not including in the marital estate proceeds from the sale of the family home that Husband alleges Wife dissipated prior to the final order.Â  Finally, he asserts the court erred in its division of the coupleâ€™s credit card debt.Â  
 The apportionment of marital property is within the discretion of the family court judge and will not be disturbed on appeal absent an abuse of discretion.Â  Morris v. Morris, 295 S.C. 37, 39, 367 S.E.2d 24, 25 (1988).Â  Section 20-7-472 of the South Carolina Code provides the family court must consider fifteen factors and give each weight as it determines.Â  S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 20-7-472 (Supp. 2004).Â  On review, this court looks to the fairness of the overall apportionment, and if the end result is equitable, the fact that this court might have weighed specific factors differently than the family court is irrelevant.Â  Johnson v. Johnson, 296 S.C. 289, 300-01, 372 S.E.2d 107, 113 (Ct. App. 1988); see Doe v. Doe, 324 S.C. 492, 502, 478 S.E.2d 854, 859 (Ct. App. 1996) (stating the reviewing court will affirm the family court judgeâ€™s apportionment of marital property if it can be determined that the judge addressed the relevant factors under section 20-7-472 with sufficiency for the reviewing court to conclude the judge was cognizant of the statutory factors).
A.Â Â Severance Pay
Husband contends the family court erred by including his six months severance pay as part of the marital estate.Â  We disagree.
Section 20-7-473 of the South Carolina Code defines marital property as â€œall real and personal property which has been acquired by the parties during the marriage and which is owned as of the date of filing or commencement of marital litigation as provided in Â§ 20-7-472 regardless of how legal title is held.â€Â  S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 20-7-473 (Supp. 2004).Â  This court recently addressed severance pay in Bowman v. Bowman, 357 S.C. 146, 158, 591 S.E.2d 654, 660 (Ct. App. 2004):

  [W]e adhere to South Carolinaâ€™s sound and established approach of scrutinizing the true nature and purpose of the benefit.Â  See, e.g., Mears v. Mears, 305 S.C. 150, 156, 406 S.E.2d 376, 380 (Ct. App. 1991), overruled on other grounds by Marsh v. Marsh, 313 S.C. 42, 437 S.E.2d 34 (1993) (concluding proper classification of employment termination benefits as marital or nonmarital property â€œdepends on the purpose of the paymentsâ€); Mallett v. Mallett, 323 S.C. 141, 152, 473 S.E.2d 804, 810 (Ct. App. 1996) (holding property classified as nonmarital because the â€œpurposeâ€ of the benefit was to replace earnings after the date commencement of marital litigation); Fisher v. Fisher, 319 S.C. 500, 504, 462 S.E.2d 303, 305 (Ct. App. 1995) (finding benefits paid pursuant to a â€œvoluntary separation incentiveâ€ were analogous to an â€œearly retirement,â€ and the payments were thus deemed marital property â€œunder the facts of this caseâ€); Tinsley v. Tinsley, 326 S.C. 374, 381-82, 483 S.E.2d 198, 202 (Ct. App. 1997) (holding disability benefits were not marital property since the â€œpayments are a replacement for income he would be earning currently and would be able to earn in the future had he not become disabledâ€).Â  Thus, classification of property as marital or nonmarital must be determined in light of the true nature and purpose of the benefit.Â  South Carolina does not classify property as marital or nonmarital based on the title or nomenclature assigned by a party.

In the instant case, the contract between Husband and Springs involving the six months severance pay clearly indicated it was given to Husband in exchange for his agreement â€œto release Springs from any and all claims, suits, demands, or other causes of action of any kind . . . [Husband] might have against Springs . . . .â€Â  Accordingly, the family court did not err in including the pay received prior to filing of marital litigation in the marital estate to be divided amongst the parties.
B.Â Â KKB Partnership
Husband maintains two payments received from the KKB Partnership were used solely by Wife and should have been included in the marital estate of the parties due to Husband not receiving the benefit of the payment.Â  We agree in part.
Initially, we note Husband only contested the family courtâ€™s failure to include one payment of $3,000 in the marital estate and not the two payments he addresses on appeal.Â  Accordingly, we need only address the issue of the payment that was raised to the family court for its consideration as the issue regarding the other payment is not preserved for our review on appeal.Â  See Widman v. Widman, 348 S.C. 97, 119, 557 S.E.2d 693, 704 (Ct. App. 2001) (holding issue cannot be raised for the first time on appeal, but must have been raised to and ruled upon by the trial judge to be preserved for appellate review).
â€œWe continue to recognize and respect the broad discretion accorded to family court judges in the fact-sensitive inquiries surrounding the identification of marital and nonmarital property as well as the determination of the equitable distribution of the marital estate.â€Â  Bowman v. Bowman, 357 S.C. 146, 156, 591 S.E.2d 654, 659 (Ct. App. 2004).Â  
The family court specifically found Wife received the $3,000 payment from the real estate partnership, which included both parties as well as other family members.Â  The court further found Wife spent the money on tuition for the daughter in college.Â  Uncontroverted testimony presented at trial indicated the amount received from the partnership was given every year to the daughter for use in paying her college expenses.
Because the contested payment was received prior to the filing of this litigation, we hold the trial court erred in declining to find it constituted marital property.Â  However, we find no reversible error given the payment had already been disposed of and, thus, was not available for equitable distribution.Â  Moreover, we note Husband never objected to Wifeâ€™s use of the KKB partnership payment to pay for the daughterâ€™s tuition nor did Husband express a desired intent to seek reimbursement for these payments.
C.Â Simpsonville Home
Husband contends Wife dissipated the proceeds received from the sale of their Simpsonville home shortly before the filing for divorce.Â  We disagree.
Initially, we question whether this issue is preserved for review on appeal given it was not specifically raised to the trial court in Husbandâ€™s motion for reconsideration and was never addressed by the family court.Â  See Widman v. Widman, 348 S.C. 97, 119, 557 S.E.2d 693, 704 (Ct. App. 2001) (holding issue cannot be raised for the first time on appeal, but must have been raised to and ruled upon by the trial judge to be preserved for appellate review).Â  However, to the extent it was briefly discussed during the hearing on Husbandâ€™s motion to reconsider, we have decided to address the merits. 
Subject to certain exceptions, â€œmarital propertyâ€ includes â€œall real and personal property which has been acquired by the parties during the marriage and which is owned as of the date of filing or commencement of marital litigation.â€Â  S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 20-7-473 (Supp. 2004).Â  Thus, for purposes of equitable distribution, the value of marital property is the value of the property at the time of the commencement of the marital litigation.Â  See Mallett v. Mallett, 323 S.C. 141, 151, 473 S.E.2d 804, 810 (Ct. App. 1996) (â€œMarital property is valued as of the date of the filing of the complaint.â€).Â  Our supreme court has noted:Â  â€œthere must be some evidence of willful misconduct, bad faith, intention to dissipate marital assets, or the like, before a court may alter the equitable distribution award for such misconduct.â€Â  McDavid v. McDavid, 333 S.C. 490, 496, 511 S.E.2d 365, 368 (1999).Â  
Wife was given $30,000 of the $70,000 in proceeds from the sale of the Simpsonville home.Â  Half was used to repay part of a debt owed to her father, with the remainder being spent by Wife for investigators, attorneys, tuition for the partiesâ€™ daughter, and a storage building.Â  Husband stated he believed she would use the entire $30,000 to pay off the debt to her father and because she did not do so, the $15,000 spent on other items should count against her portion of the estate.Â  Her expenses were not made with the intent of dissipating the martial assets so as to require a change in the equitable distribution.Â  Additionally, we note Husband does not appear any better able to document his expense of the $40,000 than Wife can explain the full expenses paid out of her $30,000 share.Â  Although Wife testified Husband paid off a second line of credit with the $40,000, there is no documentation as to what expenses constituted the significant increase in this debt.Â  Accordingly, the family court did not err in failing to count at least $15,000 against Wifeâ€™s equitable distribution.
D.Â Â Condominium Down Payment
Husband contends $7,000.00 used as a down payment on his condominium was part of his severance pay and, therefore, should not have been included in the marital estate.Â  We disagree.
Subject to certain exceptions, â€œmarital propertyâ€ includes â€œall real and personal property which has been acquired by the parties during the marriage and which is owned as of the date of filing or commencement of marital litigation.â€Â  S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 20-7-473 (Supp. 2004).Â  As discussed above, the severance agreement provided for the payment of funds to Husband, which are marital assets due to their nature as compensation for a release of claims and not as payment of future earnings.Â  The agreement also included a provision allowing for the payment of up to $7,000 for relocation expenses.Â  While it appears Husband did not actually receive the check until after marital litigation was commenced, it is clear the benefit was received at the time the agreement was signed.Â  Thus, the value of the down payment later paid by Husband should be considered a marital asset as the right to repayment was in existence prior to filing of marital litigation.
E.Â Â Credit Card Debt
Husband contends the family court erred in requiring him to pay the full amount of the Visa credit card debt because it was in his name, even though both parties used the card prior to the filing of marital litigation.Â  We agree.
Pursuant to section 20-7-472(13) of the South Carolina Code, the family court is required to give consideration to the marital debts of the parties when making its equitable distribution of marital property.Â  S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 20-7-472(13) (Supp. 2004).Â  â€œDebts incurred for marital purposes are subject to equitable distribution.â€Â  Jenkins v. Jenkins, 345 S.C. 88, 103, 545 S.E.2d 531, 539 (Ct. App. 2001).Â  Section 20-7-472 creates a rebuttable presumption that a debt of either spouse incurred prior to marital litigation is a marital debt, and must be factored into the totality of equitable apportionment.Â  Hickum v. Hickum, 320 S.C. 97, 102, 463 S.E.2d 321, 324 (Ct. App. 1995).
Marital debt, like marital property, must be specifically identified and apportioned in equitable distribution.Â  Smith v. Smith, 327 S.C. 448, 457, 486 S.E.2d 516, 520 (Ct. App. 1997) (holding section 20-7-472 implicitly requires that marital debt, like marital property, be specifically identified and apportioned in the equitable distribution).Â  The same rules of fairness and equity that apply to the equitable division of marital property also apply to the division of marital debts.Â  Hardy v. Hardy, 311 S.C. 433, 437, 429 S.E.2d 811, 813-14 (Ct. App. 1993).Â  Â Â Â Â Â Â Â  
In the instant case, the family court recognized the parties had marital credit card debt.Â  However, due to the confusion created by the partiesâ€™ financial declarations the court simply ordered that each side be responsible for the debt on their own financial declaration.Â  It appears this places the full burden of the partiesâ€™ Visa credit card bill upon Husband.Â  We find this result is not equitable given the evidence in the record.
Husbandâ€™s first financial declaration included a Visa credit card with a balance of $10,708.Â  In his second financial declaration, he lists the balance as $20,000 but admitted the increase was nonmarital.Â  Wifeâ€™s first and second financial declaration listed a Visa credit card with a balance of $12,508.28.Â  However, at trial, she indicated the only Visa credit card she was aware of had a balance of about $2,000. 
Based on the evidence in the record, we find the Visa card listed on each partyâ€™s financial declaration is a marital debt.Â  Accordingly, we find the balance remaining at the time of the filing of marital litigation should be divided equally between the parties.Â  Therefore, we modify the family courtâ€™s order to require that each party be responsible for one-half of the $10,708 balance listed on Husbandâ€™s financial declaration.Â  Any increase in the balance above that amount will be the responsibility of Husband.
IV.Â Â Â  Attorneyâ€™s Fees
Husband contends the family court erred in its award of attorneyâ€™s fees to Wife.Â  We disagree.
An award of attorneyâ€™s fees lies within the sound discretion of the family court and will not be disturbed on appeal absent an abuse of discretion.Â  Bowen v. Bowen, 327 S.C. 561, 563, 490 S.E.2d 271, 272 (Ct. App. 1997).Â  The family court, in determining whether to award attorneyâ€™s fees, should consider each partyâ€™s ability to pay his or her own fees, the beneficial results obtained, the partiesâ€™ respective financial conditions, and the effect of the fee on the partiesâ€™ standard of living.Â  E.D.M. v. T.A.M., 307 S.C. 471, 476-77, 415 S.E.2d 812, 816 (1992).Â  In determining the reasonable amount of attorneyâ€™s fees to award, the court should consider the nature, extent, and difficulty of the services rendered, the time necessarily devoted to the case, counselâ€™s professional standing, the contingency of compensation, the beneficial results obtained, and the customary legal fees for similar services.Â  Glasscock v. Glasscock, 304 S.C. 158, 161, 403 S.E.2d 313, 315 (1991).
The family court clearly considered the relevant factors in making an award of attorneyâ€™s fees and in setting the amount.Â  The court considered the beneficial results obtained by Wife, the fault of the Husband in the divorce, and the financial situation of the parties. While our reversal of the imputation of income could affect the family courtâ€™s determination of Husbandâ€™s superior financial position, we believe Wife is nonetheless entitled to attorneyâ€™s fees based upon our review of the record.Â  
Additionally, the court did not err in the amount of the attorneyâ€™s fees as Wife was awarded only a portion of her outstanding attorneyâ€™s fees.Â  Even though Wife paid a small portion of her fees using marital money, the court did not award her an unreasonable amount given the Glasscock factors, even if the amount she previously paid was added to the award.Â  Accordingly, we find the court did not abuse its discretion in awarding Wife $10,000.00 in attorneyâ€™s fees.Â  
Furthermore, to the extent Husband asserts the court erred in denying his request for a Qualified Domestic Relations Order[2] for the payment of the award of attorneyâ€™s fees, we find Husband abandoned this issue given his argument consists of two sentences without any citation to authority. See First Sav. Bank v. McLean, 314 S.C. 361, 363, 444 S.E.2d 513, 514 (1994) (noting that where a party fails to cite any supporting authority or where the argument is merely a conclusory statement, the issue is deemed abandoned on appeal); R & G Constr., Inc. v. Lowcountry Regâ€™l Transp. Auth., 343 S.C. 424, 437, 540 S.E.2d 113, 120 (Ct. App. 2000) (deeming an issue abandoned if the appellantâ€™s brief treats it in a conclusory manner).Â  
CONCLUSION
We find the family court did not err in awarding Wife permanent periodic alimony, notwithstanding her testimony that she desired a certain amount for a fixed time period.Â  We conclude the amount of the alimony was proper and did not give Wife credit for expenses related to her daughterâ€™s schooling.Â  We reverse the family courtâ€™s imputation of income to Husband, but find the amount of alimony awarded should not be altered.
Many of the issues regarding the division of the marital estate were not properly preserved for review on appeal, including the valuation of the Wifeâ€™s retirement account.Â  On the merits, we conclude the family court properly divided the marital estate with the exception of the credit card debt.Â  The court properly included the amount of Husbandâ€™s severance agreement with Springs and the down payment on his condominium in marital property.Â  In terms of the KKB partnership payment, we find the court erred in declining to find it constituted marital property.Â  However, we find no reversible error given the payment had already been disposed of in paying for daughterâ€™s tuition.Â  We find the Wife did not dissipate income from the sale of the Simpsonville home.Â  Finally, we find the court erred in its division of the credit card debt and allocate that debt consistent with the instructions in this opinion.Â  We find the court properly awarded Wife attorneyâ€™s fees after considering all relevant factors.Â  
Accordingly, the decision of the family court is
AFFIRMED IN PART, REVERSED IN PART, AND MODIFIED IN PART.
HEARN, C.J., and HUFF and BEATTY, JJ., concur.

[1]Â Â  Because oral argument would not aid the court in resolving the issues on appeal, we decide this case without oral argument pursuant to Rule 215, SCACR.
[2]Â Â  Section 9-18-10(9) defines â€œQualified domestic relations orderâ€ as follows:

  â€œQualified domestic relations orderâ€ means a domestic relations order which creates or recognizes the existence of an alternate payeeâ€™s right, or assigns to an alternate payee the right, to receive all or a portion of a benefit payable with respect to a member or retired member under a retirement system, which directs that retirement system to disburse benefits to the alternate payee, and which meets the requirements of this chapter. 

S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 9-18-10(9) (Supp. 2004).Â  Section 9-18-20 further explains:

  A qualified domestic relations order may order that all or any part of any (1) retirement benefit, (2) withdrawal or refund of contributions, (3) disability benefit, or (4) death benefit that becomes payable under the retirement system on account of the member or retired member, instead be paid by the system to the alternate payee.Â  

S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 9-18-20(A) (Supp. 2004) (Emphasis added); Smith v. S.C. Retirement Sys., 336 S.C. 505, 514, 520 S.E.2d 339, 344 (Ct. App. 1999).
