THIS OPINION HAS NO PRECEDENTIAL VALUE.Â  IT SHOULD NOT BE CITED OR RELIED ON AS PRECEDENT IN ANY PROCEEDING EXCEPT AS PROVIDED BY RULE 239(d)(2), SCACR.
THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Court of Appeals


  
    
      
        The State, Respondent,
      
    
  

v.

  
    
      
        Kaye Blackwell, Appellant.
      
    
  


Appeal From Cherokee County
Â J. Michael Baxley, Circuit Court Judge

Unpublished Opinion No. 2006-UP-025
Heard January 10, 2006 â€“ Filed January 12, 2006

AFFIRMED


      
        
          
            Acting Chief Attorney Joseph L. Savitz, III, of Columbia, for Appellant.
            Attorney General Henry Dargan McMaster, Chief Deputy Attorney General John W. McIntosh, Assistant Deputy Attorney General Salley W. Elliott, Senior Assistant Attorney General Norman Mark Rapoport, all of Columbia; and Solicitor Harold W. Gowdy, III, of Spartanburg, for Respondent.
          
        
      
    
    PER CURIAM:Â  Kaye Blackwell appeals from her conviction for possession of methamphetamine, arguing the trial judge erred by allowing the primary arresting officer to testify that Blackwell told him she was not willing to cooperate with the police.Â  We affirm.
    FACTS
    On May 5, 2003, officers executed a search warrant for Blackwellâ€™s residence.Â  When police entered the trailer, they found Blackwell in the bathroom, standing over the toilet.Â  The toilet had just been flushed and an officer retrieved several bags of methamphetamine from the swirling water.Â  To get to the toilet, the officer pushed Blackwell into the bathtub.Â  After obtaining the bags, the officer helped Blackwell out of the tub.Â  At that time, the officer found a white pill bottle laying in the tub.Â  When the officer later opened the bottle, he discovered that it contained various glassine baggies.Â  Of the bags tested, the bags combined contained a total of .31 grams of methamphetamine.Â  Blackwell initially told the officers the drugs were for her personal use; however, she later stated they belonged to an unidentified male, who was found in the living room of the trailer.Â  On June 22 and 23, 2004, Blackwell was tried for possession of methamphetamine with intent to distribute.Â  The jury found Blackwell guilty of possession of methamphetamine.Â  The judge sentenced her to five years imprisonment, fined her $5,000, and ordered her to undergo treatment for substance abuse.Â  Blackwell now appeals.Â Â Â Â Â  
    LAW/ANALYSIS
Blackwell argues the trial judge erred by allowing the primary arresting officer to testify that Blackwell told him she was not willing to cooperate with the police because the testimony was inadmissible and unfairly prejudicial.Â  We disagree.
In criminal cases, an appellate court reviews errors of law only.Â  State v. Wilson, 345 S.C. 1, 5, 545 S.E.2d 827, 829 (2001).Â  â€œA courtâ€™s ruling on the admissibility of evidence will not be reversed on appeal absent an abuse of discretion or the commission of legal error that results in prejudice to the defendant.â€Â  State v. Adams, 354 S.C. 361, 377, 580 S.E.2d 785, 793 (Ct. App. 2003).Â  â€œA trial judgeâ€™s decision regarding the comparative probative value and prejudicial effect of evidence should be reversed only in â€˜exceptional circumstances.â€™â€ Â State v. Hamilton, 344 S.C. 344, 357, 543 S.E.2d 586, 593 (Ct. App. 2001).
Error in criminal prosecution is harmless error when it could not reasonably have affected the result of the trial.Â  State v. Mitchell, 286 S.C. 572, 573, 336 S.E.2d 150, 151 (1985).Â  In this case, there was abundant evidence in the record from which the jury could have found Blackwell guilty, notwithstanding the officerâ€™s testimony.Â  Blackwell was found in her home, standing over a toilet that contained several bags of methamphetamines.Â  See State v. Hudson, 277 S.C. 200, 203, 284 S.E.2d 773, 775 (1981) (holding that where an officer retrieved three cellophane bags containing white powder from the toilet before they could be flushed away, there was sufficient evidence from which a reasonable trier of fact could conclude beyond a reasonable doubt that appellant constructively possessed heroin with intent to distribute); State v. Bowers, 301 S.C. 457, 461, 392 S.E.2d 482, 485 (Ct. App. 1990) (finding that where officials found a matchbox containing narcotics swirling in the toilet when they searched the home, there was substantial circumstantial evidence that reasonably tended to prove appellant had actual possession of the drugs immediately before the police entered the premises).Â  A pill bottle containing additional bags of methamphetamines was found in her bathtub after Blackwell was pulled out of the tub.Â  Additionally, Blackwell told the police that the drugs belonged to her.Â  Considering the overwhelming evidence of Blackwellâ€™s guilt, any possible error that resulted from the challenged testimony was harmless.Â  Furthermore, the reference to Blackwellâ€™s lack of willingness to cooperate was a single reference, which was never repeated or alluded to again at her trial.Â  See State v. Truesdale, 285 S.C. 13, 18-19, 328 S.E.2d 53, 56 (1984) (noting that a violation of Appellantâ€™s constitutional protection against self-incrimination constitutes harmless error if the reference to silence is a single reference; the single reference is not repeated or alluded to in either the trial or in jury argument; the prosecutor does not directly tie the defendantâ€™s silence to his exculpatory story; the exculpatory story is totally implausible, transparently frivolous; and the evidence of guilt is overwhelming).
AFFIRMED. 
GOOLSBY, ANDERSON, and SHORT, JJ., concur.

THIS OPINION HAS NO PRECEDENTIAL VALUE.  IT SHOULD NOT BE CITED OR RELIED ON AS PRECEDENT IN ANY PROCEEDING EXCEPT AS PROVIDED BY RULE 239(d)(2), SCACR.
THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Court of Appeals


  
    
      
        Deborah C. Head, Respondent,
      
    
  

v.

  
    
      
        Grant R. Head, Appellant.
      
    
  


Appeal From Sumter County
Â R. Wright Turbeville, Family Court Judge

Unpublished Opinion No. 2006-UP-026
Submitted January 1, 2006 â€“ Filed January 12, 2006

AFFIRMED


  
    
      
        Harry C. Wilson, Jr., of Sumter, for Appellant.
        Ryan A. McLeod, of Sumter, for Respondent.
      
    
  

PER CURIAM:Â  Grant R. Head (Husband) appeals the family courtâ€™s order finding him in contempt for failure to pay Deborah C. Head (Wife) alimony pursuant to a temporary order.Â  We affirm.
FACTS
On February 29, 2004, the family court issued a temporary order that required Husband to pay Wife alimony in the amount of $2,000 per month beginning on February 16, 2004.Â  The court also awarded Husband temporary possession of the marital home and held him responsible for all expenses related to the home.Â  Additionally, the court ordered Husband to continue the $450 monthly payments on the Wifeâ€™s vehicle.Â  Subsequently, Husband filed a motion for reconsideration pursuant to Rule 59(e) of the South Carolina Rules of Civil Procedure.Â  In his motion, Husband requested that the family court eliminate several of his financial obligations, particularly the order to pay alimony.Â  In the alternative, Husband requested the court reduce the amount of alimony.Â  After a hearing, the family court denied Husbandâ€™s motion.Â  
As a result of Husbandâ€™s failure to pay alimony for four months, Wife filed a Rule to Show Cause on May 13, 2004, seeking to hold Husband in contempt, requiring him to pay back alimony, and requesting attorneyâ€™s fees and costs.Â  After a hearing, the family court found Husband in contempt and sentenced him to an indeterminate period not to exceed six months incarceration unless he paid Wife $8,000 in back alimony and $1,585.08 in attorneyâ€™s fees.Â  According to Wife, Husband paid the entire amount in cash within two hours of the hearing.Â  Husband appeals.Â  
STANDARD OF REVIEW
A determination of contempt ordinarily resides in the sound discretion of the trial court.Â  Whetstone v. Whetstone, 309 S.C. 227, 233, 420 S.E.2d 877, 880-81 (Ct. App. 1992).Â  â€œThis court will reverse a trial courtâ€™s decision regarding contempt only if it is without evidentiary support or is an abuse of discretion.â€Â  First Union Natâ€™l Bank v. First Citizens Bank & Trust Co. of South Carolina, 346 S.C. 462, 466, 551 S.E.2d 301, 303 (Ct. App. 2001).Â  â€œAn abuse of discretion occurs either when the court is controlled by some error of law or where the order, based upon findings of fact, lacks evidentiary support.â€Â  Townsend v. Townsend, 356 S.C. 70, 73, 587 S.E.2d 118, 119 (Ct. App. 2003).
DISCUSSION
I.
Husband argues the family court erred in finding him in contempt.Â  We disagree.
â€œThe power to punish for contempt is inherent in all courts and is essential to the preservation of order in judicial proceedings.â€Â  In re Diggs, 344 S.C. 434, 434, 544 S.E.2d 632, 632 (2001).Â  A courtâ€™s contempt power arises when an individual willfully disobeys an order of the court.Â  Id.; S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 20-7-1350 (Supp. 2004) (A party may be found in contempt of court for the willful violation of a lawful court order.).Â  â€œA willful act is defined as one â€˜done voluntarily and intentionally with the specific intent to do something the law forbids, or with the specific intent to fail to do something the law requires to be done; that is to say, with bad purpose either to disobey or disregard the law.â€™â€Â  Spartanburg County Depâ€™t of Soc. Servs. v. Padgett, 296 S.C. 79, 82-83, 370 S.E.2d 872, 874 (1988) (quoting Blackâ€™s Law Dictionary 1434 (5th ed. 1979)).Â  â€œ[B]efore a court may find a person in contempt, the record must clearly and specifically reflect the contemptuous conduct.â€Â  Widman v. Widman, 348 S.C. 97, 119, 557 S.E.2d 693, 705 (Ct. App. 2001).Â  
â€œIn a proceeding for contempt for violation of a court order, the moving party must show the existence of a court order and the facts establishing the respondentâ€™s noncompliance with the order.â€Â  Hawkins v. Mullins, 359 S.C. 497, 501, 597 S.E.2d 897, 899 (Ct. App. 2004).Â  â€œOnce the moving party has made out a prima facie case, the burden then shifts to the respondent to establish his or her defense and inability to comply with the order.â€Â  Widman, 348 S.C. at 120, 557 S.E.2d at 705.
At the conclusion of the contempt hearing, the court explained that its ruling was based on the following findings:Â  (1) Husband had the ability to pay the $2,000 per month alimony but had refused to comply with his obligation because he disagreed with the amount set in the temporary order; (2) Husband chose to pay other bills and expenses rather than pay alimony; (3) Husband had the ability to pay given there was evidence that he received cash income and that his tree service business had made a profit for the years 2000 through 2003. 
Because there is evidence to support the courtâ€™s ruling, we find the court did not abuse its discretion in holding Husband in contempt.[1]Â Â Â  It is undisputed that Husband failed to pay Wife any alimony despite being ordered to do so.Â  Thus, the question becomes whether his failure to pay was willful.Â  
Husband acknowledges that he failed to comply with his alimony obligation; however, he contends his failure to do so was not willful given his financial situation.Â  He asserts he did not have the ability to pay the alimony because his other expenses exceeded his income.Â Â  Specifically, he claims his tree service business has not been profitable for the past few years and there is outstanding debt on the partiesâ€™ former photo business.Â  As a result of these business failures, Husband claims he has incurred significant credit card debt and has had to refinance the marital home and borrow money to reduce the business expenses.Â  Additionally, in mitigation, Husband points out that in order to avoid repossession of Wifeâ€™s vehicle he paid the balance of the loan in the amount of $5,800.
Although Husband testified regarding his financial difficulties involving his tree business, he confirmed Wifeâ€™s testimony that he has received cash payments for his work and that some of the payment checks were made out to him individually as opposed to the business.Â  He admitted that he had received a late-model Porsche as payment for his work.Â  Husband also acknowledged that he paid off the $5,800 balance on the Wifeâ€™s vehicle, which was more than the $3,000 that was required to avoid repossession.Â  He also testified that he made more than the minimum payments on his credit cards and has kept his utility and cable bills current.Â  Additionally, Husband admitted that he was current with his child support obligation from a previous marriage and, in fact, had on occasion paid more than the required amount.Â  Husband also acknowledged that since the temporary order was issued he has paid for the services of a private investigator in preparation for the final divorce hearing.Â  Finally, the question regarding whether Husbandâ€™s business was profitable based on his method of depreciating the business assets was a credibility determination for which we defer to the family court.Â  See Brown v. Malloy, 345 S.C. 113, 119, 546 S.E.2d 195, 198 (Ct. App. 2001) (deferring to family court where decision was dependent on credibility and family court saw the witnesses and heard the testimony).
II.
Husband argues the award of attorneyâ€™s fees to Wife should be reversed if this court finds the family court abused its discretion in finding Husband in contempt.Â  In light of our decision regarding the contempt finding, we also affirm the award of attorneyâ€™s fees and costs to Wife as a contempt sanction.Â  
Accordingly, the decision of the family court is
AFFIRMED.
 HEARN, C.J., and HUFF and BEATTY, JJ., concur.

[1]Â Â  Given this appeal is presented to us in the posture of a contempt action based on a temporary order, we express no opinion as to the final decree of divorce, particularly concerning the award of alimony.Â  We emphasize that our analysis is strictly confined to determining whether there is evidence to support the family courtâ€™s decision to hold Husband in contempt.

THIS OPINION HAS NO PRECEDENTIAL VALUE.Â  IT SHOULD NOT BE CITED OR RELIED ON AS PRECEDENT IN ANY PROCEEDING EXCEPT AS PROVIDED BY RULE 239(d)(2), SCACR.
THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In the Court of Appeals


  
    
      
        Sheila M. Costenbader, Appellant,
      
    
  

v.

  
    
      
        Glenn A. Costenbader, Respondent.
      
    
  


Appeal From Fairfield County
Â Walter B. Brown, Jr., Family Court Judge

Unpublished Opinion No. 2006-UP-027
Heard January 9, 2006 â€“ Filed January 12, 2006

AFFIRMED IN PART AND REVERSED IN PART


  
    
      
        Stephen C. Hucks, of Columbia, for Appellant,
        John S. Nichols and Walter H. Smith, of Columbia, for Respondent.
      
    
  

PER CURIAM:Â  In this domestic dispute, Sheila M. Costenbader (Wife) appeals the family court order granting her divorce from Glenn A. Costenbader (Husband).Â  We affirm in part and reverse in part. 
FACTS
On October 7, 1972, Wife and Husband married.Â  Thirty-one years later, on September 5, 2003, they divorced.Â  Wife and Husband began their marriage in Pennsylvania.Â  In 1987, they moved to Winnsboro, South Carolina, where Wife worked at an Advanced Auto Parts store and Husband worked at a Mack Truck plant.Â  In the Fall of 2001, Husband discovered the Mack Truck plant was closing.Â  
Earlier that year, on February 7, 2001, Wife sought a divorce based on Husbandâ€™s infidelity and intoxication.Â  Wife claimed, and Husband admitted, Husband committed adultery multiple times during their marriage.Â  Wife alleged Husband would frequent a local bar called Grizzly Jacks each day after work.Â  She complained of his excessive drinking at the bar as well as his corresponding absence from the marital home.Â  
The family court granted Wifeâ€™s divorce based on Husbandâ€™s adultery.Â  Initially, the family court granted Wife alimony of $500 per month; however, the court reconsidered and denied this award because it found Husbandâ€™s marital misconduct did not affect the economic circumstances of the parties.Â  The court concluded the Jackson Creek Road property, which Husband purchased with money he inherited from his parents, was nonmarital property.[1]Â  The court apportioned the marital estate 50/50.Â  Finally, the court granted Wife attorneyâ€™s fees of $2,000, the amount of the initial retainer, although Wife requested $5,500.Â  
Presently, Wife works as a rural mail carrier.Â  She makes between $35,000 and $40,000 a year, less expenses for the upkeep of her vehicle.Â  Husband has been unemployed since 2002.Â  Wife and Husband had three children during the marriage, all of whom have reached the age of majority.Â  
ISSUES

  
    I. 
    Whether the family court erred in denying alimony previously awarded to Wife.
  
  
    II.
    Whether the family court erred in concluding the Jackson Creek Road property was not part of the marital estate. 
  
  
    III. 
    Whether the family court erred in apportioning the marital estate. 
  
  
    IV.
    Whether the family court erred in granting a divorce based solely on Husband’s adultery.
  
  
    V. 
    Whether the family court erred in awarding attorney’s fees of $2,000 rather than the $5,500 requested by Wife.      
  
  
    VI.
    Whether the family court erred in holding Wife in contempt. 
  
  
    VII.
    Whether the family court erred in granting Husband’s motion for reconsideration. 
  

STANDARD OF REVIEW
In an appeal from the family court, the appellate court may find facts in accordance with its own view of the preponderance of the evidence.Â  Dearybury v. Dearybury, 351 S.C. 278, 569 S.E.2d 367 (2002).Â  This broad scope of review does not require the appellate court to disregard the findings of the family court.Â  Bowers v. Bowers, 349 S.C. 85, 561 S.E.2d 610 (Ct. App. 2002).Â  Rather, the appellate court should be cognizant of the fact the family court was in a better position to evaluate the credibility of the witnesses and assign comparative weight to their testimony.Â  Holler v. Holler, 364 S.C. 256, 612 S.E.2d 469 (Ct. App. 2005).
LAW/ANALYSIS
I.Â Â Alimony 
Wife argues the family court erred in denying her alimony.Â  We agree.
The decision to grant or deny alimony is within the sound discretion of the family court and will not be disturbed absent an abuse of discretion.Â  Dearybury v. Dearybury, 351 S.C. 278, 282, 569 S.E.2d 367, 369 (2002).Â  An abuse of discretion transpires when the family court is controlled by an error of law or when the findings of fact are without evidentiary support.Â  Id.Â  Section 20-3-130(C) of the South Carolina Code (Supp. 2004) outlines thirteen factors the family court must consider and weigh when it determines an alimony award.Â  One of these factors is â€œmarital misconductâ€ that affects â€œthe economic circumstances of the parties.â€Â  S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 20-3-130(C)(10).Â  â€œNo one factor is dispositive.â€Â  Allen v. Allen, 347 S.C. 177, 184, 554 S.E.2d 421, 425 (Ct. App. 2001).Â  â€œAlimony is awarded as a substitute for support normally incident to a marital relationship and should place the supported spouse, as nearly as possible, in the same position he or she enjoyed during the marriage.â€Â  Roberson v. Roberson, 359 S.C. 384, 390-91, 597 S.E.2d 840, 843 (Ct. App. 2004). 
In this case, the family court terminated the $500 monthly alimony it initially granted to Wife, because it found Wife presented no evidence Husbandâ€™s marital misconduct affected the economic circumstances of the parties.Â  We find the record replete with evidence to the contrary and reverse the family court on this issue.Â  First, Husband admitted he had sex with three other women while married to Wife.Â  Second, Husband conceded to drinking until drunk, and admitted Wife picked him up from Grizzly Jacks multiple times as a result of his intoxication.Â  On such occasions, Wife would have to drive Husband back to Grizzly Jacks in the morning, so he could pick up his truck to drive to work.Â  
Wife testified Husband went to Grizzly Jacks just about every day after work, where he would spend hundreds of dollars each month on alcohol.Â  His absence from the marital home made it difficult for Wife to make marital decisions and raise their three children.Â  His intoxication lead to numerous arrests for driving under the influence, which lead to increased insurance rates.Â  Based on these facts, the family court initially awarded Wife $500 monthly alimony.Â  The family court later terminated this award for reasons not explained in the order nor manifested by the record.Â  Because we believe the record shows Husbandâ€™s marital conduct affected the economic circumstances of the parties, we find the family court erred in terminating the alimony it initially awarded Wife. 
Therefore, we find the $500 monthly alimony is proper to place Wife in the same position she enjoyed prior to this divorce action.Â  During the marriage, Husband made significantly more money than Wife.Â  Husband testified he contributed 75% of the marital income over the course of their marriage.Â  Moreover, Husbandâ€™s unemployment status is not entirely outside of his control.Â  When Husband heard about the plant closing in Winnsboro, he had the option of transferring to other plants, including plants in Georgia, Maryland, and Pennsylvania.Â  He only attempted to transfer to the Pennsylvania plant because he did not want to live where the other plants were located.Â  He was unable to obtain a transfer to the Pennsylvania plant, and has been unemployed since 2002.Â  We do not believe Husband incapable of finding employment, and in light of the purpose of alimony to place Wife in the same position she enjoyed during the marriage, we reinstate the $500 monthly alimony to Wife from Husband.Â  
II.Â Â Marital Property
Wife argues the family court erred in omitting the Jackson Creek Road real property from the marital estate.Â  We disagree. 

  The term â€œmarital propertyâ€ . . . means all real and personal property which has been acquired by the parties during the marriage and which is owned as of the date of filing or commencement of marital litigation as provided in Â§ 20-7-472 regardless of how legal title is held, except the following, which constitute nonmarital property:
  (1) property acquired by either party by inheritance, devise, bequest, or gift from a party other than the spouse;

S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 20-7-473 (Supp. 2004).Â  The burden of showing an exemption under section 20-7-473 is upon the party claiming the property acquired during the marriage is nonmarital.Â  Widman v. Widman, 348 S.C. 97, 557 S.E.2d 693 (Ct. App. 2001).Â  Nonmarital property can be transmuted into marital property if the property at issue is (1) so commingled with marital property as to be untraceable, (2) jointly titled, or (3) utilized by the parties in support of the marriage or in some other manner as to evidence an intent by the parties to make it marital property.Â  Greene v. Greene, 351 S.C. 329, 338, 569 S.E.2d 393, 398 (Ct. App. 2002).Â  The party claiming transmutation has the burden of showing the parties regarded the property at issue as marital property during the marriage.Â  Id.
Husband testified, and Wife did not dispute, the Jackson Road Property was acquired by inheritance.Â  Therefore, Husband showed this property was exempted under section 20-7-473, and should be considered nonmarital property.Â  Wife argues the Jackson Road Property should be transmuted because they treated it as marital property.Â  She claims she helped Husband move brush and burn trash on the property.Â  Husband claims the Jackson Road Property was not transmuted, and produced a deed showing the property was entitled to Husband only.Â  Based on these facts, Wife failed to carry the burden of showing the parties considered Jackson Road Property marital property.Â  See Johnson v. Johnson, 296 S.C. 289, 295-96, 372 S.E.2d 107, 111 (Ct. App. 1988) (â€œThe mere use of separate property to support the marriage, without some additional evidence of intent to treat it as property of the marriage, is not sufficient to establish transmutation.â€).
The family court correctly found the Jackson Road Property was not marital property, because Husband purchased it with inheritance money, nor transmuted property, because it was not commingled with marital property, titled solely to Husband, and not utilized in a way that evidenced an intent to make it marital property.Â Â  
III.Â Â Â Â  Equitable Division
Wife argues the family court erred in apportioning the marital property.Â  We disagree. 
â€œThe family courtâ€™s apportionment of marital property will not be disturbed on appeal absent an abuse of discretion.â€Â  Roberson, 359 S.C. at 389, 597 S.E.2d at 842-43.Â  â€œThe family court has wide discretion in determining how marital property is to be distributed.â€Â  Greene, 351 S.C. at 341, 569 S.E.2d at 400.Â  Section 20-7-472 of the South Carolina Code (Supp. 2004) outlines fifteen factors the family court should weigh when apportioning the marital property, and an appellate court will affirm the family court if it can be determined the family court addressed these factors. Roberson, 359 S.C. at 389, 597 S.E.2d at 843. 
The family court sufficiently addressed the factors outlined in section 20-7-472.Â  The family court considered the age of the parties, the marital misconduct of Husband, the value of the marital property, the income of each spouse, the health of each party, the Husbandâ€™s nonmarital property, alimony, and other relevant factors when it apportioned the marital property 50/50.Â  We find no abuse of discretion. Â Â 
IV.Â Â Â Â  Grounds for Divorce
Wife argues the family court erred in granting Wifeâ€™s divorce based solely on Husbandâ€™s adultery.Â  We disagree. 
Section 20-3-10 of the South Carolina Code (1985) provides that â€œ[n]o divorce from the bonds of matrimony shall be granted except upon one or more of the following grounds,â€ including â€œadulteryâ€ or â€œhabitual drunkenness . . . .â€ (emphasis added).Â  Nothing in section 20-3-10 mandates the family court must grant a divorce on all possible grounds listed: any one ground will suffice.Â  Because Husband admitted his adultery, the family court could, and did, grant a divorce on that ground alone.Â  We find Wifeâ€™s argument to be without merit.Â  
V.Â Â Â Â Â  Attorneyâ€™s Fees
Wife argues the family court erred in awarding attorneyâ€™s fees of $2,000 rather than the $5,500 Wife requested.Â  We disagree.Â Â Â Â Â  
â€œAn award of attorneyâ€™s fees lies within the sound discretion of the family court and will not be disturbed on appeal absent an abuse of discretion.â€Â  Roberson, 359 S.C. at 392, 597 S.E.2d at 844.Â  Section 20-3-120 of the South Carolina Code (1985) provides:

  In every divorce action from the bonds of matrimony either party may in his or her complaint or answer or by petition pray for the allowance to him or her of alimony and suit money and for the allowance of such alimony and suit money pendente lite.Â  If such claim shall appear well-founded the court shall allow a reasonable sum therefor.

In determining the amount of attorneyâ€™s fees to award, the family court should consider the following six factors: (1) the nature, extent, and difficulty of the case; (2) the time necessarily devoted to the case; (3) professional standing of counsel; (4) contingency of compensation; (5) beneficial results obtained; (6) customary legal fees for similar services.Â  Glasscock v. Glasscock, 304 S.C. 158, 161, 403 S.E.2d 313, 315 (1991). 
 In light of the fact Husband admitted his adultery from the outset of the case, Wifeâ€™s divorce action was fairly straightforward.Â  We find the family court did not abuse its discretion in awarding Wife $2,000 in attorneyâ€™s fees rather than $5,500.
Â VI.Â Â Â  Contempt
Wife argues the family court erred in holding Wife in contempt.Â  We disagree. 
The determination of contempt is within the sound discretion of the family court and will not be disturbed absent an abuse of discretion.Â  Smith v. Smith, 359 S.C. 393, 396, 597 S.E.2d 188, 189 (Ct. App. 2004).Â  Contempt results from the willful disobedience of a court order.Â  Id.Â  A willful act is one done voluntarily and intentionally with the specific intent not to do something the law requires to be done.Â  Id.Â  A party cannot be held in contempt for violating a court order that fails to apprise that party in clear and certain terms of the actions that must be taken to satisfy the order.Â  Phillips v. Phillips, 288 S.C. 185, 188, 341 S.E.2d 132, 133 (1986) (â€œOne may not be convicted of contempt for violating a court order which fails to tell him in definite terms what he must do.â€).
The family court ordered each party to execute any deeds necessary to effectuate the apportionment of the marital estate.Â  Wife was required to deliver to Husband deeds to property in Pennsylvania and Florida.Â  These properties were clearly indicated in an exhibit to the family court order.Â  Wife intentionally did not deliver these deeds.Â  Accordingly, the family court did not abuse its discretion when it held Wife in contempt for failing to deliver these deeds to Husband.Â Â  
VII.Â Â  Motion for Reconsideration 
Wife argues the family court erred in granting Husbandâ€™s motion for reconsideration.Â  We disagree. 
Wife appears to argue that because the issues raised by Husband in his Rule 59(e), SCRCP, motion to alter or amend judgment were not heard by oral argument, the family court erred in granting Husbandâ€™s motion.Â  Rule 59(f) expressly provides a Rule 59(e) motion â€œmay in the discretion of the court be determined on briefs filed by the parties without oral argument.â€Â  In this case, the family court chose to rule on Husbandâ€™s motion without oral argument.Â  Because the decision to grant the motion without oral argument is clearly within the family courtâ€™s discretion, Wife should have filed a brief in opposition to Husbandâ€™s motion if she wished to contest the issues raised by Husbandâ€™s motion.Â  Accordingly, the family court did not err in granting Husbandâ€™s motion. 
CONCLUSION
 Therefore, we hold the family court erred in terminating Wifeâ€™s alimony.Â  We reinstate the $500 monthly alimony to Wife from Husband.Â  The remaining issues are affirmed.Â  
The order of the family court isÂ Â  
AFFIRMED IN PART; REVERSED IN PART.
GOOLSBY and ANDERSON, JJ., and CURETON, A.J., concur.

[1]Â  There are two relevant tracts of real property on Jackson Creek Road.Â  The first, located at 10448 Jackson Creek Road, is the marital home awarded to Wife.Â  The second, located at 2202 Jackson Creek Road, is the parcel of land the family court determined to be nonmarital property.Â  The Jackson Creek Road property referred to here is the latter tract located at 2202 Jackson Creek Road.Â Â Â

THIS OPINION HAS NO PRECEDENTIAL VALUE.  IT SHOULD NOT BE CITED OR RELIED ON AS PRECEDENT IN ANY PROCEEDING EXCEPT AS PROVIDED BY RULE 239(D)(2), SCACR.  
THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Court of Appeals

  
    
      
        South Carolina Department of Social Services, Respondent,
      
    
  

v.

  
    
      
        Melissa Wilson Evans, Carl Evans, John Doe, and Melissa Hope Evans, DOB 1/23/01, Defendants,
        of whom Melissa Wilson Evans is the, Appellant.
      
    
  


Appeal From Orangeburg County
Â Anne Gue Jones, Family Court Judge

Unpublished Opinion No. 2006-UP-028
Submitted December 1, 2005 â€“ Filed January 12, 2006Â Â Â  

AFFIRMED


  
    
      
        Ariel Townsend Rosamond, of Orangeburg, for Appellant.
        Jerrod A. Anderson, of Orangeburg, for Respondent.
      
    
  

PER CURIAM:Â  This is an appeal from a family court order terminating parental rights.Â  Melissa Wilson Evans argues the family court erred by failing to give adequate consideration to the recommendation of the guardian ad litem in making its decision.Â Â  We affirm.[1]
FACTS
Evans is the biological mother of Melissa Hope Evans (Hope). This appeal arises from the family courtâ€™s termination of Evansâ€™s parental rights on July 16, 2004, for the following statutory grounds: (1) Hope had been in foster care under the responsibility of the State for fifteen of the most recent twenty-two months; (2) Evans failed to remedy the conditions that caused that removal; and (3) Evans failed to support or visit Hope for a period of six months prior to the commencement of the termination of parental rights proceedings.Â  Â 
Hope was born on January 23, 2001.Â  Two days later the South Carolina Department of Social Services (DSS) placed her into emergency protective custody when Evans and Hope both tested positive for cocaine.Â  On January 29, 2001, the family court held a probable cause hearing, and Evans, who lived with her mother, was granted temporary custody of Hope.Â  Evans attended Lowcountry Crossroad Treatment Facility and was later discharged.Â  Evans then began an outpatient program at the Dawn Center in Orangeburg.Â  
On August 22, 2001, Evans again tested positive for cocaine and DSS placed Hope in foster care.Â  Subsequently, the family court issued a formal notice of removal, which gave custody to DSS and granted Evans supervised visitation with Hope.Â  The family court also ordered Evans to comply with a treatment plan which included drug rehabilitation and parenting classes.Â  
On November 3, 2001, because of Evansâ€™s relapse, the Dawn Center recommended Evans enter an inpatient program rather than an outpatient program.Â  Evans disagreed with the recommendation of inpatient treatment, and has not returned to the Dawn Center.Â  Although Evans completed the parenting classes, she has not completed a drug treatment program.Â  Â 
On February 21, 2003, DSS filed an action for termination of parental rights.Â  During the hearing, Evans testified police arrested her for possession of cocaine on April 11, 2003.Â  Since her arrest, Evans has been working for the Sheriffâ€™s department as an informant.Â  Because of her cooperation, no charges have been brought against her.Â  Also during the hearing, the guardian testified that he believed the petition to terminate parental rights should be dismissed and in his opinion, Evans impressed him as someone who truly wanted her child back.Â  The guardian further testified he felt DSS should help Evans with job training or some other kind of economic assistance.Â  However, the guardian also testified that he had never met with Hope nor observed Hopeâ€™s relationship with her foster family.Â  
Following the hearing, the family court found, pursuant to Section 20-7-1572 of the South Carolina Code (Supp. 2004), Hope had been removed from Evansâ€™s home for more than six months, and Evans failed to visit.Â  Moreover, Hope had been in foster care for fifteen of the most recent twenty-two months.Â  Additionally, even though DSS demonstrated a reasonable and meaningful effort to provide rehabilitative services, Evans failed to remedy the conditions which led to Hopeâ€™s removal.Â  The family court also found termination to be in Hopeâ€™s best interest and therefore terminated Evansâ€™s parental rights.Â  This appeal followed.Â  
STANDARD OF REVIEW
In a termination of parental rights (TPR) case, â€œthe appellate court has jurisdiction to examine the entire record to determine the facts according to its view of the evidence.â€ Doe v. Baby Boy Roe, 353 S.C. 576, 579-80, 578 S.E.2d 733, 735 (Ct. App. 2003) (citing Richland County Depâ€™t of Soc. Servs. v. Earles, 330 S.C. 24, 32, 496 S.E.2d 864, 868 (1998)).Â  In our examination, the best interest of the child is our paramount consideration.Â  Roe, 353 S.C. at 579, 578 S.E.2d at 735.Â  Additionally, the grounds for TPR must be proved by clear and convincing evidence.Â  S.C. Depâ€™t of Soc. Servs. v. Parker, 336 S.C. 248, 254, 519 S.E.2d 351, 354 (Ct. App. 1999) (citing Santosky v. Kramer, 455 U.S. 745, 747-48 (1982) (holding â€œ[b]efore a State may sever completely and irrevocably the rights of parents in their natural child, due process requires that the State support its allegations by at least clear and convincing evidenceâ€)).Â  â€œOur broad scope of review does not require us to disregard the findings below or ignore the fact the trial judge was in a better position to asses the credibility of the witnesses.â€Â  S.C. Depâ€™t of Soc. Servs. v. Cummings, 345 S.C. 288, 293, 547 S.E.2d 506, 509 (Ct. App. 2001) (citing Dorchester County Depâ€™t of Soc. Servs. v. Miller, 324 S.C. 445, 452, 477 S.E.2d 476, 480 (Ct. App. 1996)).
LAW/ANALYSIS
The sole issue on appeal is whether the family court erred by failing to give adequate consideration to the recommendation of the guardian ad litem.Â  For the reasons set out below, we find clear and convincing evidence supports the family courtâ€™s order terminating parental rights.
In Shainwald v. Shainwald, we stated that â€œmuch of the criticism of guardians ad litem stems from the failure . . .Â  to recognize the proper function of a guardian ad litem.â€ 302 S.C. 453, 457, 395 S.E.2d 441, 444 (Ct. App. 1990).Â  Properly understood, the guardian functions as a â€œrepresentative of the court, appointed to assist the court in making its determination of custody by advocating for the best interest of the children and by providing the court with an objective view.â€Â  Patel v. Patel, 347 S.C. 281, 287, 555 S.E.2d 386, 389 (2001) (citing Fleming v. Asbill, 326 S.C. 49,Â­Â­ 57, 483 S.E.2d 751, 755 (1997)).Â  The role of the guardian ad litem in making a custody recommendation is to â€œaid, not direct, the court.â€ Clear v. Clear, 331 S.C. 186, 191, 500 S.E.2d 790, 792 (Ct. App. 1998);Â  see also Shainwald, 302 S.C. at 457, 395 S.E.2d at 443 (â€œ[T]he guardian ad litem does not usurp the judgeâ€™s function; he aids it.â€) (citation omitted).Â  The family court is not required to adhere to the guardianâ€™s recommendation regarding custody.Â  See, e.g., Shirley v. Shirley, 342 S.C. 324, 340, 536 S.E.2d 427, 435 (Ct. App. 2000) (â€œBased on our review of the record, the judge gave proper weight and consideration to the recommendation delivered by the guardian ad litem and did not abuse his discretion in refusing to follow the recommendation.â€); Pountain v. Pountain, 332 S.C. 130, 138, 503 S.E.2d 757, 761 (Ct. App. 1998) (finding no abuse of discretion where the family court considered but ultimately rejected the guardianâ€™s recommendation). 
Turning to the case at bar, the family court, after due and deliberate consideration of the guardianâ€™s testimony, found termination of Evansâ€™s parental rights was in Hopeâ€™s best interest.Â  The evidence presented by DSS showed Evans tested positive for cocaine and failed to complete drug abuse treatment.Â  Further, she was arrested for possession of cocaine but was not prosecuted for the offense due to her agreement to work as an unpaid drug informant for the Orangeburg County Sheriffâ€™s Department.Â  The family court found that Evans was still involved in a setting where illegal drugs were present, which was not in Hopeâ€™s best interest.Â  Additionally, Evans failed to pay child support, her visits were sporadic at best, and Hope has been in foster care for fifteen of the last twenty-two months.Â  Most notably, the family court also found, in evaluating Evansâ€™s demeanor, her testimony of sobriety was not credible.Â  Despite the guardianâ€™s testimony that the petition for terminating Evansâ€™s parental rights should be dismissed, we agree with the family court that Hopeâ€™s best interest would be served by termination.
We reiterate that the family court judge is in a better position to evaluate the credibility of the witnesses.Â  â€œ[W]here the evidence presented in the record adequately supports the findings of the trial judge, due deference should be given to his judgment based on his superior position in weighing such evidence.Â  This is especially true in cases involving the welfare and best interests of children.â€Â  Aiken County Depâ€™t of Soc. Servs. v. Wilcox, 304 S.C. 90, 93, 403 S.E.2d 142, 144 (Ct. App. 1991) (citations omitted). The family court adequately considered the facts in light of what would be in Hopeâ€™s best interest and made detailed and specific findings.[2]Â  Based on our review of the record, we find the family court did not abuse its discretion in refusing to follow the guardian ad litemâ€™s recommendation.Â  Accordingly the decision of the family court is 
AFFIRMED.
KITTREDGE, WILLIAMS, JJ., AND CURETON, A.J., CONCUR.

[1] We decide this case without oral argument, pursuant to Rule 215, SCACR.  
[2] Evansâ€™s also argues the family court failed to make a finding as to why it rejected the recommendation of the guardian.Â  This argument has absolutely no merit. The record is replete with the family courtâ€™s findings as to why Evansâ€™s parental rights were terminated.Â

THIS OPINION HAS NO PRECEDENTIAL VALUE.Â  IT SHOULD NOT BE CITED OR RELIED ON AS PRECEDENT IN ANY PROCEEDING EXCEPT AS PROVIDED BY RULE 239(d)(2), SCACR.
THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Court of Appeals


  
    
      
        Louise Trask and James E. Garrison, III, M.D., as Co-Personal Representatives of the Estate of Louise Canada McKinney, Deceased, and Co-Trustees of the Virginia T. Howell Revocable Trust, Respondents,
      
    
  

v.

  
    
      
        Jiffy McIntosh, Judy Darrough, Jerry McKinney, American Skandia Life Assurance Company, Coastal Investor Services, Inc., Michael Hill, and Lorena Queen, 
        Of whom Michael Hill is the Appellant.
      
    
  


Appeal From Horry County
Â J. Michael Baxley, Circuit Court Judge

Unpublished Opinion No. 2006-UP-029
Heard January 10, 2006 â€“ Filed January 12, 2006Â Â Â  

REVERSED AND REMANDED


  
    
      
        Richard C. Burke, of Charleston, for Appellant.
        Thomas A. Holloway, of Beaufort, for Respondents.
      
    
  

PER CURIAM:Â  Michael Hill appeals from an order denying his motion to compel arbitration.Â  We reverse and remand.
FACTS
On May 30, 1997, Mary Garrison, in her capacity as trustee of the Virginia T. Howell Revocable Trust, opened a brokerage account for the purchase of annuities with Robert Thomas Securities, Inc., through their Myrtle Beach branch office, Coastal Investor Services, Inc., and their employee, Michael Hill. The contract between Garrison and Hill incorporated by reference a “Client Agreement” that contained a binding arbitration clause, which Garrison acknowledged receipt of by her signature. The Client Agreement contained an arbitration clause that applied to all disputes arising under the contract and bound all successors in interest to the terms of the agreement. Neither Garrison nor Hill signed the Client Agreement. Garrison died on May 1, 2001. 
On August 26, 2002, Louise Trask and James Garrison, who are successor trustees to the Howell Trust, filed an action against Hill, alleging that Hill was negligent and breached his fiduciary duty by selling Garrison a brokerage account with an incorrect designated beneficiary. In his answer, Hill alleged that the brokerage agreement underlying the action was subject to binding arbitration. Hill filed a motion to stay the action against him and to compel arbitration. On December 15, 2003, after a hearing on Hill’s motion to compel arbitration, Judge John declined to rule on the motion, continuing the matter until the parties conducted limited discovery that was restricted to the issue of arbitrability. However, in the intervening months between the initial hearing and the second hearing on September 14, 2004, the only discovery conducted was Hill’s sua sponte production of his entire documentary file to respondents in May 2004. After the second hearing on the motion, Judge Baxley issued his order denying Hill’s motion to compel arbitration. Hill appeals. 
LAW/ANALYSIS
Hill argues the trial court erred by failing to compel arbitration under the Federal Arbitration Act because there was a binding contract, evidencing intent to arbitrate any disputes arising under the contract.Â  We agree. 
â€œThe question of the arbitrability of a claim is an issue for judicial determination, unless the parties provide otherwise.â€Â  Zabinski v. Bright Acres Assocs., 346 S.C. 580, 596, 553 S.E.2d 110, 118 (2001).Â  â€œDeterminations of arbitrability are subject to de novo review.â€Â  Stokes v. Metropolitan Life Ins. Co., 351 S.C. 606, 609, 571 S.E.2d 711, 713 (Ct. App. 2002).Â  

â€œThe policy of the United States and South Carolina is to favor arbitration of disputes.â€Â  Zabinski, 346 S.C. at 596, 553 S.E.2d at 118.Â  â€œ[U]nless the court can say with positive assurance that the arbitration clause is not susceptible to an interpretation that covers the dispute, arbitration should be ordered.â€Â  Id. at 597, 553 S.E.2d at 118.Â  The arbitration agreement in the instant case states that if the parties cannot resolve a dispute or controversy by mediation, â€œthereafter, any unsettled dispute or controversy will be resolved by arbitration . . . in accordance with the United States Arbitration Act (Title 9 of the United States Code).â€Â  Therefore, any claim pursuant to the contract is subject to arbitration.Â  
The arbitration clause in this case is contained in the Client Agreement.Â  Garrison signed a contract that stated, â€œBy signing below, I acknowledge that I have received, read, understood, and agree to abide by all the terms and conditions set forth in the Client Agreement Incorporated herein by this reference.Â  The Client Agreement contains a binding arbitration clause and other provisions substantially affecting my rights.â€Â  Thus, Garrison and her successors are bound by the arbitration clause in the Client Agreement.Â Â Â  Â 
Additionally, â€œ[u]nless the parties have contracted to the contrary, the FAA [Federal Arbitration Act, 9 U.S.C.A. Â§Â§ 1 to 16 (West 1999)] applies in federal or state court to any arbitration agreement regarding a transaction that in fact involves interstate commerce, regardless of whether or not the parties contemplated an interstate transaction.â€Â  Munoz v. Green Tree Financial Corp., 343 S.C. 531, 538, 542 S.E.2d 360, 363 (2001).Â  Neither party in this case disputes the FAA applies to claims arising under the contract Garrison signed in 1997.Â  Therefore, the trial judge erred by applying South Carolina arbitration law and failing to order arbitration in this case.
REVERSED AND REMANDED.
GOOLSBY, ANDERSON, and SHORT, JJ., concur.

THIS OPINION HAS NO PRECEDENTIAL VALUE.Â  IT SHOULD NOT BE CITED OR RELIED ON AS PRECEDENT IN ANY PROCEEDING EXCEPT AS PROVIDED BY RULE 239(d)(2), SCACR.
THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Court of Appeals

  
    
      
        The State, Respondent,
      
    
  

v.

  
    
      
        Stephen Tyrone Simmons, Appellant.
      
    
  


Appeal From York County
Â Lee S. Alford, Circuit Court Judge

Unpublished Opinion No. 2006-UP-030
Submitted January 1, 2006 â€“ Filed January 12, 2006Â Â Â  

AFFIRMED


  
    
      
        Acting Chief Attorney Joseph L. Savitz III, of Columbia, for Appellant.
        Attorney General Henry Dargan McMaster, Chief Deputy Attorney General John W. McIntosh, Assistant Deputy Attorney General Salley W. Elliott, Assistant Attorney General Deborah R.J. Shupe, all of Columbia; and Solicitor Thomas E. Pope, of York, for Respondent.
      
    
  

PER CURIAM:Â  In this appeal of a guilty plea, Stephen Tyrone Simmons argues the trial court erred in accepting his guilty plea because it was made conditional on his ability to appeal the denial of pre-trial motions.Â  We affirm.[1]Â  
FACTS    
On April 27, 2002, York County narcotics officers instructed James Moore, a confidential informant, to contact Simmons and set up a deal over the telephone to purchase cocaine.Â  Moore and Simmons agreed to meet at a liquor store.Â  Simmons delivered to Moore what was later identified as 114.70 grams of cocaine.Â  The police videotaped the transaction between Simmons and Moore.Â  Simmons was apprehended, given his Miranda rights, which he waived, and confessed to delivering cocaine to Moore.
In July 2002, the York County Grand Jury indicted Simmons on one count of trafficking between 100 and 200 grams of cocaine.Â  The case was called for a jury trial on November 6, 2002.Â  Simmons proceeded pro se.Â  Prior to trial, Simmons submitted a Uniform Commercial Code (UCC) document to the trial court, moved to dismiss the claims against him based on this document, and moved to file a commercial lien against everyone involved in the prosecution.Â  The trial court denied the motion stating that it was unrelated to the criminal case at hand.Â  Simmons then moved to renounce his United States citizenship.Â  The trial court informed Simmons it did not have jurisdiction to grant such a request, and he would have to pursue the request in federal court. 
The trial court impressed upon Simmons the importance of having representation, and Simmons decided that it was in his best interest to move forward with an attorney.Â  After a brief recess, Simmonsâ€™s counsel informed the trial court that Simmons wanted to plead guilty pursuant to an agreement with the State to allow a plea to the lesser charge of trafficking between 28 and 100 grams of cocaine, second offense, with a negotiated sentence of sixteen years.Â  In accordance with the plea agreement and negotiated sentence, Simmons was sentenced to sixteen years.Â  This appeal followed.Â  
LAW/ANALYSIS
Simmons argues the trial court erred in accepting his guilty plea because it was made conditional on his ability to appeal the denial of his pre-trial motions concerning the UCC claim and the request to renounce his citizenship. We disagree. 
In South Carolina, a guilty plea must be unconditional.Â  State v. Peppers, 346 S.C. 502, 504, 552 S.E.2d 288, 289 (2001).Â  If an accused attempts to attach any condition, the trial court must direct a plea of not guilty.Â  State v. Oâ€™Leary, 302 S.C. 17, 18, 393 S.E.2d 186, 187 (1990).Â  The basis for this rule â€œis the settled doctrine that a guilty plea constitutes a waiver of all prior claims of constitutional rights or deprivations thereof.â€Â  Peppers, 346 at 504, 552 S.E.2d at 289. 
Rule 201, SCARC, provides an appeal â€œmay be taken, as provided by law, from any final judgment or appealable order.â€Â  However, it is error for defendants to preserve certain issues while entering pleas of guilty, and if a defendant does so, the plea is conditional and invalid.Â  See State v. Oâ€™Leary, 302 S.C. 17, 18, 393 S.E.2d 186, 187 (1990).Â  The issues Simmons sought to preserve for appeal are not issues that are prohibited from being preserved.Â  Generally, the issue of a conditional plea arises when a defendant seeks to preserve for appeal a challenge to the constitutionality of the underlying statute or preserve for appeal pre-trial motions concerning the deprivation of a constitutional right. Â 
In Oâ€™Leary, the trial court accepted the defendantâ€™s plea of guilty to the offense of driving under suspension (â€œDUSâ€), conditioned, however, upon the defendantâ€™s right to appeal his constitutional challenges of the DUS statute.Â  Id. at 18, 393 S.E.2d at 187.Â  In finding Oâ€™Learyâ€™s plea to be conditional and invalid, the Supreme Court of South Carolina held that

   [g]uilty pleas are unconditional and, if an accused attempts to attach any condition, the trial court must direct a plea of not guilty. . . . It is, thus, impermissible for a defendant to preserve constitutional issues while entertaining a guilty plea; the trial court may not accept the plea on such terms.

    Id. (citations omitted).
Additionally, in the case of State v. Truesdale, 278 S.C. 368, 296 S.E.2d 528 (1982), the trial court reversed the defendantâ€™s conviction, following his conditional guilty plea.Â  In pre-trial motions, Truesdale sought a change of venue, a limitation on the use of peremptory challenges by the solicitor, and certain restrictions upon the disqualification of jurors for cause.Â  Id. at 369, 296 S.E.2d at 529.Â  These motions were denied, and Truesdale entered a plea of guilty.Â  The Supreme Court of South Carolina held the entrance of such a conditional guilty plea was improper, and it was error for the trial court to accept the pleas on such terms.Â  Id. at 370, 296 S.E.2d at 529.Â  It is important to note that prior to the trial court accepting Truesdaleâ€™s guilty plea, his counsel made an equivocating statement as follows: 

  However, to the extent that the denial of any of these three motions did, as we maintain, deny this young man a jury that was constitutionally selected, it would be my judgment and I think the record should reflect our position, that the plea is in fact the product of what we assert to be the deprivation of his constitutional rights.

Id. at 370, 296 S.E.2d at 528.Â  In the instant case, Simmons did not condition his plea on the appeal of his pre-trial motions, nor did Simmons make an equivocating statement denying his guilt while still pleading guilty.Â  He never attempted to reserve the right to later deny his guilt.Â  
Courts have often upheld pleas that preserved certain issues not connected with the guilt.Â  In the case of State v. Downs, 361 S.C. 141, 604 S.E.2d 377 (2004), Downs reserved the right to present evidence that he committed the crime while he was mentally ill and moved forward with the guilty plea.Â  This court held that guilty but mentally ill (GBMI) is still guilty.Â  Id. at 146, 604 S.E.2d at 380.Â  The difference between guilty and GBMI pertains only to post-sentencing medical treatment, and therefore, Downsâ€™s guilty plea was unconditional.Â  Id.Â  This issue also arose in the case of Easter v. State, 355 S.C. 79, 584 S.E.2d 117 (2003).Â  The Supreme Court of South Carolina found that when Easter entered his guilty plea, but objected to his sentence, he did not enter an invalid, conditional guilty plea.Â  Id. at 81, 584 S.E.2d at 119.Â  â€œSentencing, although often combined with the admission of guilt in a hearing, is a separate issue from guilt and a distinct phase of the criminal process.â€Â  Id.Â  
Both the Easter and Downs cases are similar to this case.Â  Here, Simmons sought pre-trial motions concerning a commercial lien and renouncing his United States citizenship.Â  Neither of these motions concerned his guilt.Â  In fact, when the trial court asked Simmons if he was â€œin fact guilty of trafficking powder cocaine,â€ Simmons replied â€œYes.â€Â  The trial court explained Simmonsâ€™s right to appeal and that by pleading guilty, he was â€œextinguishing some rights that you would have to raise on appeal.â€Â  Simmons was then given time to consult with his attorney concerning his appellate rights, and his attorney informed the trial court that Simmons understood those rights. 
Simmons did not attach a condition to his guilty plea.Â  Simmons did not condition his plea on the outcome of an appeal of his pre-trial motions.Â  Simmons merely sought to preserve his right to appeal motions that did not concern his guilt.Â  Therefore, the trial court did not err in accepting Simmonsâ€™s guilty plea because it was not an invalid conditional plea.Â  
AFFIRMED. 
GOOLSBY, ANDERSON, and SHORT, JJ., concur.

[1] We decide this case without oral argument pursuant to Rule 215, SCACR.

THIS OPINION HAS NO PRECEDENTIAL VALUE.Â  IT SHOULD NOT BE CITED OR RELIED ON AS PRECEDENT IN ANY PROCEEDING EXCEPT AS PROVIDED BY RULE 239(d)(2), SCACR.
THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Court of Appeals


  
    
      
        The State, Respondent,
      
    
  

v.

  
    
      
        Charles Allen Henderson, Appellant.
      
    
  


Appeal From Greenville County
Â James C. Williams, Jr., Circuit Court Judge

Unpublished Opinion No.Â  2006-UP-037
Submitted December 1, 2005 â€“ Filed January 18, 2006

REVERSED AND REMANDED

  
    
      
        
      Assistant Appellate Defender Aileen P. Clare, of Columbia, for Appellant.
      Attorney General Henry Dargan McMaster, Chief Deputy Attorney General John W. McIntosh, Assistant Deputy Attorney General Salley W. Elliott, Assistant Attorney General David A. Spencer, all of Columbia; and Solicitor Robert M. Ariail, of Greenville, for Respondent.
      
    
  

PER CURIAM: Charles Henderson appeals his convictions for possession with intent to distribute cocaine in proximity of a school and trafficking in cocaine. Henderson argues the trial court erred by denying his motion to suppress evidence due to a defective search warrant and by using four separate verdict forms.Â  We reverse and remand.[1] Â Â 
FACTS
Charles Henderson, Kevin Covert, and others were present in Covertâ€™s house in Greenville County when police searched it on September 26, 2002.Â  When the officers entered the house they found Henderson in the living room with a coffee grinder containing a white powder substance, small plastic bags of white powered substance, a cutting agent, sifting instruments, and an electronic scale, all in front of him on a coffee table.Â  A cell phone box on the couch next to him contained a large plastic bag of cocaine, weighing 441.50 grams.Â  Cocaine, weighing 22.89 grams, was found on the coffee table.Â  Two smaller quantities of cocaine, weighing 6.47 grams and 1.62 grams, were also recovered.Â  Police also found $1,950 on the floor in front of the couch.Â  Additionally, police found a pistol on a bookshelf.Â  Henderson was the only person in the living room.Â  Covert was found in a bedroom on the other side of the house.Â  A holster for a gun, a 9-mm. magazine, and several dozen rounds of ammunition were found in an adjacent bedroom that belonged to Henderson. 
All the individuals in the house were arrested and charged with trafficking in cocaine.Â  However, Henderson and Covert were also charged with possession of a weapon during the commission of a violent crime.Â  Donald Myers and Roger Harris, both charged with trafficking, pled guilty to simple possession and were to receive suspended sentences in exchange for testifying for the State.Â  
At trial, Myers testified he purchased cocaine from Henderson and Covert at the house numerous times.Â Â  Myers stated his purchases usually amounted to between one hundred and two hundred dollars each for between one and three-quarters grams and three and one-half grams of cocaine.Â  Myers also testified he had seen both Henderson and Covert bagging cocaine.Â  On September 26, Myers was at the house to purchase cocaine from Covert.Â  Harris also testified he had purchased cocaine from Henderson and Covert at their house at least twice a week for the previous two years.Â  Harris stated Henderson sometimes delivered cocaine to his house.Â  Henderson testified that he never sold drugs to Myers or Harris.Â Â Â  
Henderson was tried together with his co-defendant, Covert, and convicted of both charges.Â  Henderson was sentenced to concurrent sentences of 25 years for the trafficking charge and 10 years for the distribution charge.Â  Henderson now appeals.Â  
LAW/ANALYSIS
 I.Â Â Â Â Â Â  Suppression of Evidence  
Henderson contends the trial judge erred by denying his motion to suppress evidence and by applying a good faith exception to the statutory warrant requirement because the warrant was defective.Â  We agree.Â  
In criminal cases, an appellate court reviews errors of law only and is bound by factual findings of the trial court unless clearly erroneous.Â  State v. Wilson, 345 S.C. 1, 5-6, 545 S.E.2d 827, 829 (2001).Â  â€œA courtâ€™s ruling on the admissibility of evidence will not be reversed on appeal absent an abuse of discretion or the commission of legal error that results in prejudice to the defendant.â€Â  State v. Adams, 354 S.C. 361, 377, 580 S.E.2d 785, 793 (Ct. App. 2003).Â  
During the trial, Henderson and Covert moved to suppress evidence seized during the search on the basis that although the search was conducted on September 26, 2002, the magistrateâ€™s signature is dated September 28, 2002 on the warrant itself.Â  The magistrateâ€™s signature and the date of September 26, 2002 only appear on two separate pages of the affidavit.Â  During the trial, Detective Timothy Conroy testified that he did not see the magistrate sign the search warrant on the 26th and that â€œmost probably she didnâ€™t sign that night and that was brought back to her on some other occasion to sign.â€Â  Upon finding the warrant was defective under section 17-13-140 of the South Carolina Code (2003), the trial judge ruled a good faith exception to the Fourth Amendmentâ€™s exclusionary rule should apply to South Carolinaâ€™s statutory warrant requirement and denied the motion to suppress all evidence obtained during the September 26 search.
First, we must determine whether the warrant was defective because the signature was dated two days after the search was conducted.Â  Section 17-13-140 of the South Carolina Code (2003) states that a warrant shall be â€œissued only upon affidavit sworn to before the magistrate, municipal judicial officer, or judge of a court of record establishing the grounds for the warrant.â€Â  Though the statute does not specifically require that the warrant be signed, it requires that it be â€œissued.â€Â  In Davis v. Sanders, 40 S.C. 507, 19 S.E. 138 (1894), â€œ[our supreme] court held that the warrant was not â€˜issuedâ€™ as required by law, and conferred no authority on the sheriff to make the arrest, because the magistrate did not sign at the foot as he intended to do, and because he did not intend the indorsement on the back as his signature of the warrant.â€Â  Du Bose v. Du Bose, 90 S.C. 87, 90, 72 S.E. 645, 646 (1911).Â  Therefore, a warrant is not issued until signed by an appropriate magistrate, municipal judicial officer, or judge of a court of record.Â  See 77-370 S.C. Op. Attâ€™y Gen. 295 (1977) (stating a warrant is properly issued only when signed by the magistrate and only upon a sworn affidavit).Â  Thus, the warrant in this case was defective because there was no evidence that the magistrate signed the warrant before the search was conducted and the signature on the warrant is dated two days after the search was conducted.
Courts of other states have also held a search warrant must be signed because it is the confirmation that the magistrate determined the facts asserted in the affidavit support a finding of probable cause.[2]Â  In State v. Surowiecki, 440 A.2d 798, 799 (Conn. 1981), the Connecticut Supreme Court held that a warrant is not â€œissuedâ€ without a lawful signature on the search warrant by the person authorized to issue it.Â  The court reached this conclusion even though there was no doubt the judge intended to sign the search warrant and failed to do so because of a â€œmere oversight.â€Â  Id. at 798.Â  There are also several public policy considerations to support a requirement that the warrant be signed prior to a search: it impresses upon the magistrate the importance of his action in issuing a warrant; it discourages police misconduct by dictating that officers can not reasonably rely on an unsigned document as an authorization for conducting a search and by requiring officers to take corrective measures before they conduct a search; and it provides needed protections and assurances to persons in control of the property to be searched that the search has been authorized.Â  State v. Hentkowski, 397 N.W.2d 255, 258 (Mich. Ct. App. 1986).Â  Â Â 
Having found the warrant was defective because the signature was dated two days after the search was conducted; we must next determine whether the good faith exception to the Fourth Amendmentâ€™s exclusionary rule should apply to South Carolinaâ€™s statutory warrant requirement.Â  The trial judge allowed the introduction of the evidence seized pursuant to a good faith exception as adopted by the United States Supreme Court in United States v. Leon, 468 U.S. 897 (1984).Â  The Leon rule applies when a search warrant is defective on Fourth Amendment grounds.Â  Id.Â  However, in this case, the evidence Henderson sought to have excluded was obtained because of a defective search warrant based on a state statutory violation, not a constitutional violation.Â  
In South Carolina, the statutory warrant requirement is separate and distinct from the prohibition in the federal and state constitutions against unreasonable searches and seizures.Â  S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 17-13-140 (2003); see U.S. Const. amend. IV; S.C. Const. art. I, Â§ 10.Â  In fact, as the South Carolina Supreme Court has recognized, section 17-13-140 of the South Carolina Code actually imposes stricter warrant requirements than the constitutional provisions.Â  See State v. Jones, 342 S.C. 121, 128, 536 S.E.2d 675, 678 (2000).Â  Therefore, the Leon good faith exception is not applicable to this case and we must determine whether there is a good faith exception to the statutory warrant requirement in South Carolina.
In State v. Sachs, 264 S.C. 541, 559, 216 S.E.2d 501, 510 (1975), the Supreme Court of South Carolina found a good faith exception permits the introduction of evidence seized pursuant to a warrant that is defective under section 17-13-140 of the South Carolina Code if the officers have made a good faith attempt to comply with the affidavit requirement.Â  In Sachs, the affidavit the officers relied on contained misstated facts; however, the court determined that such misstatements in an affidavit were â€œnecessary hazardsâ€ encountered when federal and state authorities search in a joint effort and the affidavit satisfied a good-faith attempt to comply with the statute relating to search warrants.Â  Id.Â  
In State v. McKnight, 291 S.C. 110, 112-13, 352 S.E.2d 471, 472 (1987), the officers orally recited the facts upon which the warrant was based, but no affidavit was ever executed. Â As a result, the court found that there was no good faith effort to comply with the statute; however, the court declined to decide whether there is a good faith exception for officers who execute a search with objectively reasonable reliance on a warrant that is ultimately found to be invalid.Â  Id. at 114, 352 S.E.2d at 473.Â  The instant case falls somewhere between the cases of McKnight and Sachs.Â  This is not a case of the â€œnecessary hazardsâ€ of obtaining a warrant as in the case of Sachs and it is not a failure to comply with the statutory warrant requirement as in McKnight.Â  Here, the officers failed to notice that either the magistrate did not sign the warrant on September 26 or that the signature on the warrant itself was misdated as September 28, while the search was conducted on September 26, 2002.[3]Â  The officers could have discovered either error by simply looking at the warrant itself; therefore, we find there was no good faith effort to comply with the statute.
Since we find the warrant was defective and the good faith exception to the warrant requirement does not apply in this case, we must finally determine if the admission of the evidence found with the defective warrant constituted harmless error.Â  â€œError is harmless where it could not reasonably have affected the result of the trial.â€Â  State v. Reeves, 301 S.C. 191, 193-94, 391 S.E.2d 241, 243 (1990).Â  Generally, appellate courts will not set aside convictions due to insubstantial error not affecting the result.Â  State v. Davis, 364 S.C. 364, 409, 613 S.E.2d 760, 784 (Ct. App. 2005).Â  The violation found in this case cannot be seen as harmless error because exclusion of the evidence could have reasonably affected the result of the trial and the issue of the amount of cocaine allegedly possessed by Henderson was a central issue in this case. [4]  
II.Â Â Â Â  Verdict Form 
Henderson contends the trial judge erred by creating four separate special verdict forms for the single charge of trafficking because it unfairly emphasized guilt and gave the jury four separate opportunities to convict him of a single charge.Â  We disagree.Â  
At the close of the case, the judge drafted a special verdict form for each defendant with interrogatories consisting of a statement followed by a choice of â€œyesâ€ or â€œnoâ€ as to the trafficking charge and the lesser-included charges of possession with intent to distribute and simple possession.Â  Henderson claims the verdict form created a high probability that the jury would feel compelled to convict him because the first question on the verdict form, pertaining to the trafficking statute, was divided into four separate options and provided multiple choices.Â  As the trafficking statute reads, there are four ways that a jury can find a defendant guilty of â€œtrafficking in cocaineâ€: (1) one who sells, manufactures, cultivates, delivers, purchases, or brings into this State ten grams or more of cocaine; (2) one who provides financial assistance or otherwise aids, abets, attempts to bring into this State ten grams or more of cocaine; (3) one who conspires to sell, manufacture, cultivate, deliver, purchase, or brings into this State ten grams or more of cocaine; or (4) one who is knowingly in actual or constructive possession or who knowingly attempts to become in actual or constructive possession of ten grams or more of cocaine in this State.Â  S.C. Code Ann. Section 44-53-370(e)(2) (2002).Â  
This is a novel question of law in South Carolina; however, we find the law on jury charges to be applicable.Â  In State v. Rabon, 275 S.C. 459, 462, 272 S.E.2d 634, 636 (1980), our Supreme Court stated that â€œ[t]he Constitution of this State requires that the trial judge declare the law, but no particular verbiage is necessary.â€Â  The court further ruled that the judgeâ€™s charge must be considered as a whole to determine if it adequately covered the applicable law under the facts of the case.Â  Id.Â  Although the statute was broken into four parts on the verdict form, the language of the statute remained unchanged for the most part and adequately covered the law.Â  Additionally, â€œ[t]he test for sufficiency of a jury instruction is what a reasonable juror would have understood the charge to mean.Â  State v. Hughey, 339 S.C. 439, 458, 529 S.E.2d 721, 731 (2000).Â  Therefore, even if the judgeâ€™s attempt to provide guidance to the jury by breaking the statute into four parts was in error, when considered as a whole, the verdict question was a correct statement of the law and was not prejudicial to Henderson.Â  
REVERSED AND REMANDED. 
ANDERSON, J., (dissenting in part and concurring in part in RESULT ONLY):
 I adhere to my dissenting and concurring opinion in State v. Covert,Â  Op. No. 4071 (S.C. Ct. App. Filed Jan. 17, 2006). The latter case involved an appeal by the appellantâ€™s co-defendant and raised issues relating to the search warrant and the special verdict forms.Â  I VOTE to reverse.
__________
GOOLSBY, J. (concurring and dissenting):Â  I adhere to the views expressed in my dissenting opinion in State v. Covert, Op. No. 4071 (S.C. Ct. App. Filed Jan. 17, 2006), both as to the issue of the search warrant and as to the issue of the special verdict form.Â  
I would affirm.

[1] We decide this case without oral argument pursuant to Rule 215, SCACR.
[2] Courts in other states have made the same determination:Â  Kelley v. State, 316 So.2d 233 (Ala. Crim. App. 1975); Martin v. State, 344 So.2d 248 (Fla. Dist. Ct. App. 1976); Byrd v. Commonwealth, 261 S.W.2d 437 (Ky. Ct. App. 1953); United States v. Carignan, 286 F.Supp. 284 (Mass. Dist. Ct. 1967); People v. Hentkowski, 397 N.W.2d 255 (Mich. Ct. App. 1986); State v. Fleming, 227 S.W.2d 106 (Mo. Ct. App. 1950); State v. Williams, 565 N.E.2d 563 (Ohio 1991); State v. Cochrane, 173 N.W.2d 495 (S.D. 1970).
[3] The State did not offer any evidence that the magistrate signed the warrant on September 26, 2002, and the magistrate did not testify at trial.Â  
[4]Â  The State argues that Henderson does not have standing to raise the issue of the defective search warrant because he was not living in the house at the time of the search and therefore did not have a reasonable expectation of privacy in the house.Â  However, in State v. McKnight, our supreme court determined that the issue of standing would have only been relevant if the case had been decided on constitutional grounds.Â  The court held that â€œ[s]ince the trial judgeâ€™s ruling was based on the stricter, statutory grounds, each of the respondents against whom the evidence was offered had standing to object to the validity of the search.â€Â  291 S.C. at 115, 352 S.E.2d at 474.Â  Therefore, because this case was also not decided on constitutional grounds, we find Henderson had standing to object to the validity of the search.Â Â
