THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Court of Appeals

  
    
      
        Theresa Ann Baldwin, as Personal Representative of the Estate of John Gerald Baldwin, Respondent,
      
    
  

v.

  
    
      
        Robert Peoples, Appellant.
      
    
  


Appeal From Fairfield County
Kenneth G. Goode, Circuit Court Judge

Unpublished Opinion No. 2006-UP-038
Heard December 6, 2005 â€“ Filed January 18, 2006

REVERSED AND REMANDED


  
    
      
        Charles E. Carpenter, Jr. and Karl S. Brehmer, both Â of Columbia, for Appellant.
        Bryan D. Ramey, of Piedmont and John S. Nichols, of Columbia, for Respondent.
      
    
  

PER CURIAM:Â  Theresa Ann Baldwin, as Personal Representative of the Estate of John Gerald Baldwin (the Estate), filed a wrongful death action against Robert Peoples.Â  The trial court granted a directed verdict to the Estate as to liability, holding Peoplesâ€™ violation of certain statutes was the direct and proximate cause of Baldwinâ€™s death.Â  The jury returned a verdict for the Estate in the amount of $300,000, and the trial court subsequently granted the Estateâ€™s motion for new trial nisi additur of $357,469.31 for a total award of $657,469.31.Â  Peoples appeals various rulings of the trial judge, including the granting of the directed verdict for the plaintiff on the issue of liability.Â  We reverse and remand for a new trial.
FACTUAL/PROCEDURAL BACKGROUND
Around 3:00 on the afternoon of February 1, 1996, John Gerald Baldwin was driving a tractor-trailer westerly on a stretch of Interstate 20 when he collided with the back of a forty-foot semi-trailer truck loaded with logs and being pulled by Robert Peoples.Â  Shortly before the accident, Peoples had merged onto the interstate from Highway 521 ahead of Baldwin, driving thirty miles an hour on the entrance ramp.Â  He had increased his speed up to forty miles per hour at the time of the impact.Â  Following the collision between the two trucks, Baldwin was found dead in the cab of his truck with logs piercing his neck and stomach.Â  
On January 29, 1997, Baldwinâ€™s wife, as personal representative of his estate, filed a wrongful death action against Peoples.Â  Peoples answered, denying his negligence and alleging that Baldwinâ€™s own negligence caused or contributed to his death.Â  When the case initially went to trial, the jury returned a verdict in favor of Peoples, finding Baldwin to be 100% negligent.Â  The Estate appealed the verdict, and this court reversed and remanded the case for a new trial.Â  Baldwin v. Peoples, Op. No. 2000-UP-766 (S.C. Ct. App. filed Dec. 18, 2000).Â  On certiorari, the South Carolina Supreme Court affirmed in result based on an additional ground appearing in the record, finding the trial court allowed improper argument from the defense that Peoples had not been charged by law enforcement with violating any traffic laws, thus indicating he was in no way at fault and thereby inviting the jury to relinquish its role as the ultimate fact finder.Â  Baldwin v. Peoples, Op. No. 2002-MO-062 (S.C. Sup. Ct. filed Aug. 28, 2002).Â  
At the second trial, the Estate contended the collision occurred when Peoples, mistakenly thinking Baldwin was driving in the right lane, swerved into the emergency lane, causing the logs on the rear of his truck to cross the center line and into the left lane of traffic.Â  As a result, the Estate asserted, Baldwinâ€™s truck was caught on the logs, and Peoplesâ€™ truck dragged Baldwinâ€™s truck into the emergency lane.Â  To support its theory of the case, the Estate called Donald Phillips as an expert in accident reconstruction.Â  Phillips testified the logs on Peoplesâ€™ truck overhung the trailer by almost twenty feet; eye witness testimony indicated Baldwin did not brake before impact; based on the speed of each vehicle, the collision was the equivalent of an eighteen to twenty-five mile per hour collision; and if Peoples had properly trimmed the logs to the correct length, Baldwin would not have been impaled by the logs and would not have died as a result of the collision.Â  
Peoples testified his truck was going forty miles per hour at the point of the collision, and the minimum speed limit on that stretch of Interstate 20 was forty-five miles per hour.Â  He was not concerned that he would be hit because when he looked back, no vehicles were coming behind him.Â  Peoples stated he was in the right lane the entire time he was on the interstate.Â  Peoples saw Baldwin in his mirror prior to impact, and testified Baldwin was in the right lane as well, about twenty-five feet away.Â  Peoples claimed Baldwin maintained the same speed as he approached him, never slowing down.Â  When he realized Baldwin was about to hit him, Peoples tried to increase his speed but was unable to do so.Â  Peoples denied that his truck ever strayed over into the left lane.Â  
David Thomas, the only other witness to the collision, testified he was following Baldwinâ€™s truck in the left lane when he saw a puff of smoke and then some brake lights.Â  At that point, logs began coming over the top of the cab and the trailer.Â  He stated Baldwinâ€™s truck was still in the left lane at the time of the collision, and Thomas could not see Peoplesâ€™ truck until after the collision.Â  Trooper J.W. Dorton investigated the accident, and testified he documented skid marks and radiator fluid from Baldwinâ€™s truck that were all in the right lane.Â  He found no yawl marks to indicate Baldwinâ€™s tires â€œwere going sideways.â€Â  
Peoples contended that Baldwin was in the right lane behind him and inexplicably ran into the back of the log truck.Â  To support his theory, Peoples presented the expert testimony of accident reconstructionist Joseph Jur.Â  Jur testified there was no indication either Peoples or Baldwin moved from the left lane to the right; there was no evidence Peoplesâ€™ load swung out and crossed the line; and there was no steer maneuver that could have been made to the right by Peoples that could have made the logs shift into the left lane.Â  He stated Peoples would have been in Baldwinâ€™s sight distance for twenty-five seconds, Baldwin should have been able to react in one and a half seconds, and it would have taken Baldwin only 4.9 seconds to come to a complete stop, giving Baldwin plenty of time to stop.Â  Jur opined that the collision occurred in the right lane and that Baldwin, for some unknown reason, ran into Peoplesâ€™ truck.Â  He further testified the accident could not have occurred as the Estate contended.Â  
Before closing arguments, the Estate moved for a directed verdict on liability.Â  The Estate argued, and the trial judge agreed, that Peoples violated two statutory length provisions and a statutory minimum speed provision, and that Peoples was negligent as a matter of law in entering an interstate at thirty miles per hour, knowing the speed limit was sixty-five and it would take him some time to get up to forty-five miles an hour.Â  The Estate asserted that these violations proximately caused the death of Baldwin, and it was irrelevant how the wreck occurred.Â  The trial judge granted the Estateâ€™s motion for directed verdict, held â€œthis will take out the comparative negligence,â€ and ruled Peoples was not allowed to argue proximate cause to the jury.Â  The judge then instructed the jury he had directed a verdict for the Estate and ruled as a matter of law that Peoples was â€œresponsible for the injuries to and the death of Mr. Baldwin.â€Â  The jury returned a verdict of $300,000 for the Estate.Â  Peoples made a motion for a new trial, and the Estate filed a motion for a new trial nisi additur.Â  Thereafter, the trial court granted the new trial nisi additur on damages alone in the amount of $357,469.31 and denied Peoplesâ€™ motion for a new trial.Â  This appeal followed.
STANDARD OF REVIEW
â€œWhen reviewing a ruling on a motion for directed verdict, we must view the evidence and all reasonable inferences in the light most favorable to the nonmoving party.â€Â  Hurd v. Williamsburg County, 363 S.C. 421, 426, 611 S.E.2d 488, 491 (2005).Â  â€œIf the evidence as a whole is susceptible of more than one reasonable inference, the trial judge must submit the case to the jury.â€Â  Id.Â  This Court will reverse the trial judgeâ€™s ruling on a directed verdict motion only where there is no evidence to support the ruling or where the ruling is controlled by an error of law.Â  Clark v. South Carolina Depâ€™t Pub. Safety, 362 S.C. 377, 382-83, 608 S.E.2d 573, 576 (2005).Â  â€œIn reviewing a directed verdict, this Court must determine whether a verdict for the party opposing the motion would have been reasonably possible under the facts.â€Â  Hanahan v. Simpson, 326 S.C. 140, 149, 485 S.E.2d 903, 908 (1997).Â  â€œThe issue must be submitted to a jury whenever there is material evidence tending to establish the issue in the mind of a reasonable juror.â€Â  Id.Â  
LAW/ANALYSIS
Peoples argues the trial court erred in granting a directed verdict to the Estate with respect to liability because there was ample evidence of Baldwinâ€™s own negligence, thereby creating a jury issue as to proximate cause.Â  We agree. 
Peoples presented evidence from which a jury could determine Baldwinâ€™s negligence caused the collision.Â  For instance, Jur testified at length that, in his expert opinion, Baldwin caused the collision by remaining in the right hand lane and driving his truck into the back of Peoplesâ€™ log truck.Â  Jur further testified the Estateâ€™s theory that Peopleâ€™s trailer swung out into the left lane was wrong, that the evidence showed the load did not swing, that Peoplesâ€™ truck would have had to hit the guard rail before the trailer could swing out into the left lane, and he was â€œabsolutely confident that there is no steer maneuver to the right thatÂ  . . . you can make that can get those logs to go in [the left] lane.â€Â  According to Jur, the collision â€œclearly occurred in the right-hand lane, no question about it.â€Â  In Jurâ€™s opinion, Peoplesâ€™ truck had been in Baldwinâ€™s line of sight for twenty-five seconds before the collision occurred, Baldwin could have brought his truck to a complete stop in 4.9 seconds, and Baldwin had plenty of time to stop or move his vehicle to the other lane to avoid the log truck.Â  When asked whether he had formed an opinion as to the cause of the accident, Jur replied â€œcertainly [for] some unknown reason, which I donâ€™t know the answer to, Mr. Baldwin ran into the back of Mr. Peoplesâ€™ truck.â€Â  Viewing the evidence and all inferences in the light most favorable to Peoples, a reasonable juror could determine the collision occurred as a result of Baldwinâ€™s negligence in failing to keep a proper lookout.
The Estate argues the determination of who caused the collision is irrelevant because the only reasonable inference from the evidence presented at trial is that Baldwin would not have died but for Peoplesâ€™ negligence.Â  In essence, the Estate argues Peoplesâ€™ negligence is the sole proximate cause of Baldwinâ€™s death.Â  We disagree.
â€œProximate cause requires proof of (1) causation in fact and (2) legal cause.â€Â  Bramlette v. Charter-Medical-Columbia, 302 S.C. 68, 72, 393 S.E.2d 914, 916 (1990).Â  Causation in fact is proved by establishing the injury would not have occurred â€˜but forâ€™ oneâ€™s negligence.Â  Hurd v. Williamsburg County, 363 S.C. 421, 428, 611 S.E.2d 488, 492 (2005).Â  Legal cause, on the other hand, is proved by establishing foreseeability.Â  Id.Â  An injury is foreseeable if it is the natural and probable consequence of a breach of duty.Â  Id.Â  With respect to legal cause our supreme court has held:

  [T]he touchstone of proximate cause in South Carolina is foreseeability.Â  Foreseeability of some injury from an act or omission is a prerequisite to its being a proximate cause of the injury for which recovery is sought.Â  The standard by which foreseeability is determined is that of looking to the natural and probable consequences of the complained of act.Â  While it is not necessary that the actor must have contemplated or could have anticipated the particular event which occurred, liability cannot rest on mere possibilities.Â  The actor cannot be charged with that which is unpredictable or that which could not be expected to happen.Â  In determining whether a consequence is one that is natural and probable, the actorâ€™s conduct must be viewed in the light of the attendant circumstances.Â  

Young v. Tide Craft, Inc., 270 S.C. 453, 462-63, 242 S.E.2d 671, 675- 76 (1978) (internal citations and punctuation omitted).Â  Proximate cause does not mean the sole cause.Â  Sims v. Hall, 357 S.C. 288, 299, 592 S.E.2d 315, 320 (Ct. App. 2003).Â  Oneâ€™s conduct can be a proximate cause if it was at least a direct, concurring cause of the injury.Â  Id.Â  
Ordinarily, the question of proximate cause is one of fact for the jury and the trial judgeâ€™s sole function in the matter is to determine whether particular conclusions are the only reasonable inferences that can be drawn from the evidence.Â  Hurd, 363 S.C. at 427-28, 611 S.E.2d at 492.Â  â€œA partyâ€™s negligence is the proximate cause only when, without the negligence, the injury could have been avoided or would not have happened.â€Â  Hamilton v. R & L Transfer, Inc., 361 S.C. 286, 290, 604 S.E.2d 397, 398 (Ct. App. 2004).Â  It is generally for the jury to determine whether the defendantâ€™s negligence was a concurring proximate cause of the plaintiffâ€™s injuries, and only when the evidence is susceptible of just one inference does proximate cause become a matter of law for the court.Â  Id.Â  â€œOnly in rare or exceptional cases may the issue of proximate cause be decided as a matter of law.â€Â  Bailey v. Segars, 346 S.C. 359, 367, 550 S.E.2d 910, 914 (Ct. App. 2001).Â  â€œIf there is a fair difference of opinion regarding whose act proximately caused the injury, then the question of proximate cause must be submitted to the jury.â€Â  Id.Â  â€œUnder South Carolinaâ€™s doctrine of comparative negligence, a plaintiff may only recover damages if his own negligence is not greater than that of the defendant.â€Â  Id.Â  â€œOrdinarily, comparing the plaintiffâ€™s negligence with the defendantâ€™s is a question of fact for the jury to decide.â€Â  Id.
Under the doctrine of comparative negligence, a plaintiff in a negligence action may recover damages if his negligence is not greater than that of the defendant.Â  Weaver v. Lentz, 348 S.C. 672, 684, 561 S.E.2d 360, 367 (Ct. App. 2002).Â  In such a case, the amount of the plaintiffâ€™s recovery is reduced in proportion to the amount of his negligence.Â  Id.Â  â€œGenerally, under a less than or equal to comparative negligence rule, determination of respective degrees of negligence attributable to the plaintiff and the defendant presents a question of fact for the jury, at least where conflicting inferences may be drawn.â€Â  Trivelas v. South Carolina Depâ€™t of Transp., 357 S.C. 545, 549-50, 593 S.E.2d 504, 506 (Ct. App. 2004).
There is evidence in the record before us that Baldwin failed to keep a proper look out, negligently running into the back of Peopleâ€™s truck, that his injury would not have occurred â€œbut forâ€ this negligence, and that his injury was foreseeable in that it was a natural and probable consequence of his negligence.Â  Considering all the facts and circumstances of this case, a reasonable jury could conclude Baldwinâ€™s conduct was at least a direct, concurring cause of his injury and therefore was a contributing proximate cause of his death.Â  At a minimum, the evidence created a jury issue as to comparative negligence of the two parties.Â  Because the evidence is susceptible of more than one reasonable inference, the grant of the Estateâ€™s motion for directed verdict on liability was error.Â Â Â Â  
CONCLUSION
Because we hold the trial court erred in directing a verdict in favor of the Estate on the issue of liability, we find it unnecessary to address the remaining issues on appeal.Â  For the foregoing reasons, the decision of the trial court is
REVERSED AND REMANDED.
HEARN, C.J., and HUFF and BEATTY, JJ., concur.

THIS OPINION HAS NO PRECEDENTIAL VALUE.Â  IT SHOULD NOT BE CITED OR RELIED ON AS PRECEDENT IN ANY PROCEEDING EXCEPT AS PROVIDED BY RULE 239(d)(2), SCACR.
THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Court of Appeals


  
    
      
        Amy N. Fennell and Thomas Lakelan Fennell, Appellants,
      
    
  

v.

  
    
      
        Lilly S. Filler, M.D., and Women Physicians Associates OB/GYN P.A., Respondents.
      
    
  


Appeal From Richland County
James R. Barber, III, Circuit Court Judge

Unpublished Opinion No. 2006-UP-039
Heard December 7, 2005 â€“ Filed January 18, 2006

AFFIRMED


  
    
      
        Charles L. Henshaw Jr., of Columbia, for Appellants.Â  
        Andrew F. Lindemann and Julius W. McKay, II, both of Columbia, for Respondents.
      
    
  

PER CURIAM:Â  Amy and Thomas Fennell appeal the trial courtâ€™s refusal to give a â€œsubsequent treating physicianâ€ charge following a jury verdict for the defendants in this medical malpractice action.Â  We affirm.Â  
FACTS
 In the summer of 1998, Amy Fennell began seeing Dr. Lilly Filler, an obstetrician and gynecologist, during Mrs. Fennellâ€™s first pregnancy.Â  On February 9, 1999, Dr. Filler induced delivery, and Mrs. Fennell gave birth to a healthy girl.Â  A few minutes after the birth, the placenta and other portions of afterbirth were delivered.Â  At that point, Mrs. Fennell began to hemorrhage.Â  Dr. Filler concluded Mrs. Fennellâ€™s bleeding was caused by a weak or tired uterus, also called uterine atony.Â  Mrs. Fennell was discharged from the hospital three days later.Â  
After returning home from the hospital, Mrs. Fennell began to experience excessive bleeding and pain in the abdominal area.Â  In April, Dr. Filler performed an ultrasound and saw pieces of afterbirth or â€œretained products of conceptionâ€ attached to Mrs. Fennellâ€™s uterus.Â  The next day, Dr. Filler performed a procedure known as a D&C to remove the retained products of conception.Â  Dr. Filler removed two pieces of retained products of conception, each about the size of a personâ€™s palm, that were described as â€œcalcifiedâ€ and â€œinfected.â€Â  
Approximately two months after the D&C, Dr. Donald Fylstra, a gynecologist at the Medical University of South Carolina, examined Mrs. Fennell and found no measurable endometrium in her uterus.[1]Â  Dr. Fylstra and Dr. Robert Kaufmann, a fertility specialist, administered hormones to Mrs. Fennell in an attempt to regrow her endometrial lining.Â  Some of Mrs. Fennellâ€™s endometrium returned, and there is a dispute as to whether it was enough to allow her to become pregnant again.Â  Dr. Fylstra and Dr. Kaufmann advised Mrs. Fennell that there was little chance she would become pregnant again and explained that a hysterectomy could relieve the pain she was experiencing.Â  Mrs. Fennell made the decision to undergo the procedure.Â  
In their medical malpractice action against Dr. Filler and Women Physicians Associates OB/GYN P.A., the Fennells claimed Dr. Filler breached the applicable standard of care in negligently failing to remove the products of conception from Mrs. Fennellâ€™s uterus after the birth. The Fennells claimed this failure was the proximate cause of the necessity for the D&C procedure and resulting damage to Mrs. Fennellâ€™s endometrium.Â  
A dispute also arose during the trial as to whether Mrs. Fennell had a functioning uterus at the time of her hysterectomy and whether enough had been done to medically justify the hysterectomy.Â  Dr. Fillerâ€™s expert, Dr. Mark Salley, testified to a reasonable degree of medical certainty that Mrs. Fennell could have become pregnant again had she not been given a hysterectomy.Â  
Because of this dispute, during trial the Fennells requested a â€œsubsequent treating physicianâ€ charge be given that would include the following language: 

  If an injured person uses ordinary care in selecting a subsequent physician for treatment of his or her injury, the law regards any aggravation of the original injury resulting from the negligent act of the subsequent physician as a part of the immediate and direct damages which naturally flow from the original injury.Â  

The trial court declined to include the requested charge in its jury instructions.Â  The trial court indicated its general charge on proximate cause and foreseeability was sufficient to instruct the jury on the principle of law contained in the requested charge.Â  No specific objection was raised to the general charge on proximate cause and foreseeability or the charges concerning damages as given by the trial court. Â 
The jury returned a verdict for Dr. Filler and her medical practice.Â  The Fennells were granted ten days to file post-trial motions.Â  The Fennells then filed a motion for a new trial that was subsequently denied.Â  This appeal followed.Â  
STANDARD OF REVIEW
â€œWhen instructing the jury, the trial court is required to charge only the current and correct law of South Carolina.â€Â  Cohens v. Atkins, 333 S.C. 345, 349, 509 S.E.2d 286, 289 (Ct. App. 1998).Â  The substance of the law is what must be instructed to the jury, not any particular verbiage. . . .Â  A jury charge that is substantially correct and covers the law does not require reversal.Â  Burroughs v. Worsham, 352 S.C. 382, 392, 574 S.E.2d 215, 220 (Ct. App. 2002).Â  When reviewing a jury charge for alleged error, the appellate court must consider the charge as a whole in light of the evidence and issues presented at trial.Â  Daves v. Cleary, 355 S.C. 216, 224, 584 S.E.2d 423, 427 (Ct. App. 2003).Â  â€œTo warrant reversal for refusal to give a requested instruction, the refusal must have not only been erroneous, but prejudicial as well.â€Â  Cohens, 333 S.C. at 349, 509 S.E.2d at 289 (quoting McCourt v. Abernathy, 318 S.C. 301, 306, 457 S.E.2d 603, 606 (1995)).Â  Furthermore, it is not error to refuse a request to charge when the substance of the request is included in the general instructions.Â  Brown v. Stewart, 348 S.C. 33, 53, 557 S.E.2d 676, 686 (Ct. App. 2001).Â  
LAW/ANALYSIS
The Fennells contend the trial court erred in failing to instruct the jury with a â€œsubsequent treating physicianâ€ charge.Â  We disagree. 
As a threshold matter, Dr. Filler contends this issue has not been preserved for appeal because the Fennells failed to move for a new trial on the basis of the requested jury instruction.Â  Instead the Fennellsâ€™ motion for a new trial was limited to relief under the thirteenth juror doctrine and the renewal of a mistrial motion made after Dr. Filler and the Fennellsâ€™ expert witness, Dr. March, rendered medical assistance to a juror in the courtroom.Â  Neither of the grounds raised in the motion for a new trial have been pursued on appeal.Â  
However, post-trial motions are not necessary to preserve issues that have been ruled upon at trial; they are used to preserve those that have been raised to the trial court, but not ruled upon.Â  Wilder Corp. v. Wilke, 330 S.C. 71, 77, 497 S.E.2d 731, 734 (1998); see also Hubbard v. Rowe, 192 S.C. 12, 19, 5 S.E.2d 187, 189 (1939) (finding that in matters of appeal, so far as it appears, all that is required is that the questions presented for decision must first have been fairly and properly raised in the trial court and passed upon by that court).Â  Furthermore, when a party requests a jury charge and after an opportunity for discussion the trial court declines to give the charge, it is unnecessary, in order to preserve the point on appeal, to renew the request or object to the failure to give the charge at the conclusion of the jury instructions.Â  Keaton v. Greenville Hosp. Sys., 334 S.C. 488, 494, 514 S.E.2d 570, 573 (1999) (citing State v. Johnson, 333 S.C. 62, 64 n.1, 508 S.E.2d 29, 30 n.1 (1998)); Nedrow v. Pruitt, 336 S.C. 668, 677, 521 S.E.2d 755, 760 (Ct. App. 1999).Â  In the instant case, a full discussion was held concerning the requested charge.Â  Each party was allowed to make arguments concerning the addition of the charge, and the trial court ruled on its use.Â  In addition, the Fennells reargued the issue after the jury had been charged, though the record is incomplete in this regard.Â  
Even though this issue is preserved for appeal, it fails on its merits.Â  The Fennells contend the failure to give the requested instruction was harmful because the jury did not know Dr. Filler could be liable for the harm inflicted by the subsequent treating physicians.Â  Several cases have concluded that the inclusion of an instruction such as the one requested is proper.Â  See Howard v. State Farm Mut. Auto. Ins. Co., 316 S.C. 445, 450-51, 450 S.E.2d 582, 585 (1994) (concluding that the trial judge properly gave instruction because damages by a subsequent treating physician would have â€œarisen fromâ€ accident as defined in PIP policy); Graham v. Whitaker, 282 S.C. 393, 399, 321 S.E.2d 40, 44 (1984) (finding that the trial judge properly submitted the issue of proximate cause to the jury where plaintiff fell in her physicianâ€™s office and was damaged by the negligence of a subsequent treating physician during a surgical procedure); Payton v. Kearse, 319 S.C. 188, 211, 460 S.E.2d 220, 233-34 (Ct. App. 1995), revâ€™d on other grounds, 329 S.C. 51, 495 S.E.2d 205 (1998) (determining that the trial judge properly submitted the issue of damages caused by a subsequent treating physician to the jury).Â  However, none of these cases require such a charge.
The trial court in the instant case properly instructed the jury on the issue of proximate cause.Â  Instead of charging the Fennellsâ€™ Request No. 1, the trial court stated that the same goal would be accomplished by charging proximate cause and foreseeability.Â  The trial court interspersed throughout its jury charge the following: 

  If by the lack of the required skill a physician fails to properly treat her patient so that the patient is injured or the condition is made worse than it would have been otherwise, then the physician will be liable for any injury proximately caused to the patient. . . . 
  Forseeability of some injury from a negligent act or omission is a requisite to itâ€™s [sic] being a proximate cause of the injury for which recovery is sought.Â  The standard by which forseeability is determined is by looking to the natural and probable consequences of the complained act.
  The defendant may be held liable for anything that appears to have been a natural and probable consequence of the defendantâ€™s negligence.
  Actual damages include compensation for all injuries which are naturally the proximate result of the alleged wrongful conduct of the defendant.

Considering the charge as a whole, these jury instructions clearly indicate that all injuries foreseeably flowing from any negligent acts of Dr. Filler are to be attributed to her.Â  The instruction as given embodies the same legal theory as that found in the requested instruction even though it may be somewhat less specific.Â  
Even assuming that the refusal to give the requested charge was error, it was not prejudicial.Â  Because the jury returned a general verdict for Dr. Filler with no damages, the only conclusion to be drawn is that the jury found Dr. Filler had not been negligent.[2]Â  To reverse a case for a failure to include a jury instruction pertaining solely to damages when no negligence was found would be improper.Â  
CONCLUSION
For the reasons stated herein, the trial courtâ€™s decision is 
AFFIRMED.Â  
STILWELL, KITTREDGE, and WILLIAMS, JJ., concur.

[1] Â Functional endometrium is necessary to accept, nourish, and grow a fertilized egg into a baby.Â  
[2] The Fennells contended at oral argument that they only sought damages for Mrs. Fennellâ€™s loss of childbearing capacity.Â  Consequently, they argue, the jury could have awarded a defense verdict because it did not understand that Dr. Filler could be held liable for those particular damages.Â  The record reveals, however, that Mrs. Fennellâ€™s physical pain, resulting from the retained products of conception and the D&C procedure, was also a possible element of damages.Â  Under these circumstances, it appears that a defense verdict was necessarily premised on a finding of no negligence.

THIS OPINION HAS NO PRECEDENTIAL VALUE.  IT SHOULD NOT BE CITED OR RELIED ON AS 
 PRECEDENT IN ANY PROCEEDING EXCEPT AS PROVIDED BY RULE 239(d)(2), SCACR.
THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Court of Appeals


  
    
      
The State, Respondent,
v.
Willie Lee Hagood, Appellant.
      
    
  


Appeal From Pickens County
Â Henry F. Floyd, Circuit Court Judge

Unpublished Opinion No. 2006-UP-043
Submitted December 1, 2005 â€“ Filed January 18, 2006

AFFIRMED


  
Senior Assistant Appellate Defender Wanda H. Carter, of Columbia, for Appellant.
Attorney General Henry Dargan McMaster, Chief Deputy Attorney General John W. McIntosh, Assistant Deputy Attorney General Salley W. Elliott
Assistant Attorney General David A. Spencer, all of Columbia; and Solicitor Robert M. Ariail, of Greenville, for Respondent.
  

PER CURIAM:Â  Willie Lee Hagood appeals his conviction for second-degree criminal sexual conduct, arguing the trial court abused its discretion in admitting portions of the victimâ€™s medical records into evidence.Â  We affirm.[1]
FACTS
Hagood was arrested and indicted for second-degree criminal sexual conduct.Â  The indictment alleged Hagood sexually assaulted a twenty-year-old male.Â  At trial, Hagood argued the sex was consensual.Â  The State maintained Hagood raped the victim and presented expert testimony to discredit Hagoodâ€™s version of the events.Â  
At trial, the State sought to introduce pictures of the victimâ€™s anus to corroborate the testimony of the medical examiner, to show the severity of the victimâ€™s injuries, and to contradict Hagoodâ€™s claim of consensual sex.Â  The trial court admitted the pictures, finding their probative value outweighed any prejudicial effect.Â  At the close of the evidence, the jury found Hagood guilty and sentenced him to sixteen years.Â  Hagood appeals.
LAW/ANALYSIS
Hagood argues the trial court abused its discretion in admitting portions of the victimâ€™s medical records into evidence.Â  However, the State alleges Hagood did not preserve this issue for appellate review because he did not procure a final ruling on the record.Â  We hold the issue was properly preserved, but we find the trial court did not abuse its discretion in admitting the evidence.
Unless an objection is made at the time the evidence is offered and a final ruling made, the issue is not preserved for review.Â  State v. Shumpert, 312 S.C. 502, 507, 435 S.E.2d 859, 862 (2003).Â  However, where the motion is ruled on immediately prior to the introduction of the evidence in question, no further objection is necessary.Â  State v. Tufts, 355 S.C. 493, 497, 585 S.E.2d 523, 525 (Ct. App. 2003); State v. Mueller, 319 S.C. 266, 268-69, 460 S.E.2d 409, 410-11 (Ct. App. 1995).Â  
Here, it is clear that the trial courtâ€™sÂ  decision, reached after in camera testimony and lengthy arguments with counsel, was a final ruling.Â  Moreover, immediately after the trial court ruled, the State called the medical examiner to the stand, and elicited testimony in front of the jury.Â  Because there was no opportunity for the trial court to change itâ€™s ruling, we find that Hagoodâ€™s in camera objections preserved the issue for appellate review.Â  Therefore, we now turn to the merits of Hagoodâ€™s appeal.
The admission or exclusion of evidence is left to the sound discretion of the trial court.Â  State v. Gaster, 349 S.C. 545, 557, 564 S.E.2d 87, 93 (2002).Â  The trial courtâ€™s ruling on the admissibility of evidence will not be reversed absent an abuse of discretion or the commission of legal error that results in prejudice to the defendant.Â  State v. Adams, 354 S.C. 361, 377, 580 S.E.2d 785, 793 (Ct. App. 2003).Â  Evidence should be excluded when its probative value is outweighed by its prejudicial effect.Â  State v. Kelley, 319 S.C. 173, 460 S.E.2d 368 (1995).Â  â€œA trial judge has considerable latitude in ruling on the admissibility of evidence and his rulings will not be disturbed absent a showing of probable prejudice.â€Â  Kelley, 319 S.C. at 173, 460 S.E.2d at 370).Â  The determination of relevancy and materiality of a photograph is left to the sound discretion of the trial judge. Â Kelley, 319 S.C. at 173, 460 S.E.2d at 370.Â  â€œPhotographs calculated to arouse the sympathy or prejudice of the jury should be excluded if they are irrelevant or not necessary to substantiate material facts or conditions.â€ Â State v. Middleton, 288 S.C. 21, 339 S.E.2d 692 (1986).
We find no abuse of discretion in the trial courtâ€™s admission of the picture of the victimâ€™s anus into evidence.Â  Hagood claimed the intercourse was consensual, and that he and the victim had consensual anal sex on five separate occasions in the month prior to the assault.Â  The Stateâ€™s expert medical examiner testified the condition of the victimâ€™s anus was inconsistent with a person who would have had consensual anal intercourse five times in a month.Â  The picture helped illustrate the examinerâ€™s testimony and was probative in helping the jury understand how the medical testimony rebutted the claims of Hagood.Â  
Hagood also alleges the pictures were unnecessary as the testimony adequately conveyed the severity of the victimâ€™s injuries.Â  We disagree.Â  The photographs supported the testimony of the medical examiner and were relevant to the nature of the crime.Â  The State used the photographs to establish that sex was not consensual as alleged by Hagood. These photographs merely corroborated the testimony of the medical examiner concerning how the injuries sustained by the victim were inconsistent with consensual sex.Â  We agree with the trial courtâ€™s finding that the photographs were neither prejudicial nor inflammatory.Â  Accordingly, we find the trial court did not abuse its discretion.
CONCLUSION
For the aforementioned reasons, the conviction is hereby
AFFIRMED.
HEARN, C.J., HUFF and BEATTY, J.J., concur.

[1] We decide this case without oral arguments pursuant to Rule 215, SCACR.

text:
THIS OPINION HAS NO PRECEDENTIAL VALUE.  IT SHOULD NOT BE CITED OR RELIED ON AS
PRECEDENT IN ANY PROCEEDING EXCEPT AS PROVIDED BY RULE 239(d)(2), SCACR.
THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Court of Appeals


  
    
      
Kenneth L. Amerson, Personal Representative of the Estate of Sallie Louise A. Newsome,
Appellant,
v.
Gena Phillips Ervin, as Personal Representative of the Estate of Harley A. Newsome; Christine N.
Tolson, Individually and as Conservator for Sallie Louise A. Newsome, deceased; Cely Baker Reynolds, as Guardian ad Litem for Sallie Louise A. Newsome, deceased; John H. Newsome, Sr.; and John H. Newsome Jr.,
Defendants,
Of Whom Christine N. Tolson, John H. Newsome, Sr., and John H. Newsome Jr. are the
Respondents.
      
    
  


Appeal From Darlington County
Â J. Michael Baxley, Circuit Court Judge

Unpublished Opinion No.Â  2006-UP-044
Submitted December 1, 2005 â€“ Filed January 18, 2006Â 

AFFIRMED


  
    
      
Walter B. Todd, Jr. and J. Derrick Jackson, both of Columbia, for Appellant.
David Craig Brown, R. Wayne Byrd,and Julie J. Moose, all of Florence, for Respondents.
      
    
  

PER CURIAM:Â  Kenneth Amerson, personal representative of Sallie Louise A. Newsomeâ€™s estate, contends the trial court erred in granting summary judgment on his claims for constructive trust and civil conspiracy as well as on his claim to set aside deeds against John H. Newsome, Sr. and John H. Newsome, Jr.Â  In addition, Amerson appeals the dismissal with prejudice of his claims against the remaining defendants for a constructive trust and to set aside the deeds.Â  We affirm.[1]Â  
FACTS
On September 1, 1998, Harley Newsome (Harley) died testate.Â  Harley was survived by his wife Sallie Newsome (Sallie).Â  Harleyâ€™s will named Sallie as his sole beneficiary and the executrix of his estate. However, Sallie was suffering from Alzheimerâ€™s disease and was placed in a nursing home immediately following Harleyâ€™s death.Â  Gena Phillips Ervin, an attorney, was appointed personal representative of the estate.Â  Christine Tolson, Harleyâ€™s sister, was appointed as conservator for Sallie.Â  Cely Baker Reynolds, also an attorney, was appointed as attorney and guardian ad litem for Sallie.Â  
On January 12, 1999, Ervin filed a petition for the sale of three parcels of real property to John H. Newsome, Sr. and John H. Newsome, Jr. (the Newsomes) and Tolson.Â  The petition stated Sallie was in a nursing home, and she would need the proceeds from the sale to provide for her continuing welfare and needs.Â  The petition was supported by an appraisal by Everett Johnson Realty valuing the property as farmland for a value of $88,800.Â  Sallie, through Tolson and Reynolds, was served with notice of the petition and filed answers making no objections to the sale of the property.Â  On January 14, 1999, the Honorable Marvin I. Lawson issued an order for the sale of real property (the January 14, 1999 Order) stating â€œit is in the best interests of the Estate of Harley and Sallie Newsome to sell the real property.â€Â  
On March 8, 1999, Sallie died without a will, leaving one sister, nieces, and nephews as her intestate heirs.Â  Kenneth L. Amerson, the spouse of one of Sallieâ€™s nieces, was appointed as personal representative of Sallieâ€™s estate.Â  Upon learning of the previous sale of the property, Amerson had the property reappraised by Robert Christopher who valued the property as commercial land for a value of $263,200.Â  On September 30, 1999, Amerson filed a Rule 60(b) motion seeking to set aside the January 14, 1999 Order on the grounds the final judgment of the probate court was based on mistake and misrepresentation.Â  The Newsomes then filed a motion to intervene, which was subsequently granted.Â Â  
On August 16, 2000, a hearing was held, and Judge Lawson entered an order (the October 4, 2000 Order) denying the Rule 60(b) motion on the ground that no mistake or misrepresentation existed which would warrant setting aside the January 14, 1999 Order. Amerson appealed this order to the circuit court stating the following grounds:Â  

1.Â  The probate court committed an error of law in failing to recognize and rule on the alleged conflict of interest and breach of the duty of loyalty from the estate and devised to Sallie for less than fair market value. 
2.Â  The probate court committed an error of law in failing to consider whether the interests of Sallie were properly represented in the sale of the properties. 
3.Â  The probate court committed an error of law in ignoring an established misrepresentation concerning fair market value of the properties. 
4.Â  The probate court committed an error of fact in concluding the properties were not undervalued. 
5.Â  The probate court committed an error of law and fact in concluding the sale of the properties was in the best interests of Sallie.Â  

On August 20, 2001 the Honorable Ernest Kinard entered an order (the August 20, 2001 Order), affirming the probate courtâ€™s order.Â  This court subsequently affirmed the circuit courtâ€™s order. In the Matter of the Estate of Newsome v. Amerson,Â Â  Op. No. 2003-UP-475 (S.C. Ct. App. filed July 30, 2003).Â  
Amerson commenced this action on April 22, 2002 against the various defendants.Â  The causes of action alleged against the Newsomes included constructive trust, civil conspiracy, and an equitable action to set aside the deeds.Â  The Newsomes filed a motion to dismiss pursuant to Rule 12(b)(6), SCRCP, or in the alternative for summary judgment pursuant to Rule 56, SCRCP.Â  
The trial court granted summary judgment to the Newsomes as to all causes of action.Â  Further, it dismissed with prejudice the causes of action for constructive trust and to set aside deeds as to all defendants.Â  Amersonâ€™s first three causes of action against the other defendants were unaffected by the order.Â  The trial court gave numerous reasons for its conclusion, including the following:Â  the case is barred due to a previous Rule 60(b) motion which was denied; barred as Amerson cannot establish the elements of an independent action; barred as a collateral attack of the probate order; barred by the doctrines of res judicata and collateral estoppel; barred as extrinsic fraud cannot be alleged; and finally, barred as untimely.Â  This appeal followed.Â  
STANDARD OF REVIEW 
When reviewing the grant of a summary judgment motion, appellate courts apply the same standard which governs the trial court under Rule 56(c), SCRCP, which states that summary judgment is proper when there is no genuine issue as to any material fact and the moving party is entitled to judgment as a matter of law.Â  Rule 56(c), SCRCP; Helms Realty, Inc. v. Gibson-Wall Co., 363 S.C. 334, 340, 611 S.E.2d 485, 488 (2005).Â  On appeal from an order granting summary judgment, the appellate court will review all ambiguities, conclusions, and inferences arising in and from the evidence in a light most favorable to the non-moving party below.Â  Willis v. Wu, 362 S.C. 146, 150-51, 607 S.E.2d 63, 65 (2004); see also Schmidt v. Courtney, 357 S.C. 310, 317, 592 S.E.2d 326, 330 (Ct. App. 2003) (stating all ambiguities,
conclusions, and inferences arising from the evidence must be construed most strongly against the moving party).
Additionally, under Rule 12(b)(6), SCRCP, a defendant may make a motion to dismiss based upon the plaintiffâ€™s failure to state a claim constituting a cause of action. Baird v. Charleston County, 333 S.C. 519, 527, 511 S.E.2d 69, 73 (1999).Â  The trial judge may dismiss the claim if the defendant demonstrates the plaintiff has failed â€œto state facts sufficient to constitute a cause of actionâ€ in the pleadings filed with the court.Â  Williams v. Condon, 347 S.C. 227, 232-33, 553 S.E.2d 496, 499 (Ct. App. 2001) (quoting Rule 12(b)(6), SCRCP).Â  When considering the motion to dismiss for failure to state a claim, the trial court must base its ruling solely upon the allegations made on the face of the complaint.Â  Baird, at 527, 511 S.E.2d at 73; Stiles v. Onorato, 318 S.C. 297, 300, 457 S.E.2d 601, 602-03 (1995).Â  If inferences drawn from the facts alleged on the complaint would entitle the plaintiff to relief on any theory, then the
grant of a motion to dismiss for failure to state a claim is improper.Â  Brown v. Leverette, 291 S.C. 364, 366, 353 S.E.2d 697, 698 (1987); McCormick v. England, 328 S.C. 627, 632-33, 494 S.E.2d 431, 433 (Ct. App. 1997).Â  The facts and inferences alleged in the complaint are viewed in the light most favorable to the plaintiff.Â  Toussaint v. Ham, 292 S.C. 415, 416, 357 S.E.2d 8, 9 (1987); Cowart v. Poore, 337 S.C. 359, 364, 523 S.E.2d 182, 184-85 (Ct. App. 1999).Â  
LAW/ANALYSIS
I.Â  Grant of Summary Judgment and Dismissal with Prejudice  
Amerson contends the trial court erred in granting summary judgment to the Newsomes and in dismissing with prejudice the causes of action for constructive trust and to set aside deeds as to all defendants.Â  We disagree.Â  
Â â€œThe doctrine of res adjudicata (or res judicata) in the strict sense of that time-honored Latin phrase had its origin in the principle that it is in the public interest that there should be an end of litigation and that no one should be twice sued for the same cause of action.â€ First Natâ€™l Bank v. United States Fid. & Guar. Co., 207 S.C. 15, 24, 35 S.E.2d 47, 56
(1945). Under this doctrine, a final judgment on the merits in a prior action will conclude the parties and their privies in a second action based on the same claim as to the issues actually litigated and as to issues that might have been litigated in the first action. Sub-Zero Freezer Co. v. R.J. Clarkson Co., 308 S.C. 188, 190-91, 417 S.E.2d 569, 571 (1992); Foran v. USAA Cas. Ins. Co., 311 S.C. 189, 190-91, 427 S.E.2d 918, 919 (Ct. App. 1993).
The doctrine provides that an existing final judgment rendered upon the merits, without fraud or collusion, by a court of competent jurisdiction, is conclusive of the rights, questions, and facts in issue as to the parties and their privies.Â  Griggs v. Griggs, 214 S.C. 177, 185, 51 S.E.2d 622, 627-28 (1949).Â  If the rights asserted in the second action existed at the time when the judgment was entered in the first action, res judicata will operate as a bar to the second action.Â  Plum Creek Dev. Co. v. City of Conway, 334 S.C. 30, 34, 512 S.E.2d 106, 109 (1999).Â  
Furthermore, res judicata bars subsequent actions by the same parties when the claims arise out of the same transaction or occurrence that was the subject of a prior action between these parties.Â  Id. at 34, 512 S.E.2d at 109; Rogers v. Kunja Knitting Mills, U.S.A., 336 S.C. 533, 537, 520 S.E.2d 815, 817 (Ct. App. 1999).Â  Res judicata prevents a litigant â€œfrom raising any issues which were adjudicated in the former suit and any issues which might have been raised in the former suit.â€ Hilton Head Ctr. of South Carolina, Inc. v. Pub. Serv. Commâ€™n of South Carolina, 294 S.C. 9, 11, 362 S.E.2d 176, 177 (1987). â€œRes judicata is the branch of the law that defines the effect a valid judgment may have on subsequent litigation between the same parties and their privies.Â  Res judicata
ends litigation, promotes judicial economy and avoids the harassment of relitigation of the same issues.â€ James F. Flanagan, South Carolina Civil Procedure 642 (2d ed. 1996).
To establish res judicata, the defendant must prove three elements: (1) identity of the parties; (2) identity of the subject matter; and (3) adjudication of the issue in the former suit. Sealy v. Dodge, 289 S.C. 543, 545, 347 S.E.2d 504, 505 (1986); Rogers, 336 S.C. at 537, 520 S.E.2d at 817; Owenby v. Owens Corning Fiberglas, 313 S.C. 181, 183, 437 S.E.2d 130, 131 (Ct. App. 1993); see also Nunnery v. Brantley Constr. Co., 289 S.C. 205, 209, 345 S.E.2d 740, 742-43 (Ct. App. 1986) (stating the following elements must be shown in order to establish the plea of res judicata: (1) The parties must be the same or their privies; (2) the subject matter must be the same; and (3) while generally the precise point must be ruled upon, yet where the parties are the same or are in privity the judgment is an absolute bar not only of what was decided but of what might have been decided). Even when the defendant meets all of the required elements, res judicata
will not be applied â€œwhere it will contravene other important public policies; the courts must weigh the competing public policies.â€ Johns v. Johns, 309 S.C. 199, 203, 420 S.E.2d 856, 859 (Ct. App. 1992).Â 
Additionally, â€œ[f]or a judgment to bar the maintenance of a subsequent action, there must be identity of the cause of action as well as
identity of the subject matter.â€ Nunnery, at 209, 345 S.E.2d at 743. If it is doubtful whether a second action is for the same cause of action as the first, the test generally applied is to consider the identity of facts essential to their maintenance, or whether the same evidence would sustain both. Griggs, at 185, 51 S.E.2d at 627-28 (1949). When applying the principle of res judicata, a fundamental test used for comparing causes of action is to determine whether the primary right and duty and the wrong are the same in each action. Nunnery, at 209, 345 S.E.2d at 743.
The instant action comes on the heels of a previous Rule 60(b), SCRCP motion in the probate court to set aside the sale of real property on the grounds of mistake or misrepresentation.Â  The probate court denied Amersonâ€™s motion, the circuit court affirmed, and this court later affirmed.Â  In the Matter of the Estate of Newsome v. Amerson,Â Â  Op. No. 2003-UP-475 (S.C. Ct. App. filed July 30, 2003).Â  In that initial appeal, Amerson contended the probate court erred in denying his Rule 60(b) motion because the sale price was so far below the fair market value that it shocked the conscience, and Amerson also argued that breaches of fiduciary duty by Tolson, Ervin, and Reynolds required invalidation of the sale.Â  Amerson now seeks to circumvent the previous rulings with this action. 
In this case, the identities of the parties are the same as in the first action, the subject matter is the same, the factual and legal issues are the same, the alleged bases for the plaintiffâ€™s claims as to the Newsomes are the same, and there was a prior adjudication of the same issues by a court of competent jurisdiction.Â  Amerson is barred from pursuing any clams for civil conspiracy as to the Newsomes and any claims for constructive trust and to set aside the deeds as to all defendants because the claims were previously litigated or could have been litigated in his original Rule 60(b) motion.[2]Â  These claims are barred by res judicata, and the grant of summary judgment and order of dismissal with prejudice should be affirmed.[3]Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â  
II. Civil Conspiracy Claim 
Amerson contends the trial judge erred in granting summary judgment to the Newsomes for the civil conspiracy claim, while allowing him to proceed on the claim against all other defendants.Â  We disagree.Â  
A civil conspiracy is a combination of two or more persons joining for the purpose of injuring the plaintiff and causing special damage to the plaintiff. Yaeger v. Murphy, 291 S.C. 485, 487, 354 S.E.2d 393, 394 (Ct. App. 1987).Â  The October 4, 2000 Order denying the Rule 60(b) motion conclusively determined there was no plan or conspiracy on the part of Tolson and the Newsomes to purchase the property below market value. The probate court acknowledged that the gravamen of Amersonâ€™s complaint was a plan or conspiracy on the part of Tolson and the Newsomes to purchase the property at below market value.Â Â  The probate court went on to state the reasons why such a notion was unsubstantiated and ends with the statement that â€œI find that there exists in this matter no mistake or misrepresentationâ€ that would warrant setting aside the order for the sale of the property.Â  
For the reasons applicable to the causes of action for constructive trust and to set aside deeds, i.e. res judicata, Amersonâ€™s civil conspiracy cause of action as to the Newsomes must be dismissed.Â  Amerson asserts the same facts and acts in support of the civil conspiracy and other causes of action against the Newsomes.Â  Though it is unclear why the trial court maintained the civil conspiracy cause of action for the other defendants, the grant of summary judgment to the Newsomes does not preclude Amerson from pursuing the claim against the other defendants.Â  There is no genuine issue of material fact, and the Newsomes are entitled to summary judgment.[4]Â  
CONCLUSION
Based upon the foregoing, the trial courtâ€™s order is
 AFFIRMED.
HEARN, C.J., and HUFF and BEATTY, JJ. concur.

[1] We decide this case without oral argument pursuant to Rule 215, SCACR.
[2] This conclusion is only bolstered by Amersonâ€™s admission in his brief that the previous appeal, had it been reversed, would have made this case moot.Â  
[3] Although the doctrines of res judicata and collateral estoppel do not bar a collateral attack of a judgment based on extrinsic fraud, we note that only intrinsic fraud is alleged in this case. Â Evans v. Gunter, 294 S.C. 525, 529, 366 S.E.2d 44, 46 (Ct. App. 1988).Â  Extrinsic fraud is collateral or external to the trial of the matter, while intrinsic fraud goes to the merits of the proceeding.Â  In this case, Amerson alleges a conspiracy between the other parties to defraud Sallie and her heirs.Â  This goes to the heart of the property matter and was fully presented and considered in the previous Rule 60(b) motion.Â  Furthermore, because the alleged actions were based on intrinsic fraud, they are barred because they were filed after January 15, 2000, and Rule 60(b) provides that actions for relief from an order based upon mistake, fraud, misrepresentation, or other misconduct of an adverse party must be filed not more than one year after the order was entered. Rule 60(b), SCRCP.
[4] Because we find the doctrine of res judicata supports the trial courtâ€™s decision to grant summary judgment in favor of the Newsomes, we need not address Amersonâ€™s arguments pertaining to the trial courtâ€™s alternative reasons in support of summary judgment.Â  See Futch v. McAllister Towing of Georgetown, Inc., 335 S.C. 598, 613, 518 S.E.2d 591, 598 (1999) (explaining that the appellate court need not address remaining issues when disposition of prior issues is dispositive).

THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA

        Robert Jay Lagroon, Appellant.
      
    
  


Appeal from McCormick County
Â Berry L. Mobley, Family Court Judge

Unpublished Opinion No. 2006-UP-046
Submitted January 6, 2006 â€“ Filed January 20, 2006Â Â  

AFFIRMED


  
    
      
        Robert Jay Lagroon, of Williamston, pro se.

PER CURIAM:Â  Robert Jay Lagroon appeals an order of the family court denying his motion to reconsider.Â  On appeal, Lagroon argues his consent to a child custody and child support agreement was not voluntary because he took an over-the-counter drug before the hearing, his attorney forced him to enter into the agreement under duress, and his attorney misled him to enter into the agreement.Â  In addition, Husband argues the family court erred in preventing him from using an audiotape of his conversations with his attorneys to prove the actual agreement to which he consented.Â  We affirm pursuant to Rule 220(b)(1), SCACR, and the following authorities: Forsythe v. Forsythe, 290 S.C. 253, 349 S.E.2d 405 (Ct. App. 1986) (holding when a party affirms the validity of a settlement agreement in family court, that party cannot later challenge the order incorporating it for lack of volition); Hickman v. Hickman, 301 S.C. 455, 457, 392 S.E.2d 481, 482 (1990) (holding an argument is not preserved for review when it is presented to the court for the first time in a motion to alter or amend the judgment pursuant to Rule 59(e), SCRCP).Â Â  
AFFIRMED. [1]
HEARN, C.J., HUFF and BEATTY, JJ., concur.

THIS OPINION HAS NO PRECEDENTIAL VALUE.Â  IT SHOULD NOT BE CITED OR RELIED ON AS PRECEDENT IN ANY PROCEEDING EXCEPT AS PROVIDED BY RULE 239(d)(2), SCACR.
THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Court of Appeals


  
    
      
        Tammy Rowe, Appellant,
      
    
  

v.

  
    
      
        Advance America, Cash Advance Center & Loletta â€œBuffyâ€ Grant, Respondents.
      
    
  


Appeal From Marlboro County
Paul M. Burch, Circuit Court Judge

Unpublished Opinion No. 2006-UP-047
Submitted December 1, 2005 â€“ Filed January 20, 2006

APPEAL DISMISSED


  
    
      
        Bonnie Travaglio Hunt and Chalmers Carey Johnson, both of Charleston, for Appellant. 
        Robert L. Widener and Richard J. Morgan, both of Columbia, for Respondents.
      
    
  

PER CURIAM:Â  Tammy Rowe appeals the trial courtâ€™s order of dismissal.Â  We dismiss the appeal as untimely.[1]Â  
FACTS
In March 2003, Tammy Rowe sued her former employer, Advance America, Cash Advance Center, for wrongful retention of wages, negligent supervision, breach of employment contract, and civil conspiracy.Â  In addition, she filed suit for slander, false imprisonment, emotional distress, assault and battery, and civil conspiracy against her former co-worker, Loletta Grant.Â  Advance America and Grant (Respondents) filed a motion to dismiss for failure to state a claim under Rule 12(b)(6), SCRCP.Â  On July 15, 2003, following a hearing, the trial court granted Respondentsâ€™ motion to dismiss as follows:

  Upon hearing arguments by Counsel and review of the Complaint it appears to the Court that the Complaint needs to be redrafted.Â  Therefore - Motion to Dismiss is granted without prejudice and Plaintiff may file an Amended Summons and Complaint within thirty (30) days.Â  And IT IS SO ORDERED.

On August 26, 2003, Rowe filed an amended complaint.Â  Respondents again filed a motion to dismiss.Â  The trial court dismissed the amended complaint with prejudice for Roweâ€™s failure to abide by the thirty day deadline set in the July 15, 2003 order.Â  
On October 20, 2003, Rowe filed a motion entitled â€œPlaintiffâ€™s Motion for Reconsideration,â€ setting forth numerous grounds for â€œrelief from Judgment or Order under Rule 60â€ or â€œsetting aside the Order.â€Â  The court denied the motion.Â  Rowe appeals.
LAW/ANALYSIS
 Roweâ€™s appeal to this court is not timely and must therefore be dismissed.[2]Â  When a Rule 59(e), SCRCP, motion for reconsideration is made, â€œ[t]he time for appeal for all parties shall be stayed . . . and shall run from the receipt of written notice of entry of the order granting or denying such motions.â€Â  Rule 59(e), SCRCP. Â A motion made under Rule 60, SCRCP, however, does not toll the running of the time for appeal.Â  Otten v. Otten, 287 S.C. 166, 167, 337 S.E.2d 207, 208 (1985).Â     

  We find Roweâ€™s motion was a Rule 60 motion to set aside the order rather than a Rule 59(e) motion for reconsideration.Â  It is a well-recognized legal concept in South Carolina that motions should be treated based on substance and effect as opposed to how they are styled by the moving party.Â  See Mickle v. Blackmon, 255 S.C. 136, 140, 177 S.E.2d 548, 549 (1970).Â  The court must examine the relief sought to understand the true nature of the pleading.Â  See Standard Fed. Sav. & Loan Assâ€™n v. Mungo, 306 S.C. 22, 26, 410 S.E.2d 18, 20 (Ct. App. 1991) (stating it is the substance of the relief sought that matters â€œregardless of the form in which the request for relief was framedâ€).
Although Roweâ€™s motion was captioned â€œPlaintiffâ€™s Motion for Reconsideration,â€ the motion indicates that it is being made under Rule 60 rather than Rule 59.Â  The substance of the motion is the contention that the trial court erred in granting the previous motion to dismiss without a hearing.Â  The prayer for relief seeks to have the order set aside.Â  If the trial court had granted the relief sought, it would not have merely altered or amended the previous order, but would have set it aside in its entirety.Â  It would then have been appropriate to hold a hearing on the merits of the motion that resulted in the order dismissing the amended complaint.Â  Consequently, we conclude that the motion was in sum and substance a Rule 60 motion. 
Because we find the motion was made under Rule 60, we hold Roweâ€™s appeal to this court is not timely. Â The notice of appeal in a civil action must be served on all respondents within thirty days following receipt of written notice of entry of the order or judgment.Â  Rule 203(b)(1), SCACR.Â  The requirement of service of the notice of appeal is jurisdictional.Â  Elam v. South Carolina Depâ€™t of Transp., 361 S.C. 9, 14-15, 602 S.E.2d 772, 775 (2004).Â  â€œ[I]f a party misses the deadline, the appellate court lacks jurisdiction to consider the appeal and has no authority or discretion to â€˜rescueâ€™ the delinquent party by extending or ignoring the deadline for service of the notice.â€Â  Id.Â  Rowe filed the motion in October of 2003.Â  She therefore had written notice of the dismissal order on or before that date.Â  She did not serve her notice of appeal to this court until November of 2004.Â  The appeal is therefore untimely under the South Carolina Rules of Appellate Procedure.
CONCLUSION
Because Roweâ€™s appeal is untimely, it is hereby
DISMISSED.
 STILWELL, KITTREDGE, and WILLIAMS, JJ., concur.

[1] Â We decide this case without oral argument pursuant to Rule 215, SCACR.Â Â Â Â  
[2] Â Because we find Roweâ€™s appeal untimely, we do not address the merits of the appeal.

THIS OPINION HAS NO PRECEDENTIAL VALUE.Â  IT SHOULD NOT BE CITED OR RELIED ON AS PRECEDENT IN ANY PROCEEDING EXCEPT AS PROVIDED BY RULE 239(d)(2), SCACR. 
THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Court of Appeals


  
    
      
        James M. Rodriquez and Lise Rodriguez, Appellants,
      
    
  

v.

  
    
      
        Eugene A. Eline, M.D., Lowcountry Bone & Joint Surgery, P.A., Lowcountry Medical Group, LLC., and Beaufort Memorial Hospital,
      
    
  


Appeal From Beaufort County
Â Jackson V. Gregory, Circuit Court Judge

Unpublished Opinion No. 2006-UP-048
Submitted December 1, 2005 â€“ Filed January 20, 2006Â Â Â  

DISMISSED IN PART and AFFIRMED IN PART


  
    
      
        Terry Wayne Yarbrough, of Beaufort; for Appellants.
        John K. Blincow, Jr. and R. Gerald Chambers, of Charleston; Mary Bass Lohr and James S. Gibson, of Beaufort; for Respondents.
      
    
  

PER CURIAM:Â  This appeal stems from injuries James M. Rodriguez alleges to have suffered after Dr. Eugene A. Eline performed surgery on Rodriguezâ€™s back at Beaufort Memorial Hospital.Â Â  Rodriguez and his wife appeal the trial courtâ€™s grant of summary judgment in favor of the Hospital.Â  Rodriguez also appeals the trial courtâ€™s grant of a directed verdict in favor of Dr. Eline on Rodriguezâ€™s causes of action for lack of informed consent and battery.Â  Finally, the Rodriguezes appeal the trial courtâ€™s denial of their motions for judgment not withstanding the verdict and new trial.Â  We dismiss in part and affirm in part.
FACTS
James Rodriguez first injured his back in January of 1996 when he lifted a chain-link fence while working as a driver for Coastal Mental Health.Â  He was diagnosed with a herniated disk, and Dr. Rhodin, who had treated Rodriguezâ€™s wife for many years, provided treatment.Â  Rodriguezâ€™s pain gradually improved, but in December of 1997, he re-injured his back while lifting a sink.Â  The pain from the injury was severe, and Dr. Rhodin referred Rodriguez to Dr. Eline, a board certified orthopedic surgeon.Â  
At the recommendation of Dr. Eline, Rodriguez underwent surgery on April 2, 1998. Initially, Rodriguezâ€™s condition seemed to improve, but in June, Rodriguez stood up suddenly and experienced a severe shooting pain in his left leg.Â  He reported this pain to Dr. Eline, who ordered an MRI.Â  After reviewing the results, Dr. Eline recommended fusing a section of Rodriguezâ€™s spine to prevent further disk problems and to promote stability.Â  Rodriguez admits Dr. Eline told him of the risks and benefits of surgery before the procedure was performed.
Rodriguez underwent this fusion surgery on September 24, 1998. To perform the fusion, Dr. Eline removed the disk that was degenerated and replaced it with a BAK cage.[1]Â  The BAK cage was a fairly new device, and just a few months earlier, Dr. Eline had trained to use the device.Â  However, the surgical procedure of performing an instrumental fusion was a routine part of Dr. Elineâ€™s practice, and Rodriguezâ€™s own expert, Dr. Dunn, testified that all cage devices are similar.Â  
During the surgery, a sales representative from Spinetech, the company that produces BAK cages, was present.Â  According to the Hospitalâ€™s policies, if a sales representative is in the operating room, the patient must be informed of the sales representativeâ€™s presence and the purpose of that presence.Â  Prior to surgery, Rodriguez signed a consent form authorizing Dr. Eline to perform the surgery with the help of â€œsuch assistants as may be selected by him;â€ however, Dr. Eline never specifically told Rodriguez a sales representative would be present.Â  
After the surgery, Dr. Eline continued to treat Rodriguez until January 1999.Â  Rodriguez was still experiencing pain, however, and he sought a second opinion from Dr. Donald R. Johnson of the Carolina Spine Institute.Â  Dr. Johnson discovered the cage Dr. Eline had inserted was impinging on a nerve.Â  Dr. Johnson performed another surgery on Rodriguez, this time removing the cage and replacing it with screws.Â  Dr. Johnson opined that the damage to Rodriguezâ€™s nerve was not entirely repairable and found Rodriguez had a fifty percent impairment rating and was no longer employable.Â  
Rodriguez and his wife commenced a medical malpractice action against Dr. Eline and LowCountry Bone & Joint Surgery, LLC on June 18, 2001.[2]Â  This complaint was amended numerous times.Â  Pursuant to these amendments, LowCountry Medical Group, LLC (the surgical group with which Dr. Eline was employed) and Beaufort Memorial Hospital were added as defendants.Â  The third amended complaint was served on the Hospital on January 3, 2002, asserting causes of action for medical malpractice, negligent supervision, and loss of consortium.Â  In late February 2002, the Hospital moved for summary judgment, arguing the two-year statute of limitations of the South Carolina Tort Claims Act barred the Rodriguezes from asserting a cause of action against it.Â  
In July of 2002, the Rodriguezes moved to amend their third amended complaint to assert an additional cause of action against the Hospital, alleging Rodriguezâ€™s rights under the Patientsâ€™ Bill of Rights were violated by the presence of the surgical salesperson in the operating room during Rodriguezâ€™s surgery.Â  In February of 2003, the trial court granted the Hospitalâ€™s motion for summary judgment, and therefore did not address the Rodriguezesâ€™ motion to amend.Â  
The Rodriguezes immediately appealed the grant of summary judgment, and Dr. Eline moved to stay the action against him pending the appeal.Â  As a result, the Rodriguezes withdrew their appeal, and the case was remitted to the circuit court on May 1, 2003. Â 
The Rodriguezesâ€™ action against Dr. Eline[3] went to trial on November 10, 2003.Â  The trial court directed a verdict in favor of Dr. Eline on the Rodriguezesâ€™ request for punitive damages as well as on their causes of action for lack of informed consent, battery, breach of fiduciary duty, and breach of contract. After hearing all of the evidence, the jury returned a verdict in favor of Dr. Eline.Â  The Rodriguezes filed a â€œMotion for JNOV and/or New Trial,â€ arguing the jury verdict was based on passion, prejudice, or caprice.Â  The Rodriguezes further argued a new trial was warranted because the trial court erred in granting a directed verdict on their causes of action for lack of informed consent and medical battery.Â  The trial court denied the motion, and this appeal followed.Â  
STANDARD OF REVIEW
In reviewing the grant of a summary judgment motion, the appellate court applies the same standard that governs the trial court under Rule 56(c), SCRCP. Nexsen v. Haddock, 353 S.C. 74, 77, 576 S.E.2d 183, 185 (Ct. App. 2002). Summary judgment is appropriate when it is clear that there is no genuine issue of material fact and that the moving party is entitled to a judgment as a matter of law.Â  In ruling on a motion for summary judgment, the evidence and the inferences which can be drawn therefrom should be viewed in the light most favorable to the non-moving party.Â  George v. Fabri, 345 S.C. 440, 452, 548 S.E.2d 868, 874 (2001). 
When ruling on directed verdict or JNOV motions, the trial court must view the evidence and the inferences that reasonably can be drawn therefrom in the light most favorable to the nonmoving party.Â  Sabb v. S.C. State Univ., 350 S.C. 416, 427, 567 S.E.2d 231, 236 (2002).Â  â€œIf the evidence as a whole is susceptible to more than one reasonable inference, a jury issue is created and the motion should have been denied.â€Â  Quesinberry v. Rouppasong, 331 S.C. 589, 594, 503 S.E.2d 717, 720 (1998).Â  â€œHowever, this rule does not authorize submission of speculative, theoretical, and hypothetical views to the jury.â€Â  Hanahan v. Simpson, 326 S.C. 140, 150, 485 S.E.2d 903, 908 (1997).Â Â Â  In essence, the court must determine whether a verdict for the opposing party â€œwould be reasonably possible under the facts as liberally construed in his favor.â€Â  Harvey v. Strickland, 350 S.C. 303, 309, 566 S.E.2d 529, 532 (2002). 
LAW/ANALYSIS
I.Â Â Â Â Â Â  Summary Judgment

The Rodriguezes first argue the trial court erred in granting summary judgment to the Hospital.Â  Specifically, they argue the two-year statute of limitations did not begin to run on their causes of action for lack of informed consent and violation of the Patientsâ€™ Bill of Rights until November of 2000, when they received discovery from the Hospital informing them a sales representative was in the operating room.Â Â  The Hospital argues the appeal from the trial courtâ€™s order of summary judgment is untimely because the Rodriguezes did not file their appeal until more than a year after the ruling.Â  We agree.
In Olson v. Faculty House of Carolina, Inc., 344 S.C. 194, 544 S.E.2d 38 (Ct. App. 2001) affirmed in result by 354 S.C. 161, 580 S.E.2d 440 (2003), our court addressed a similar situation and found the appeal was untimely.[4]Â  In Olson, the plaintiff was injured in November of 1995 while visiting a dining club on the University of South Carolinaâ€™s campus.Â  She filed an action against the dining club in March of 1997, and when she later discovered the club was owned by the University, she added the University as a defendant in January of 1998.Â  The University moved for summary judgment, arguing Olsonâ€™s claim was barred by the two-year statute of limitations set forth in South Carolina Tort Claims Act.Â  The trial court granted the motion, and Olson did not immediately appeal this ruling.Â  Instead, Olson pursued her actions against the dining club.Â  The dining club then moved for summary judgment, and the trial court granted it as to one of Olsonâ€™s causes of action.Â  Olson appealed this ruling as well as the earlier ruling granting summary judgment to the University.Â  Id. at 200, 544 S.E.2d at 41.
The University argued Olsonâ€™s appeal was untimely because she waited more than a year after the ruling before deciding to appeal.Â  Our court agreed, explaining:

  The order [granting summary judgment to the University] ruled that all of Olsonâ€™s claims against the University were barred by the statute of limitations.Â  This ruling therefore adjudicated all of the claims as to the University.Â  [The dining club] did not assert the statute of limitations as a defense.Â  Olsonâ€™s claims against [the dining club] were thus separate and dis[tinct] from her claim against the University.Â  The fact Olson had continuing claims against [the dining club] was irrelevant to the dismissal of the University.Â  Nothing short of direct appeal could resurrect the action against the University.

Id. at 214, 544 S.E.2d at 48 (emphasis in original).
Here, as in Olson, the trial court found that all of the claims against the Hospital were barred by the statute of limitations.Â  Thus, the trial courtâ€™s grant of summary judgment to the Hospital was a final order because it left nothing further for determination.Â  See S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 14-3-330 (1976 & Supp. 2004) (explaining which orders are appealable).Â  Because the order was final as to the University, the Rodriguezes were required to serve the appeal within thirty days after receiving the written order granting summary judgment.[5]Â  Initially, the Rodriguezes met this deadline; however, they withdrew their appeal, and the case was remitted to the circuit court.Â Â  Because this new appeal was filed more than a year after the order granting summary judgment, our court is without jurisdiction to entertain the appeal.
II.Â Â Â Â  Directed Verdict 
Rodriguez next argues the trial court erred in granting a directed verdict on his claim for lack of informed consent and battery.Â  We disagree.
Our court outlined the elements of informed consent in Hook v. Rothstein, 281 S.C. 541, 547, 316 S.E.2d 690, 695 (Ct. App. 1984):

  Under the doctrine of informed consent, it is generally held that a physician who performs a . . . surgical procedure has a duty to disclose to a patient of sound mind, I the absence of an emergency that warrants immediate medical treatment, (1) the diagnosis, (2) the general nature of the contemplated procedure, (3) the material risks involved in the procedure, (4) the probability of success associated with the procedure, (5) the prognosis if the procedure is not carried out, and (6) the existence of any alternatives to the procedure.

The Hook court went on to â€œreject the lay standard and [held] that the scope of a physicianâ€™s duty to disclose is measured by those communications a reasonable medical practitioner in the same branch of medicine would make under the same or similar circumstances.â€Â  Id. at 553, 316 S.E.2d at 698.Â  Expert medical evidence is ordinarily required to establish this standard.Â  Id.Â  
During trial, Rodriguez presented testimony from numerous experts, most of whom testified regarding damages.Â  Two experts, Dr. Robert Dunn and Dr. Francis Dyro, testified regarding the standard of care a surgeon should employ when performing back surgery, but neither testified that Dr. Eline deviated from the standard of care regarding informed consent.Â  Although Dr. Dunn stated it was unacceptable to violate Hospital policies, when asked directly if a violation of Hospital policy was a violation of the generally accepted standard of practice, Dr. Dunn stated, â€œWell, I mean a hospital wonâ€™t let you operate in a hospital that you donâ€™t have privileges in.Â  I mean â€“ â€¦ if they do, it a violation of their own policy.â€Â  This testimony fell far short of the â€œstandard of careâ€ expert testimony required by Hook.
Rodriguez argues Hookâ€™s requirement for expert testimony only applies when there are questions regarding â€œmaterial risks of the procedure and medical judgment not in the realm of the average man.â€Â  Rodriguez claims his case falls outside of Hook because it involves issues which are in the average manâ€™s realm, such as â€œ(1) risks of the surgery due to the surgeonâ€™s inexperience; (2) the patientâ€™s right to be informed, as dictated by the Board of Directors of [the Hospital]; and (3) the deliberate violation of [H]ospital policy in order to conceal Dr. Elineâ€™s inexperience.â€ Although Rodriguez cites many cases, none of them lend support to his argument that Hook should be so limited, and we therefore decline to distinguish this case from the precedent established in Hook.
Rodriguez further argues that even if Hook applies, the trial court erred in granting a directed verdict because one of Dr. Elineâ€™s experts testified at his deposition that the violation of hospital policy was a deviation from the generally accepted practice.Â  However, Dr. Elineâ€™s case was not before the trial court when it granted the directed verdict, and it would therefore be improper for our court to consider the testimony.Â  See Weir v. Citicorp Natâ€™l Servs., Inc., 312 S.C. 511, 514-15, 435 S.E.2d 864, 864 (1993) (explaining that the appellate court applies the same standard a trial court uses when considering a directed verdict motion).
We therefore find no error in the trial courtâ€™s grant of Dr. Elineâ€™s motion for a directed verdict on Rodriguezâ€™s cause of action for lack of informed consent.Â  Furthermore, because Rodriguezâ€™s cause of action for battery is premised on a lack of informed consent, we affirm the trial courtâ€™s decision to grant a directed verdict on that cause of action as well.Â  Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â  
III. JNOV and New Trial Motions
Finally, the Rodriguezes argue the trial court erred in failing to grant their JNOV and new trial motions because the trial court did not allow them to cross-examine two of Dr. Elineâ€™s experts about their relationship with the South Carolina Joint Underwriting Association (JUA).Â  However, the Rodriguezes failed to argue this ground in their JNOV and new trial motions.Â  Thus, it is not preserved for review.Â  Likewise, the Rodriguezesâ€™ argument that their motions for JNOV and new trial should have been granted because the testimony from Dr. Elineâ€™s experts was cumulative and prejudicial was not raised in their motions to the trial court.Â  Therefore, it too is not preserved for our review.Â  See Wilder Corp. v. Wilke, 330 S.C. 71, 76, 497 S.E.2d 731, 733 (1998).
CONCLUSION
Based on the foregoing, we decline to address the Rodriguezesâ€™ appeal against the Hospital because it was not served within thirty days of the trial courtâ€™s order granting summary judgment.Â  We affirm the trial courtâ€™s grant of a directed verdict in favor of Dr. Eline on Rodriguezâ€™s causes of action for lack of informed consent and battery.Â  Finally, we affirm the trial courtâ€™s denial of the Rodriguezesâ€™ JNOV and new trial motions.
DISMISSED IN PART AND AFFIRMED IN PART.
HEARN, C.J., and HUFF and BEATTY, JJ., concur. Â 

[1] A BAK cage is a small cylinder that is implanted into the hole where a diskectomy is done in order to get the bones to fuse.Â  
[2] LowCountry Bone & Joint Surgery was ultimately dismissed.Â  After Dr. Eline presented his case, both parties stipulated that he was employed by Lowcountry Medical Group, not LowCountry Bone & Joint Surgery. 
[3] As explained before, the Rodriguezes also sued two medical entities they claimed Dr. Eline was affiliated with.Â  For clarityâ€™s sake, Dr. Elineâ€™s name is used to refer to both him and his surgical group.
[4] The supreme courtâ€™s opinion in Olson does not address the timeliness of Olsonâ€™s appeal against the University. 
[5] The Rodriguezes argue they were not required to appeal the grant of summary judgment until the claims against all the defendants were resolved and cite to Link v. School Dist. of Pickens County, 302 S.C. 1, 393 S.E.2d 176 (1990) for this proposition.Â  However, the Link court found an appellant who had multiple claims against one defendant could wait to appeal the grant of summary judgment as to one of those claims until a final judgment disposing of all claims was entered.Â  Id. at 5-6, 393 S.E.2d at 178-79. The Link case did not involve multiple defendants, and therefore, is not controlling.
