title: Hurley v. Main
text:
THIS OPINION HAS NO PRECEDENTIAL VALUE.Â  IT SHOULD NOT BE CITED OR RELIED ON AS
PRECEDENT IN ANY PROCEEDING EXCEPT AS PROVIDED BY RULE 239(d)(2), SCACR.
THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Court of Appeals

  
    
      
Steve Hurley and Julie Hurley, Respondents,
v.
April Main, Keith Haynes, John Doe (Unknown Father), and Dorchester County Department of Social Services, Defendants, of whom April Main is,
Appellant.
In Re:Â  Anya Haynes and Azariah Haynes, minors under the age of eighteen (18) years.
      
    
  


Appeal From Dorchester County
Â Anne Gue Jones, Family Court Judge

Unpublished Opinion No.Â  2006-UP-056
Submitted January 3, 2006 â€“ Filed January 25, 2006

AFFIRMED


  
    
      
Gina J. McAlhany, of Summerville, for Appellant.
James B. Richardson, Jr., of Columbia, for Respondents.
      
    
  

PER CURIAM: April Main (Mother) appeals from an order of the family court terminating her parental rights over her twin daughters, Anya and Azariah Haynes.Â  We affirm.[1]
FACTS
In November of 2001, while pregnant with twins, Mother went to the hospital because she was experiencing labor pains.Â  She tested positive for cocaine.Â  However, when the twins were born on December 13, 2001, neither of them tested positive for drugs.Â  DSS allowed mother to keep custody of the children, but required her to go to New Life, an inpatient treatment facility for drug addicts.Â  Mother was unsuccessfully discharged in February of 2002, and the twins were placed in the custody of Steve and Judy Hurley on February 26, 2002, when they were two-and-a-half months old.[2]Â  
Tonya McCants, the foster care caseworker assigned to Motherâ€™s case, testified that Mother was discharged from New Life after testing positive for drugs; however according to the discharge summary, Mother was discharged for arguing with staff.Â  McCants also testified at one point that the children were born addicted to drugs, then corrected herself and said Mother tested positive for drugs when the twins were born.Â  However, McCants had no documentation to support that allegation, and she could not explain why DSS would have waited until February 26, 2002 to take custody of the children if Mother had tested positive for drugs at the childrenâ€™s birth in December.Â  
At the time Mother was discharged from New Life, she was also on probation, a condition of which required her to successfully complete inpatient drug treatment.Â  Because her discharge was a violation of probation, Mother was incarcerated.Â  
A hearing on the merits of the twinsâ€™ removal was held in March of 2001, and at that hearing, Mother and DSS agreed to a treatment plan.Â  Pursuant to the plan, Mother was required to complete a drug abuse counseling program; remain drug free; and upon her release from prison, seek stable housing and employment. 
While incarcerated, Mother enrolled in and completed drug treatment; she also completed a parenting class and participated in an educational skills class through which she received a certificate in keyboarding.Â  In addition to taking these classes, Mother sent letters to the twins, and DSS transported the twins to visit with Mother on at least seven occasions.Â  However, once DSS learned Mother would not be released from prison until fall of 2004, at the earliest, it recommended Motherâ€™s rights be terminated, and soon after that recommendation, visitation between Mother and the twins ceased.Â  
During her incarceration, Mother never sent money to the twins, though in April of 2002, she wrote a letter to DSS explaining that she had received a $1,100 tax refund and wanted to know how to send the money to her daughters.Â  DSS received the letter, but McCants testified she â€œd[id] not thinkâ€ she ever responded to it.Â  When Mother testified, she was asked extensively about how she spent the $1,100.Â  Motherâ€™s answers were evasive, and she could not even recollect whether she had purchased anything in the prison canteen over the past year.Â  
Mother testified that once she is released, she plans to live with the twins in a halfway house called Step Ahead.Â  She explained that they would live there for three to six months until she was able to find permanent housing.Â  However, Mother admitted she had not yet been accepted into the Step Ahead program, though she and her counselor were â€œworking on it.â€Â  
The twins have thrived in their current placement with the Hurleys, who have four other adopted children.Â  By all accounts, the Hurleys provide a loving household and have the financial resources to continue to care for the twins throughout their lives.[3]Â  Â 
The Hurleys filed a complaint in family court seeking to terminate Motherâ€™s parental rights to the twins on the grounds of the twins having languished in foster care for fifteen out of the last twenty-two months, Motherâ€™s failure to remedy conditions, Motherâ€™s diagnosable condition of substance abuse, and Motherâ€™s failure to support. Â The Hurleys also sought to adopt the twins.
The family court found the twins had been in foster care for fifteen out of the last twenty-two months, Mother had failed to support the twins for a period of six months, and Mother had failed to remedy conditions.Â  Based on these grounds and after finding termination was in the twinsâ€™ best interests, the family court terminated Motherâ€™s parental rights and granted the Hurleyâ€™s petition for adoption. This appeal followed.
STANDARD OF REVIEW
Â â€œ[I]n a TPR case, the appellate court has jurisdiction to examine the entire record to determine facts in accordance with its own view of the evidence.â€Â  Doe v. Baby Boy Roe, 353 S.C. 576, 579-80, 578 S.E.2d 733, 735 (Ct. App. 2003) (citing Richland County Depâ€™t of Soc. Servs. v. Earles, 330 S.C. 24, 32, 496 S.E.2d 864, 866 (1998)).Â  In determining whether to terminate parental rights, the grounds for TPR must be proved by clear and convincing evidence and the best interest of the child is the paramount consideration.Â  Id. at 579, 578 S.E.2d at 735.Â  The appellate court may review the record and make its own findings as to whether clear and convincing evidence supports the TPR.Â  Id. (citing S.C. Depâ€™t of Soc. Servs. v. Parker, 336 S.C. 248, 254, 519 S.E.2d 351, 354 (Ct. App. 1999)).Â  However, this broad scope of review does not require us to disregard the findings of the trial court or to ignore the fact that the court was in a better position to assess the credibility of witnesses.Â  Id. at 580, 578 S.E.2d at 735 (citing Dorchester County Depâ€™t of Soc. Servs. v. Miller, 324 S.C. 445, 452, 477 S.E.2d 476, 480 (Ct. App. 1996)).
LAW/ANALYSIS
Mother first argues the family court erred in terminating her parental rights based on the grounds of failure to support and failure to remedy conditions.Â  However, she does not appeal from the family courtâ€™s finding that the twins were in foster care for fifteen of the last twenty-two months. That unappealed ground alone is sufficient to terminate Motherâ€™s parental rights so long as termination is in the twinsâ€™ best interests.Â  See S.C. Dept. of Soc. Servs. v. Sims, 359 S.C. 601, 598 S.E.2d 303 (Ct. App. 2004); Doe v. Baby Boy Roe, 353 S.C. 576, 578 S.E.2d 733 (Ct. App. 2003) (finding that the ground of fifteen out of the last twenty-two months alone was sufficient to terminate Motherâ€™s parental rights when termination was in childâ€™s best interest).Â  Thus, we need not address whether there was sufficient evidence to support termination on the grounds of failure to remedy conditions and failure to support.
Mother next argues the family court erred in finding termination to be in the twinsâ€™ best interests.Â  We disagree.
At the time of the termination of parental rights hearing, the twins were two-and-a-half years old, and Mother had been incarcerated since they were just over two months old.Â  Though they have visited with Mother on seven occasions, the Hurleys have been the only parents the twins have ever known.Â  By everyoneâ€™s account, the twins have thrived while living with the Hurleys, and the Hurleysâ€™ home is a loving and stable environment.Â  
Mother, on the other hand, has a history of failing to parent her children.Â  Furthermore, although we commend Mother for completing drug treatment while in prison, we are concerned about her ability to remain drug-free upon her release.Â  According to Motherâ€™s own testimony, she successfully completed drug treatment in 1993, but was unable to stay clean. As the record shows, Mother did not even cease from drug-use while pregnant with the twins. Moreover, it is unclear where Mother will live upon her release from prison or what Mother will do to support herself and the twins.
Based on these circumstances, we find no error in the family courtâ€™s termination of Motherâ€™s parental rights.Â  See S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 20-7-1572 (Supp. 2004) (â€œThe family court may order the termination of parental rights upon a finding of one or more of the following grounds and a finding that termination is in the best interest of the child . . . .â€). Accordingly, the order of the family court is:
 AFFIRMED.
HEARN, C.J., and ANDERSON and KITTREDGE, JJ., concur.

[1] We decide this case without oral argument pursuant to Rule 215, SCACR.
[2] Mother has given birth to five other children in addition to the twins; however, none remain in Motherâ€™s custody.Â  The maternal grandmother adopted Motherâ€™s oldest child; Motherâ€™s second oldest child was privately adopted; Motherâ€™s parental rights to her third child were terminated in Florida; Mother consented to the adoption of her fourth child after DSS became involved; and Motherâ€™s fifth child lives with relatives of the father.Â  
[3] Â In fact, the Hurleys have been named â€œAdoptive Family of the Yearâ€ and â€œOutstanding Volunteer Foster Parents of the Year.â€Â

title: State v. Barnes
text:
THIS OPINION HAS NO PRECEDENTIAL VALUE.Â  IT SHOULD NOT BE CITED OR RELIED ON AS
PRECEDENT IN ANY PROCEEDING EXCEPT AS PROVIDED BY RULE 239(d)(2), SCACR.
THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Court of Appeals


  
    
      
The State, Respondent,
v.
Marcus Barnes, Appellant.
      
    
  


Appeal From Lancaster County
Kenneth G. Goode, Circuit Court Judge

Unpublished Opinion No. 2006-UP-057
Submitted January 1, 2006 â€“ Filed January 26, 2006

AFFIRMED


  
    
      
Assistant Appellate Defender Tara S. Taggart, of Columbia, for Appellant.Â  
Attorney General Henry Dargan McMaster, Chief Deputy Attorney General John W. McIntosh, Assistant Deputy Attorney General Salley W. Elliott, and Senior Assistant Attorney General Harold M. Coombs, Jr., all of Columbia; and Solicitor John R. Justice, of Chester, for Respondent.
      
    
  

PER CURIAM:Â  Marcus Barnes appeals his sentence of ten years for possession of a weapon during the commission of a crime of violence.Â  We affirm.[1]
FACTS
In September 2003, Barnes pled guilty to charges of assault with intent to kill, second-degree burglary, and possession of a weapon during the commission of a violent crime.Â  Barnes was sentenced to ten years in prison on each charge with the sentences to run concurrently.Â  
LAW/ANALYSIS
Barnes appeals his sentence as to the weapons possession charge arguing that the relevant sentencing statute provides for a maximum sentence of five years.Â  He further asserts that the trial courtâ€™s sentencing error rendered his guilty pleas on all charges involuntary.

S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 16-23-490 (2003) provides:
  
(A)Â  If a person is in possession of a firearm or visibly displays what appears to be a firearm or visibly displays a knife during the commission of a violent crime and is convicted of committing or attempting to commit a violent crime as defined in Section 16-1-60, he must be imprisoned five years, in addition to the punishment provided for the principal crime. 
  

According to the record and the sentence imposed, it appears that the trial court read this provision to mean that a sentence for the specific charge of possession of a weapon during the commission of a violent crime could be as lengthy as five years, plus the maximum allowable sentence for the most serious underlying offense.Â  The maximum sentence for second-degree burglary is fifteen years.Â  S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 16-11-312(C) (2003).Â  The trial court concluded the maximum sentence on the weapons charge was therefore twenty years, and he sentenced Barnes to ten years.Â  
Regardless of the propriety of the sentence, no objection was made to the sentencing explanation given or sentence imposed by the trial court.Â  Consequently, this issue is not preserved for our review.Â  State v. Johnston, 333 S.C. 459, 462, 510 S.E.2d 423, 425 (1999) (â€œ[T]his Court has consistently held that a challenge to sentencing must be raised at trial, or the issue will not be preserved for appellate review.â€).Â  Barnes should seek redress via an application for post-conviction relief.Â  See State v. Passmore, 363 S.C. 568, 586, 611 S.E.2d 273, 283 (Ct. App. 2005), cert. pending, (internal citations omitted) (â€œIn criminal cases, although the failure of
an attorney to preserve an issue at trial will preclude appellate review of that issue, it may nonetheless be a ground in a civil action for post-conviction relief as a claim of ineffective assistance of counsel.â€).Â  
Barnes contends that an exception can be made to this rule where a defendant runs the risk of being incarcerated beyond the legal sentence due to the additional time it will take to pursue such a remedy.Â  See Johnston at 463-64, 510 S.E.2d at 425.Â  This is not such a case.Â  Barnes is serving ten-year sentences for the burglary and assault charges concurrently with his sentence on the weapons charge.Â  Consequently, his incarceration pursuant to the proper sentences for burglary and assault with intent to kill will continue for a period that should allow him ample time to pursue relief through the proper procedure.
Barnes further argues that certain restrictions, including ineligibility for parole or work release, associated with the weapons charge could be applied to him for the entire ten-year period making it imperative that his appeal be expedited.Â  See S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 16-23-490(C) (2003).Â  However, there is no reason to believe that the probation, pardon and parole board would impose those restrictions beyond the five-year period, assuming the ten-year sentence was excessive.Â  Furthermore, it is likely that Barnesâ€™ post-conviction relief application could be disposed of within the five-year period where such restrictions are mandated.Â  
The voluntariness of Barnesâ€™ pleas is likewise an issue not properly before this court.Â  A guilty plea is subject to attack on the issue of its being made knowingly and voluntarily, but absent a timely objection during the guilty plea proceeding, the unknowing or involuntary nature of the guilty plea cannot be raised on direct appeal but must be addressed through the more appropriate channel of post-conviction relief.Â  State v. McKinney, 278 S.C. 107, 108, 292 S.E.2d 598, 599 (1982). 
AFFIRMED.
STILWELL, KITTREDGE, and WILLIAMS, JJ., concur.

[1] Â Â Â Â Â Â  We decide this case without oral argument pursuant to Rule 215, SCACR.

text:
THIS OPINION HAS NO PRECEDENTIAL VALUE.Â  IT SHOULD NOT BE CITED OR RELIED ON AS
PRECEDENT IN ANY PROCEEDING EXCEPT AS PROVIDED BY RULE 239(d)(2), SCACR.
THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Court of Appeals

  
    
      
Shannon L. Beish Appellant, 
v.
Mint Management, Inc., d/b/a Scottish Inn - Hardeeville,
Respondent.
AND
Clarence A. Beish, Appellant,
        v.
Mint Management, Inc., d/b/a Scottish Inn - Hardeeville,
Respondent.
      
    
  


Appeals From Jasper County
Â Daniel F. Pieper, Circuit Court Judge

Unpublished Opinion No.Â  2006-UP-059
Submitted December 1, 2005 â€“ Filed January 26, 2006

AFFIRMED


  
    
      
Darrell T. Johnson, Jr. and Warren P. Johnson, both of Hardeeville, for Appellants.
Rebecca Lafitte and Robert E. Horner, both of Columbia, for Respondent.
      
    
  

PER CURIAM:Â  Shannon Beish and her husband, Clarence Beish,[1] each brought suit against Scottish Inn after Shannon allegedly tripped and fell in the entryway to the motel due to a defective strip that covered a transition from the tile in the entryway to the carpet on the interior of the motel.Â  The trial court granted a directed verdict in favor of the Motel.Â  We affirm.
1.Â Â Â Â Â Â  It is well settled in South Carolina that â€œ[a] merchant is not the insurer of his customerâ€™s safety; rather, a merchant owes his customer the duty to exercise ordinary care to keep his premises in a reasonably safe condition.â€Â  Young v. Meeting Street Piggly Wiggly, 288 S.C. 508, 510, 343 S.E.2d 636, 637 (Ct. App. 1986). A customer seeking to recover damages for injuries sustained on a storekeeperâ€™s premises must show either: â€œ(1) that the injury was caused by a specific act of the [storekeeper] which created the dangerous condition; or (2) that the [storekeeper] had actual or constructive knowledge of the dangerous condition and failed to remedy it.â€Â  Garvin v. Bi-Lo, Inc., 343 S.C. 625, 628, 541 S.E.2d 831, 832 (2001) (citations omitted).Â  The Beishes first argue the trial court erred in requiring them to â€œshow actual or constructive notice of a hazard or an impending hazard originating with the premises itself.â€Â  After reviewing the record, we find the trial court did not impose such a requirement.Â  To the contrary, in a pre-trial colloquy it was established that the Beishes theory of recovery was not based on notice, but rather that the motel created a dangerous condition that led to Shannonâ€™s injury.Â  Accordingly, we find this argument to be without merit.
2.Â Â Â Â Â Â  Â  The Beishes next argue the trial court erred in finding there was no evidence presented from which one could infer the motel had actual or constructive notice of the dangerous condition.Â  To support this argument they note that evidence was presented which showed the motel clerk was seated directly in front of the entrance and approximately ten feet from where Shannon fell.Â  However, the fact that the alleged dangerous condition was within an employeeâ€™s field of vision alone is not enough to prove the motelâ€™s negligence.Â Â Â  See e.g., Gillespie v. Wal-Mart Stores, Inc., 302 S.C. 90, 91, 394 S.E.2d 24, 25 (Ct. App. 1990) (â€œThe mere fact that water was on the floor of the store and was within the field of vision of a nearby store employee at the time Gillespie slipped upon it is not by itself enough evidence to Wal-Mart with negligence.â€); Hunter v. Dixie Home Stores, 232 S.C. 139, 101 S.E.2d 262 (1957) (holding that even though two employees were standing in proximity to where plaintiff fell, one ten to twelve feet away and the other 25 or 30 feet away, this alone was not enough evidence to establish the defendant had notice of the dangerous condition).Â  
AFFIRMED.  [2]
STILWELL, KITTREDGE, and WILLIAMS, J.J., concur.

[1] Shannon Beish brought a general negligence action and Clarence Beish brought a loss of consortium claim.Â  Although the cases were appealed to this court separately, because the issues complained of are identical, we combined the appeals for purposes of this decision.
[2] We decide this case without oral argument pursuant to Rule 215, SCACR.

text:
THIS OPINION HAS NO PRECEDENTIAL VALUE.Â  IT SHOULD NOT BE CITED OR RELIED ON AS 
 PRECEDENT IN ANY PROCEEDING EXCEPT AS PROVIDED BY RULE 239(D)(2), SCACR.
THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Court of Appeals


  
    
      
Hank Singleton, Appellant,
v.
Stevens Shipping & Terminal Co., Employer, and Genesis, Carrier,
Respondents.
      
    
  


Appeal From Charleston County
Â Thomas L. Hughston, Jr., Circuit Court Judge

Unpublished Opinion No. 2006-UP-066
Submitted January 1, 2006 â€“ Filed January 26, 2006

AFFIRMED


  
Malcolm M. Crosland, Jr., of Charleston, for Appellant.
J. Hubert Wood, III, and J. Alexandra van Staveren, both of Charleston, for Respondents.
  

PER CURIAM:Â  Hank Singleton appeals the trial courtâ€™s denial and dismissal of his appeal from the Workersâ€™ Compensation Commission.Â  Singleton argues the trial court erred as a matter of law in failing to apply the appropriate methodology for calculating his average weekly wage as defined under section 42-1-40 of the South Carolina Code (Supp. 2005).Â  We affirm.[1]Â  
FACTS
On June 9, 2000, Hank Singleton was involved in an accident arising out of and in the course of his employment with Stevens Shipping and Terminal Company at the Wando Terminal in Mt. Pleasant, South Carolina.Â  Singleton was operating a hustler machine when a crane picked up a container that was not properly detached and caused the hustler machine to be lifted and dropped.Â Â Â Â Â  
At the time of the accident, Singleton was a member of the Longshoreman Association and was classified as a Journeyman.Â  As a Journeyman, a classification achieved by working over seven hundred hours on the docks, Singleton was able to obtain seniority over newcomers and could get work before others.Â  Singleton had been working at the waterfront for about five years.Â  Just before his injury, Singleton worked, on average, three to four days a week and was only paid for the time he worked.Â  Â Singleton never made more than $7,000 a year.
Singleton was chosen to be an Operator for the Nucor Scrap Gang.Â  However, Singleton was injured before the list was made public.Â  A typical member of the Nucor Scrap Gang earns $13.50 per hour, works ten to eleven hour days about seven days a week, and makes a weekly wage between $700 and $800.Â  
A Single Commissioner of the Workersâ€™ Compensation Commission held a hearing on May 31, 2002 to determine if Stevens was required to pay compensation to Singleton.Â  The Commissioner found Singleton was entitled to compensation, and determined Singletonâ€™s compensation rate was $86.78 based on an average weekly wage of $130.10.Â  The average weekly wage was reached by taking one half of Singletonâ€™s earnings for 1999, combining those with his earnings from 2000, and dividing the total by forty-nine weeks (the number of weeks from July 1, 1999 through date of Singletonâ€™s injury).Â  The Commissioner cited Singletonâ€™s sporadic work history, Singletonâ€™s documented earnings for 1999 and 2000, Singletonâ€™s admission that he has never earned more than $7,000 in a calendar year, and testimony indicating Singleton had a little more than seven hundred documented work hours on the waterfront since becoming a longshoreman in 1996, as evidence supporting the decision.Â  
Singleton appealed the Commissionerâ€™s decision to the Workersâ€™ Compensation Commission.Â  The Commission affirmed the Single Commissionerâ€™s order in its entirety.Â  
Singleton appealed the Commissionâ€™s decision to the trial court.Â  The trial court found substantial evidence to support the Commissionâ€™s decision, and therefore, denied and dismissed Singletonâ€™s appeal.Â  This appeal followed.Â  
STANDARD OF REVIEW
â€œThe South Carolina Administrative Procedures Act governs judicial review of a decision of an administrative agency.â€Â  Clark v. Aiken County Govâ€™t, 366 S.C. 102, 107, 620 S.E.2d 99, 101 (Ct. App. 2005) (citing S.C. Code Ann. Â§Â§ 1-23-310 to -400 (Supp. 2005)). Â Section 1-23-380(A)(6) of the South Carolina Code (Supp. 2005) establishes the substantial evidence rule as the standard of review.Â  Lark v. Bi-Lo, Inc., 276 S.C. 130, 133, 276 S.E.2d 304, 305 (1981).Â  Under this standard, a reviewing court may reverse or modify an agency decision based on errors of law, but may only reverse or modify an agencyâ€™s findings of fact if they are clearly erroneous. Â See S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 1-23-380(A)(6)(d) and (e) (Supp. 2005).Â  
â€œ[T]his court must affirm an award of the Workersâ€™ Compensation Commission in which the circuit court concurred if substantial evidence supports the findings.â€ Â Solomon v. W.B. Easton, Inc., 307 S.C. 518, 520, 415 S.E.2d 841, 843 (Ct. App. 1992).Â  â€œSubstantial evidence is evidence which, considering the record as a whole, would allow reasonable minds to reach the conclusion that the administrative agency reached to justify its action.â€ Â Howell v. Pac. Columbia Mills, 291 S.C. 469, 471, 354 S.E.2d 384, 385 (1987).Â  â€œThe possibility of drawing two inconsistent conclusions from the evidence does not prevent the commissionâ€™s findings from being supported by substantial evidence.â€Â  Sellers v. Pinedale Residential Ctr., 350 S.C. 183, 188, 564 S.E.2d 694, 697 (Ct. App. 2002).Â  
LAW/ANALYSIS
Singleton argues the trial court failed to apply the appropriate methodology for calculating his average weekly wage.Â  We disagree. 

Section 42-1-40 of the South Carolina Code (Supp. 2005) provides:
  
â€˜Average weekly wagesâ€™ means the earnings of the injured employee in the employment in which he was working at the time of the injury during the period of fifty-two weeks immediately preceding the date of the injury . . . . â€˜Average weekly wageâ€™ must be calculated by taking the total wages paid for the last four quarters immediately preceding the quarter in which the injury occurred . . . divided by fifty-two or by the actual number of weeks for which wages were paid, whichever is less.Â  [portions omitted]
When for exceptional reasons the foregoing would be unfair, either to the employer or employee, such other method of computing average weekly wages may be resorted to as will most nearly approximate the amount which the injured employee would be earning were it not for the injury.
  

â€œThe statute provides an elasticity or flexibility with a view toward always achieving the ultimate objective of reflecting fairly a claimantâ€™s probable future earning loss.â€Â  Sellers, 350 S.C. at 191, 564 S.E.2d at 698.Â  â€œMoreover, it is well established that the objective of wage calculation is to arrive at a fair approximation of the claimantâ€™s probable future earning capacity.â€Â  Elliott v. S.C. Depâ€™t of Transp., 362 S.C. 234, 238, 607 S.E.2d 90, 92 (Ct. App. 2004).
The Commissioner found no exceptional circumstances to justify the calculation of an average weekly wage based on speculative future earnings.Â  We find, based on the substantial evidence standard of review, reasonable minds could reach the conclusion the Commissioner and, subsequently, the Commission reached.Â  Singletonâ€™s pay and hours are both speculative because, at the time of the injury, he had not started working with the Nucor Scrap Gang. Â In fact, the record indicates Singleton was never offered a job with the Nucor Scrap Gang; Singleton was merely â€œchosen to be the operatorâ€ but before the list was put out, he was injured.Â  In addition, Singleton had an established work history and no demonstrated commitment to working more than three or four days a week.[2]
CONCLUSION
Based on the above, we find the trial court did not err in dismissing and denying Singletonâ€™s appeal.Â  The decision of the trial court is accordingly 
 AFFIRMED.
KITTREDGE, WILLIAMS, JJ., AND CURETON, A.J.,
concur.

[1] We decide this case without oral argument, pursuant to Rule 215, SCACR.Â  
[2] We note that this case can be distinguished from cases when the reviewing court found exceptional circumstances existed.Â  In those cases, either the claimant had a guaranteed, proven raise or other exceptional circumstances existed that are not present here.Â  See, e.g., Elliott, 362 S.C. at 238, 607 S.E.2d at 92 (finding exceptional circumstances when the claimant was given a merit based award that was not speculative and was already in place at the time of the accident); see also, Booth v. Midland Trane Heating & Air Conditioning, 298 S.C. 251, 379 S.E.2d 730 (Ct. App. 1989) (finding claimantâ€™s average weekly wage should be calculated based solely on new wage because raise given four months before injury); see also Sellers, 350 S.C. 183, 564 S.E.2d 694 (Ct. App. 2002) (affirming Commissionâ€™s finding that exceptional circumstances existed to calculate wage based on future projections when claimant was young, seriously injured, and had a good work ethic).
